link.heading: Examining measurement of the psychological empowerment of public librarians based on the spritzer model
link.authors: Riahinia Nosrat1, Abdollahi Bijan2, Anjami Zainab3, Zeinali Vahide4, Salimi Zahra5
link.authorDes: 1Full Professor, Library and Information Science Department, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran (corresponding author)2Department of Educational Management, Faculty of Management and Accounting, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran3MA. Library and information sciences, University of Kharazmi, Tehran, Iran4Ph. D. Library and information Sciences, Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran5MA. Library and Information Sciences, University of Kharazmi, Tehran, Iran
link.abstract: The purpose of this study is to investigate the psychological empowerment of public libraries librarians of Ardabil province based on the Spritzer Model and prioritize factors affecting it.The study is descriptive based on survey. The research community consisted of 112 people; of whom 96 were studied in the census method. The data were collected through two questionnaires to measure psychological empowerment of the Spritzter model and effective factors. To analyze the obtained data, one sample t test, one-way variance analysis and Duncan's test for comparison of averages at a probability level of 0.05 and multivariate regression test to determine the most important predictors of librarians’ empowerment in the research community of the 13 components that were effective on the ability, were used.The mean of librarians’ psychological empowerment was 5.55 meaningful career sense 26/6; competence sense 25/6; sense of autonomy 25/5; effective sense 18/5; and the sense of confidence was 81/4. In addition, the results of stepwise multivariate regression analysis showed that from the point of view of the librarians of Ardabil province among the 13 components affecting on capability, they have a greater impact on the ability of their capability to prioritize order, independence, participatory management, group formation, information provision, access to resources and arousal excitement are more effective than other components.The research community in each of the five dimensions of empowerment was satisfactory and acceptable. It can be said that librarians of public libraries in Ardebil province have a good psychological ability.
link.keywords: Empowerment, Spritzer Model, Librarians, Public Libraries.

link.heading: Awareness About Public Library Resources in Rural Varanasi: AStudy
link.authors: Chauhan Ashish Kumar1, Dr. Mrs Kumbar Rashmi T2
link.authorDes: 1Project Assistant, INFLIBNET Centre, Gandhinagar, Gujarat. ashishharry555@gmail.com, 080909704452Assistant Professor, Central University of Gujarat, Gujarat. rashmi.kumbar@cug.ac.in, 09825600176
link.abstract: This paper is an attempt to study public library awareness in the society. The significance of the public library, especially in mass literacy and in informing people regarding the nation and government is beyond dispute. Nevertheless, what if there exists the least communication between society and the library? While government (both central and state) is so committed about accomplishing goals of public welfare, why still basic illiteracy clings to village people? Is there a major breach between govt. institutions and their public reach? Most importantly, how much the local student fraternity are aware of or access public library? To investigate few such issues, A field research was conducted on few villages at the vicinity of Varanasi. Following the survey method, each data have been sampled and evaluated for the optimal utilization to diagnose the problems and to suggest some efficient methods to overcome those obstacles for constructing a better society, a better nation.
link.keywords: Public Library System, Rural Varanasi, District Library, Infrastructure facilities, public library awareness, information literacy, digital collection.

link.heading: Authorship Trends and Collaborative Research in Physics: Bibliometric Study of Publications in Pramana-Journal of Physics 2006–2015
link.authors: Sharma Pratibha1, Dr. Mahapatra R K2
link.authorDes: 1Library & Information Officer, Indian Institute of Mass Communication, New Delhi, 110067, E-mail: pratibha.iimc@gmail.com2Associate Professor & Head, Department of Library & Information Science, Tripura University, Tripura, E-mail: rkmahapatra@tripurauniv.in
link.abstract: The proposed study carried out the analysis of bibliometric parameters including publishing trends, authorship pattern of contributions, institution-wise distribution of contributions, country-wise distributions of contributions, intellectual collaborations and productivity of the journal, authorship pattern of the articles contributed by scientists and researchers during 2006–2015 in Pramana-Journal of Physics. The data has been collected from the Web of Science (WoS) database for 10 years. The findings reveal that 2133 articles with 6913 citations were contributed by 4023 authors in Pramana during ten years (2006–2015). Maximum number of citations were received by articles during 2008 and most of the articles were written in shared responsibility.
link.keywords: Bibliometric Management, Bibliometric Methods, Bibliometric Analysis, Citation Analysis, Authorship Pattern.

link.heading: Library Trends and Technologies in Higher Education Institutes in Thailand: A Study
link.authorDes: 1Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai-400088, India. garimagujral9@gmail.com, 98715261032Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai-400088, India
link.abstract: The shift from traditional libraries to digital libraries has transformed how users access and interact with information. Higher education institutions across the world have realized the importance of information literacy. Mahasarakham University considered to be the educational hub of North Eastern Thailand, was studied for this research. This paper reflects upon the users’ opinion and level of satisfaction about various sections and services provided by the Academic Resource Centre, Mahasarakham University, Thailand. Discusses the information access pattern, preferred format of documents and users’ opinion regarding open access. Traces the advancements and innovations in technology that have had a tremendous impact on the way libraries function and have fuelled Thailand's shift from an industrial economy to a knowledge economy. The significant findings of the study in the context of library trends and technologies are 34.2% of users used electronic resources every day. E-Books were the most preferred format of document for 65% of users. 12% of users strongly agreed that lack of access to computers make use of e-Resources is the cause of no-development. 37% of users strongly agreed that students are leading users of eresources. 44% of users felt that management should provide the necessary infrastructure for the success of e-Resource development.13% Users strongly agreed that Information Communication Technology (ICT) facilitates quick access to information. 40% of users agreed that the application of ICT reduces workload; 27% of users agreed that “Open access provides larger potential evidence and audience.”
link.keywords: Libraries, Thailand, Information Communication Technology, Library trends and technologies, Digital literacy.

link.heading: Book Acquisition using Koha A Case study of Rabindra Granthagar, Assam University Central Library
link.authors: Sharma AK1, Roy Tuhina Choudhury Deb2
link.authorDes: 1Librarian, Rabindra Granthagar, Assam University, Silchar2Professional Assistant, Rabindra Granthagar, Assam University, Silchar
link.abstract: The present paper projects the status of library automation using acquisition module of Koha-an open source library integrated software in Rabindra Library of Assam University, Silchar. Technology has overpowered the manual systems of various house-keeping operations of the libraries. With the advent of smartphones or android phones, librarians are forced to provide the notifications of the libraries on the android phones of the patrons-be it catalogue, any new service or transaction details or otherwise. Like other service sectors such as Bank, Airlines, etc. libraries are forced to adopt new technologies and serve their users in a better way by making use of the technology. Libraries are forced to adopt the required transformation in their look, services in a better positive way. Modern techniques have become more indispensible for quick and prompt services as users are very demanding and their patience level is very low. A properly computerized library helps in expeditious retrieval and dissemination of information as well as other library services in smoother and more efficient way. Acquisition section is one of the most important sections of the library which deals with the procurement of documents and their efficiency and promptness reflects the related activities of the libraries. By implementing acquisition module of Koha in the section, Rabindra library could integrate all the activities of the library more effectively and efficiently and make its patrons more satisfied. This paper mainly projects a case study of acquisition module of Koha and its implementation in Rabindra Library, Assam University, Silchar.
link.keywords: Library automation, Open Source Software, Koha, Library Management, Library Acquisition.

link.heading: Content Management using Google Website and the Formation of Digital Libraries: A Case Study on NIFM Library Website
link.authorDes: 1Sr. Library & Information Assistant, National Institute of Financial Management, nandk1981@gmail.com2Deputy Librarian, National Institute of Financial Management, Faridabad, Haryana
link.abstract: In the era of digitization, it is becoming a need of Library and Information Managers (LIMs) to prepare an environment of the digital library. This environment provides library users with easy access to the library collection in online search, full text documents search, information sharing, online public access catalogue (OPAC) etc. A website can provide all the information related to the library at one place. Library and Information Manager (LIM) is not a web designer but has to organize information from time to time for the users on the web with the help of Google website. This process can be easily implemented in the library to keep the users updated. Google website allows designing a website in an easy way which is discussed in this paper as an example of a website of National Institute of Financial Management's Library, Faridabad.
link.keywords: Library website, Content Management, Open Source, Google Site, Digital Library, NIFM Library, Google Tools, World Wide Web, Online Library.

link.heading: Use of Institutional Repository Software in Private Autonomous Engineering College Libraries of Andhra Pradesh
link.authors: Kiran VV Lakshmi Ravi1, Rao K Venkata2
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Rayalaseema University, Kurnool, 518007. Contact: 9949023845, Email: vvlravikiran@gmail.com2University Librarian, Acharya Nagarjuna University, Nagarjuna Nagar, 522510. Contact: 9440110301, Email: kodela2006@yahoo.com
link.abstract: This work examines the issues related to use of institutional repository software among the private autonomous engineering college libraries of Andhra Pradesh. The paper tries to assess the purpose and scope of the use of institutional repository software in libraries. Andhra Pradesh had a total of fifty autonomous engineering colleges up to academic year 2018–19 as per UGC (https://ugc.ac.in/subpage/Autonomous_Colleges.aspx)1, out of which, five are government autonomous engineering colleges, and the remaining 45 are under private management. The forty five private autonomous engineering college libraries were selected for the study. Open form questionnaire was mailed to all the librarians for a free response in the respondents own words. The questionnaire related to resources available in the institutional repository software among the college libraries. Primary data were received from eight colleges on appointment visit, fifteen colleges sent it by post, eighteen colleges sent by e-mail and four colleges did not respond. The response rate was 91 percent. Out of 41 colleges only 13(31%) colleges were maintaining institutional repository software out of which 5 are using open source software, 8, in-house developed software and no one uses commercial software. The study suggests needful and helpful findings for librarians to make and implement institutional repository software in their colleges.
link.keywords: Autonomous engineering colleges, institutional repository software, opensource software, in-house software, commercial software.

link.heading: News & Events
Investigating Factors Affecting Librarians’ Confidence in Academic Libraries
link.authors: Mahmoudi Aisha1, Riahinia Nosrat2, Hamidrezaarasteh3, Vahidezeinali4, Salimi Zahra5
link.authorDes: 1MA. Library and information sciences, University of Kharazmi, Tehran, Iran2Full Professor, Library and Information Science Department, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran (corresponding author)3Department of Educational Management, Faculty of Management and Accounting, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran4PhD. Library and information sciences, Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran5MA. Library and information sciences, University of Kharazmi, Tehran, Iran
link.keywords: Trust, Librarians, Academic Libraries, Tehran, Iran.

link.heading: Human Orientation: Origin, Concept and Applicability to Libraries-Dialogue with Pioneers
link.authors: Mrs Rakshikar Nidhi Niwant1, Dr Powdwal Sushama C.2
link.authorDes: 1Librarian, Asmita College of Arts and Commerce for Women, nidhi25librarian@gmail.com2Retired University Librarian and Head SHPT School of Library Science of SNDT Women University, spowdwal@gmail.com
link.abstract: Human orientation (HO) science is a concept coined in the year 1993 and was initially applied to transportation terminals as a public place. It is not yet found to be applied to libraries as public or community places.The present article portrays the contribution of two pioneering scholars who promoted the concept of Human Orientation Science and applied the same to various areas like transport, health and banking sectors. Further, the article presents application side/features of the concept with the help of interviews of the experts conducted as a part of the research.
link.keywords: Community places, First-time library users, Human Orientation Science, Interviews with pioneers, Libraries, Signage, Wayfinding, Ergonomics.

link.heading: LIS Education in India: Emerging Trends and Challenges
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, Central Library, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi-110016. vanita@library.iitd.ac.in
link.abstract: LIS education in India is century old. This paper deals with how LIS education in India has been started and how it has been affected by the technological advancements. It also highlights the level of courses provided by the universities, colleges, polytechnics, library associations and documentation centres. The paper also endeavoured to highlight the committees and commissions formed by the Government of India and University Grants Commission (UGC) for the development of the libraries and LIS education. Different challenges affecting LIS education and the solutions to those challenges have been carefully dealt with. This paper will be helpful for all the LIS teachers, students, and LIS professionals in understanding the need of change in LIS curriculum keeping at par with the technology.
link.keywords: Library and Information Science Education; Library; LIS Schools; UGC; Curriculum and CBCS.

link.heading: Accountability in Research: A Bibliometric Analysis
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Librarian, Indira Gandhi National Tribal University, Amarkantak, mohitji@igntu.ac.in2Library Information Assistant, Indian Institute of Advanced Study, Shimla, priyarangra26494@gmail.com
link.abstract: Accountability in Research is a peer-reviewed bi-monthly journal published by Taylor & Francis. The present bibliometric study analyzed 575 scholarly communications published in the journal during 1989 to 2018. The study highlights the distribution of articles, authorship patterns, collaborative coefficient, H-classic publication, research themes of the journal. The study found that half of the papers were authored by single author (290 papers, 50.43%). The results indicated that the growth of articles in the journal increased from 9 articles in 1989 to 30 articles in 2018. Majority of the contributions was by United States in every respect. The study found that United States has received highest number of citations (2528 citations, 77.43%), but in terms of CPP value the impact of papers of Australia is much higher than any other country including United States. The CPP value of 575 papers was 5.68. Elliott, K.C. contributed papers with highest CPP value of 15.33. The study showed that the collaborative research work has been increased among the authors of the journal. The journal has published 24 h-classic papers in last three decades.
link.keywords: Bibliometrics, Accountability in Research, Authorship pattern, Collaborative Coefficient, H-Classic.

link.heading: Open Access Repositories: A Global Perspective with a Special Emphasis on India and China
link.authorDes: 1Professional Assistant, Indian Institute of Advanced Study, Shimla. suresh19871987@gmail.com2Library Information Assistant, National Institute of Technology, Silchar. swarnika.dey1988@gmail.com
link.abstract: Previously research was dependent more on print form for disseminating institutional research output, but after the development of digital technologies like Institutional repositories, researchers of every organizations are now in a better position to share their intellectual scholarly research output to the digital world in a fast, easy and convenient way. Institutional repository is one of the model of open access which improves the visibility of an organization globally. This paper aims to analyze the current status of the two countries India and China which are registered in the Open Directory of Open Access Repository (OpenDOAR). During this study, it was found that, 79 repositories are from India and 40 repositories are from China out of 119 repositories. The major achieving content is journals articles 96 (166%) in China 37 (92%) and India 59 (74%). The study also found that most of the open access repositories are institutional repositories from India 67 (85%) and China 39 (97%) followed by disciplinary, aggregating and governmental.
link.keywords: Repositories, Institutional Repositories, Open Access Repository, OpenDOAR, India, China.

link.heading: Need of Information Literacy in Higher Education
link.authorDes: Librarian, Central Library, MET's Institute of Engineering, Bhujbal Knowledge City, Adgaon, Nashik-3, Maharashtra. sambhajipatil07@gmail.com
link.abstract: The knowledge economy is based primarily on the production and strategic use of information and knowledge. The ability to produce and use information effectively is thus a vital source of skills for citizens of the world. As India is moving towards information and knowledge-based society, it must be necessary for university students, research scholars and faculty members to possess competencies and information literacy skills to accomplish their research goals. Information literacy(IL) is becoming an increasingly important component of the higher educational curriculum, with many disciplines incorporating elements of information literacy training within their traditional teaching. This article will highlight on necessity and importance of information literacy in higher education.
link.keywords: Information Literacy, Higher Education, Critical Thinking, Life Long Learning, Information Skills.

link.heading: Information Needs of Distance Learners in Bangalore University, Bangalore: A Study
link.authorDes: Research Scholar, Bangalore University, smilingfriends18@gmail.com
link.abstract: The study focuses on the information needs of distance learners of the Bangalore University, Bangalore, Karnataka. The main objective was to know the information needs of postgraduate commerce students. The study was a survey and made use of a questionnaire as research instrument. The stratified random sampling technique was used. Total 100 questionnaires were distributed randomly to the distance learners. 88 questionnaires were received back from the respondents. Based on the findings, it was recommended among other things that distance learners expected the university library to provide more library materials and services. Distance learners need awareness programme on e-PG Patashala and use of the digital information on their course. Distance learners lack information searching techniques and skills, for that Bangalore University can conduct the refresher course for the students.
link.keywords: Distance learners, Information needs, Bangalore University, Survey method.

link.heading: Availability of ICT Infrastructure and Its Use in College Libraries: A Study With Special Reference to Selected Libraries of Kolar District, Karnataka
link.authorDes: Librarian, Sri BhagawanMahaveer Jain College, Geetha Road, Robertsonpet, KGF-563122. Phone No.9945726867, E mail- savithavs_murthy@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: The present study is an attempt to assess the way in which the college libraries have responded to changing information environment and developed their infrastructure toward use of ICT. The findings show that ICT infrastructure in the libraries is still at different stages of development. Most of the libraries have minimum infrastructure for the implementation of ICT, but they face the problem of manpower too.
link.keywords: Library automation, Academic library, Information communication technology, Internet, digital library, E-resources.

link.heading: Food Security in India: A Bibliometrics Study
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi-1100072Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi-110007
link.abstract: The present study is an attempt to conduct a bibliometrics analysis based on the Web of Science Core Collection on food security research publications from 2000 to 2018 time period. The research focused on major source of articles, productive and prolific authors based on dominance factor, most relevant keywords and the countries with which India has collaborated. The data analysis has been done using R studio. The study concludes that there is quality research going on in the food security discipline and collaboration too at the global level to resolve the issues of food security.
link.keywords: Food security, Co-citation, Prolific authors, Authors.

link.heading: Library & Information Science Journals in DOAJ: A Bibliometric Study
link.authorDes: Library Infoormation Assistant, India Institute of Mass Communication, dheerajnegi3@gmail.com, Phone: 9990519121
link.abstract: This paper presents an analysis of the Directory of Open Access Journals for the period 2003-April 2019: DOAJ. It is an online directory that indexes and provides access to quality open access, peer-reviewed journals. The total number of published journals during the period of study was 140. The aim of this study was to analyse different parameters like country wise distribution, language wise distribution, etc. It was found that 32 journals were published as on 2017. The United States of America publishes 25 LIS journals included in DOAJ (17.5%).
link.keywords: DOAJ, Bibliometric Open Access, LIS, E-Resources, E-Journals, Serial crisis, Scholarly communication.

link.heading: Digital Divide and Libraries: A Systematic Literature Review
link.authors: Rai Alka1, Dr Sharma Arvind Kumar2
link.authorDes: 1Deputy Librarian, Ambedkar University, Delhi, India, Email: alka@aud.ac.in2Professor, DLIS, M.L.B. Government College of Excellence, Gwalior. M.P. Email: arvindksharma23@gmail.com
link.abstract: Today world is moving at a fast pace, however the widening economic gaps, and digital disparities are the matter of concerns. The digital divide has been identified as one of the distressing problems of the 21st century in the present economic and technological development. Information and Communication Technology (ICT) influences every significant aspect of our life, including the way we learn. The ICT may be a disabler for many, who either do not have access to these resources or do not have the awareness and skills to use new technologies in a public space. This article is based on the review of available primary and secondary literature and authors have tried to understand the issues related to digital divide, digital/information literacy, digital resources, and the role of librarians in bridging the gap of the digital divide.
link.keywords: Digital Divide, Information Literacy, Digital Literacy, Library, ICT, Electronic Resources.

link.heading: Availability and Accessibility of Information Resources on Rajasthani Arts and Culture for the Tourists in Select Libraries of Museums and Institutes in Rajasthan: A Study
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Email: sunita.pandey10@bhu.ac.in2Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Email: shail3@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The arts and culture of Rajasthan are rich and wide spread. Eye catching places of cultural interest provide a perfect opportunity to visit and shop for handcrafted items in Rajasthan. Museums and cultural institutes libraries hold disparate collections in a variety of media, presenting the large volume of information on Rajasthani arts and culture and the mission of these cultural institutes is to make their collections accessible to not only their intended users but the tourists.This study is set out to know the availability of different types of information resources in Rajasthani arts and culture in the select museums and cultural institutes libraries where tourists come to visit and further investigate the methods used by these libraries to expose significantly information resources to the tourists visiting Rajasthan.
link.keywords: Information Resources, Arts and Culture, Cultural Institutes, Tourists of Rajasthan.

link.heading: News & Events
Subject Mapping of Information Literacy Competency Levels of Social Science Researchers in National Capital Region, India
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007 Email: rajeshzone29@gmail.com2Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, Email: shail3@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The present study is an attempt to assess and map the ILC level of social science researchers in the select central universities using ACRL's Standards. In keeping with the objectives of study, the purpose of ILC mapping is to identify and establish the ILC levels of researchers within and across different subjects. This is supposed to be of great help to all the stakeholders to plan, organize and participate in various IL activities and ultimately enhance the IL competency of researchers. The findings indicate that the highest IL competent researchers were found on Standard V having competency in information use ethics. The maximum of researchers from all the subjects have shown IL incompetency on Standard II and were found lacking skills and competency to access and browse the required information.
link.keywords: ACRL Standards, Information Need, Information Access, Information Evaluation, Information Use, Information Use Ethics, Mapping of Information Literacy Competency.

link.heading: Emerging Roles of Librarians in Academic Libraries: A Great Leap Forward
link.authors: Mr Shoyel1, Dr Jalal Samir Kumar2
link.authorDes: 1Professional Trainee, IIT, Kharagpur, sohayel131@gmail.com, 85839659262Deputy Librarian, IIT, Kharagpur, jalalsk1971@gmail.com, 9933941352
link.abstract: The transition of library collection from print to electronic to digital to virtual led a tremendous scope and opportunity for librarians in delivering various library services to the users especially in an academic library. Advancement of ICT dramatically changed the concept of rendering library services in traditional libraries. Academic and special libraries do not even require large building and infrastructure to serve their users because resources are mostly available digitally and accessible over the campus network. Emergence of new technologies and tools turn the world into a global village where the main driving force is knowledge. Librarians are facing several challenges in managing huge information. This paper discusses the changing role of librarians in academic libraries and addresses the challenges faced by them in delivering library services to their users in digital environment, The study also discusses the skills set required to satisfy the information seeking behavior of the users in the context of virtual environment.
link.keywords: Librarians, Librarianship, digital age, skills, changing roles, challenges, academic library.

link.heading: Need of Digitisation of Indigenous Knowledge on Medicinal Plants: A Study on the Santals of Birbhum District, West Bengal
link.authorDes: Palli Samgathana Vibhaga Library, Visva-Bharati, Sriniketan. Email: atanu.sinha1977@gmail.com; Contact: 8250880146, 8609320481
link.keywords: Santals, Indigenous knowledge, Ethno-botany, Digitisation, Birbhum district. West Bengal.

link.heading: Implementation of Radio-Frequency Identification System in Fakiragram College: A Practical Approach.
link.authors: Hazarika Hirak Jyoti1, Dr. Kumar S Ravi2
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, North-Eastern Hill University, Shillong, Meghalaya. E-mail: hirakhazarika2014@gmail.com2Assistant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, North-Eastern Hill University, Shillong, Meghalaya. E-mail: ravikumarnehu@gmail.com
link.keywords: Library automation, North East India, Koha, Open-source ILS, RFID, ICT.

link.heading: Bibliometrics of Ph D theses accepted by Indian Agricultural Research Institute (IARI) during 2011 to 2016
link.authorDes: 1CSIR-National Institute of Science, Technology and Development Studies (CSIR-NISTADS), Dr. K.S. Krishnan Marg, Pusa Gate, New Delhi, 110012, India. Email: gargkc022@gmail.com2MLIS Student, IGNOU, New Delhi
link.abstract: An analysis of 476 Ph D theses accepted by Indian Agricultural Research Institute (IARI) in different disciplines of agricultural science and technology during 20112016 indicates that the number of theses accepted during study period is inconsistent. The highest number of theses was accepted during 2015. Of the 476 theses accepted 353 were submitted by male scholars and 123 by female scholars. Of the total 206 supervisors, 49 were female and 157 were male supervisors. On an average Male supervisors produced more students than female supervisors. Highest number of theses was accepted in the discipline of agronomy closely followed by genetics and plant breeding. Professor D.S. Rana of the Department of Agronomy guided highest number of scholars closely followed by Professor A.K. Singh of the Department of Genetics and Plant Breeding.
link.keywords: Santals, Indigenous knowledge, Ethno-botany, Digitisation, Birbhum district. West Bengal, Bibliometrics, Agricultural sciences, IARI, Doctoral dissertations, Krishikosh.

link.heading: Canons for Ontology
link.authorDes: Senior Technical Assistant, Department of Library & Information Science, Banaras Hindu University, Email: aishwaryavermabhu@gmail.com
link.abstract: The paper introduces about the concept of ontology, its components, plug-ins and various visualization tools used for building an ontology, steps for building an ontology have been discussed and the paper proposes the canons for building an ontology, the basic principle which follows throughout the ontology building process.
link.keywords: Ontology, Semantic Web, Big Data, Canons, Ontology tools.

link.heading: A Study of Information Resources and Services in the Select Libraries of Fine Arts Colleges and Art Galleries in India
link.authorDes: 1Ph. D Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, India. Email: ranirekha191@gmail.com2Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, India. Email: shail3@yahoo.com
link.abstract: This study examines information resources in both forms i.e. print and non-print and services in Fine Arts Colleges and Art Galleries. To conduct the study, a survey was made, and structured interview was also conducted with the Librarian/Head of the institution of select libraries in India. From the findings of the study, it reveals that most of libraries/institution have good collection of print as well as non print materials. For automated services in the library, it was found that only four libraries out of twelves libraries selected are using library automation software. Except IGNCA no one is using digital library software in the area of art.
link.keywords: Information Resources, Information Service, Fine Art, Galleries.

link.heading: Book Review
link.authorDes: Formerly, Professor, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, India. satija_mp@yahoo.com

link.heading: Choice Based Credit System (CBCS) in LIS Courses: Entering into New Vista of Higher Education System
link.authorDes: Associate Professor and Coordinator, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi. E-Mail: kpsingh330@gamil.com
link.abstract: The paper discusses various aspects related to the library and information science education being taught at Delhi University. It describes genesis of the Department, courses offered, availabilities of facilities, eligibility and admission criteria, availability of seats for BLIS/MLIS/M. Phil. and Ph. D, etc. The paper also discusses the various parameters of the newly implemented choice-based credit system and credit score of the BLIS and MLIS programmes.
link.keywords: Choice Based Credit System, LIS Education, University of Delhi.

link.heading: Information Services for the Visually Challenged Students in Medinipur Division of West Bengal: An Anlytical Study
link.authors: Pradhan Sudipta1, Dr Sahu Nivedita Bhattacharyya2
link.authorDes: 1Ph. D. Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, Vidyasagar University, Midnapore-721102. E-mail: spradhan.lisc@gmail.com2Assistant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, Vidyasagar University, Midnapore-721102. E-mail: nives.b22@gmail.com
link.abstract: The present study highlights the information services for the visually challenged students provided by the special schools in the Medinipur division under the Districts of Bankura, Purulia, Paschim Medinipur, Jhargram and Purba Medinipur for providing services to the visually challenged students of secondary and higher secondary level. There are eleven (11) such schools in the division spread over the districts and only Jhargram district has no such special school. The study reveals that the institutes meant for the visually challenged should increase access, availability and funding for assistive technology through efforts and initiatives. Only one institute Vivekananda Mission Asram (VMA) uses sufficient Braille resources and Assistive technology. It has been revealed from the study that due to improper information about the assistance from the Government level (both Central and State) these institutes are suffering from shortage of funds. Also shortage of teaching faculty in these institutes is another hindrance in the overall development of the visually challenged students. Only in two institutes, VMA and AAHS trained librarians are recruited to run the library. The study also focuses that only in 5 institutes out of the 11 institutes the visually challenged students are very much satisfied with at least one service of the library.
link.keywords: Visually challenged, Braille resources, assistive technology, Medinipur division, library services, information services.

link.heading: Usage of LIS ETDs for Doctoral Research in India, UK and USA: A Case Study
link.authors: Pattanaik Bibhuti Bhusan1, Dr. Yanthan Zuchamo2
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Librarian, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi-110067. E-mail: bibhutipattanaik@gmail.com2Assistant Professor, IGNOU. E-mail: yanthans@gmail.com
link.abstract: The paper attempts to verify the research scenario of Library and Information Science (LIS) via ETDs, and explores their impact on research. For this study, the authors have reviewed a selected list of LIS PhD theses that were awarded during 2001 to 2010 across the countries like India, UK and USA, and explores their usage in the form of ETDs. Further, all those ETDs have been reviewed to access the research productivity, citation impact, institutions visibility, and open access of research.
link.keywords: ETDs, LIS Research, Open Access, Citation.

link.heading: Open Access Journals and their Research Impact-A Pilot Study
link.authors: Nashipudi Mohmed Hanif1, Dr. Ravi B.2
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, RCU, Belagavi, Librarian, Government First Grade College, Ramdurg-591123, District Belgaum, Karnataka, India. E-mail: hanif.bn@gmail.com2Librarian, University of Hyderabad, Central University PO, Hyderabad-500046, Telangana, E-mail: bravicta@gmail.com
link.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to study the journal impact rankings of the open access SCImago Journal & Country Rank (SJR) database. The paper looks at the SJR database which offers essential scientometric information for more than 28, 000 scholarly and professional journals based on data licensed from Elsevier's Scopus database. In this study, an attempt is made to study the research impact of the open access Library & Information Science (LIS) journals for ten years. This study tries to emphasis the importance and quality of the open access journals in the field of LIS and the growth of their research impact indicated by the different journal quality indicators by the open access movement.
link.keywords: Open Access Publishing, Open Access Journals, Gold Open Access, Indian OA Journals, Scholarly Communication, and Research Impact.

link.heading: Intellectual Property Rights: Inevitable for Creativity Protection#
link.authorDes: Associate Professor and Coordinator, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi. E-mail: kpsingh330@gmail.com
link.abstract: In the era of information explosion, the application of ICT is extending the facility of easy access use and misuse of intellectual legacy of the creators. In order to provide protection to the creators of intellectual property several efforts have been made at national as well as global levels presents papers discusses the need to protect the intellectual property of the creators and highlights the legal protection being extended for protection of intellectual property rights especially highlighting the areas such as inventions, trademark, industrial design, indicators of source, writings, paintings, musical work, dramatical works etc.
link.keywords: Inventions, trademark, industrial design, indicators of source, writings, paintings, musical work, dramatical works etc.

link.heading: Managing Intangible Cultural Heritage Information Resources in Sahitya Academy Library, New Delhi: A Case Study
link.authors: Madan Rupali1, Dr Chadha R K2,3
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, Banasthali University, Rajasthan-304022. E-Mail: art241972@yahoo.co.in2Professor, LIS & Research, Malwanchal University3Ex-Additional Secretary, Lok Sabha Secretariat, Parliament of India, New Delhi-110001. E-Mail: ravichad@gmail.com
link.abstract: This study focuses on the Management of Intangible Cultural Heritage Information Resources available in the Sahitya Academy (SA) Library. The study demonstrates the requirements of the readers and also depicts the satisfaction level of the readers with respect to their specific requirements. The overall objective of this study is to ascertain the availability of Intangible Information Resources, the types of resources selected for digitization and the information required for the readers. This paper also discusses in detail the services provided to the readers with the assistance of applications from the arena of Information Communication and Technology (ICT).
link.keywords: Intangible Cultural Heritage (ICH), Intangible Cultural Heritage Information Resources, Sahitya Academy (SA), New Delhi.

link.heading: Assessment of Emotional Intelligence of Librarians Working in Mumbai Region
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, Knowledge Resource Centre, Rajabai Tower, University of Mumbai, anjali.sandesh@gmail.com
link.abstract: Advancement of ICT has brought about sea change in the role of libraries and librarians. These constant changes in the environment of the library can affect the emotions of the people working in the library. Emotional Intelligence is a skill which helps in managing one's emotions. The present study was carried out with the aim of assessing the Emotional Intelligence of Librarians working in Mumbai region. A convenience sample of 41 librarians working in the Mumbai region were selected. A likert scale was developed which included 36 items which tested the different dimensions of Emotional Intelligence. It was found that the emotional intelligence of the respondent librarians were high. Findings of study and recommendation to enhance the emotional intelligence of librarians are discussed.
link.keywords: Emotional Intelligence, Librarians, Self Awareness, Self Management, Social Awareness.

link.heading: A Scientometric Assessment of Indo-US Collaboration Pattern in Leishmaniasis Research during 2012–2016
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, Email: sandhpandey79@gmail.com
link.abstract: This study examines the pattern of growth and collaboration in leishmaniasis research for the year 2012–2016 as indicated by papers indexed in Science Citation Index-Expanded. The study found that Brazil is world's most prolific producer of leishmaniasis research and has the second lowest international collaboration rate among the countries. USA was the top partner for India, showing 68 co-affiliated papers with India. Salton's measures clearly indicate that India's strongest mutual collaborative partner is Belgium (0.124) and then USA (0.084). On USA's side, Salton's measure for Brazil was highest (0.157). Out of 68 paper, 59% were bilateral (involving only India and USA) and 29 multilateral (involving other countries also with India and USA. A highly significant difference observed in CPP for domestic Indian papers (listing India-affiliated researchers only) was 6.0 and for domestic USA papers 9.34. For papers listing both Indian and USA authors (international or multilateral China-Canada collaborations) the CPP was 138.44. Thus, collaboration with USA dramatically increases the average citation rate for India-based researchers. Prolific institution, journal and author were discussed for Indo-US collaborated papers.
link.keywords: Scintometrics, Salton's Measure, Leishmaniasis research, Collaboration.

link.heading: News & Events
The Effect of Telegram Social Network-Based Marketing on the Use of Central Library Services at Kharazmi University
link.authors: Salimi Zahra1, Riahinia Nosrat2, Akhshik Somaye Sadat3, Zeinali Vahide4

link.heading: Impact of Librarianship in Corporate World#
link.authorDes: Project Manager-Information Management, IT Firm Company, Gurgaon, India. Email: balajram@gmail.com
link.abstract: The objective of this study is to demonstrate the impact and importance of librarianship in Corporate World. Further, the study reveals that how is extended scope of librarianship in Corporate Environment. It deals with basic knowledge of Document Management Systems & application of Library & Information Knowledge in DMS. Further this paper highlights the significance of DR S. R Ranganathans's Five Laws of Library Science with ISO Documentation Standards. Discusses implementation of National Knowledge Commission Recommendations in Corporate Librarianship. This paper outlines and discusses the challenges and necessary technological skills needed for corporate librarianship.
link.keywords: Librarianship, Corporate Librarian, Document Management System, Document Controller, DMS, ISO Documentation.

link.heading: Relevance of Tony Wagner's Survival Skills for Library and Information Science (LIS) Professionals of 21st Century
link.authorDes: Former University Librarian, Banasthali University and NALSAR University of Law, Hyderabad. E mail: sdvyas15@yahoo.com, Mob: 8890 123 656
link.abstract: Tony Wagner's seven survival skills are useful and relevant to the needs of LIS professionals of 21st century. The paper discusses the survival skills as well as other required professional skills expected of LIS professionals. The demands of 21st century LIS professionals are different from 20th century professionals. The main reason for it is due to constant changes in the globalized era.
link.keywords: Survival skills, Competency skillscritical thinking, problem solving, team based leadership, information technology skills, Communication skill.

link.heading: Search Strategies Adopted By Users of Agricultural Libraries of Northern India For Searching Electronic Information Resources
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, Sher-e-Kashmir University of Agricultural Science and Technology of Kashmir. E-Mail: nazir69@skuastkashmir.ac.in, Mob: 7889519155
link.abstract: The study has been conducted with a purpose to explore which are the most popular search platforms, and search approaches adopted by users of electronic information resources (EIRs). The investigator made a personal survey of seven sampled universities for collecting data about the questions under investigation and questionnaire was used as a data collection tool. The investigator also had a face to face interaction with respondents to substantiate the responses and remove ambiguities thereof. Statistical Package for Social Science (SPSS) was used to make analysis of the data on empirical basis. Chi Squared (χ2) Test was used to derive association between the variables and test the level of significance thereof. It is explored that the ‘search engines’ and ‘university webpage’ are the most popular search platforms among users of the agricultural libraries of northern India. The newly emerged platforms i.e. ‘remote access software’ and ‘federated search engines’ have not yet become popular among users of surveyed libraries. ‘Google’ proves to be the number one search engine and ‘Yahoo’ is seen to be used by 20.00% of users. The ’Title’, and ‘Keyword/Subject Term’ happen to be much popular than other search approaches and a good percentage of respondents approach information through ‘Author’.
link.keywords: Electronic information resources (EIRs), search platforms, search engines, search approaches, search strategies.

link.heading: Assessment of Information Literacy Competency of Social Science Researchers
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, DLIS, University of Delhi, Delhi-1100072Associate Professor, DLIS, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007
link.abstract: The present paper is a research report of a study conducted to assess the awareness, use and satisfaction level of researchers with library services. The study has also attempted to assess the information literacy competency level of social science research scholars of select four central universities in Delhi. The study has used 50 questions based on five standards of ACRL.
link.keywords: Library Resource Awareness, Information Literacy, ACRL Standards, Competency Assessment, Research Scholar.

link.heading: An Online System for Effective Bibliometric Services
link.authors: Viswanath G S1, Sharma Preeti2, Panwar Yatish3
link.authorDes: 1Tech. Assist., National Science Library, CSIR-NISCAIR. Email: viswanath@niscair.res.in, viswam.gs@gmail.com, Ph. 94477135782Project Assist. National Science Library, CSIR-NISCAIR. Email: preetisharmacs1989@gmail.com3Sr. Tech. Officer., National Science Library, CSIR-NISCAIR. Email: yatish@niscair.res.in
link.abstract: Bibliometrics is an interdisciplinary area which communicates with all other areas of research. An organization of national importance doing research has to rely on the expert reviews and analysis of research performance. Experts use different methods and tools to analyze the performance & quality of a research/researcher. The National Science Library, CSIR-NISCAIR has been providing citation analysis and other bibliometric services. To provide the service, the National Science Library has created an online application to analyze the citations and generate various reports. The paper explains the modules of this online application and how it is used by the Institute in a productive way. The paper also describes some of the back-end operations of the application.
link.keywords: Bibliometric, Citation analysis, Research productivity, self-citation, H-index, In-house application, NISCAIR.

link.heading: User Study of Awareness About Plagiarism of Dr. B. R. Ambedkar Central Library of Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Professor, Department of Library And Information Science, University of Delhi. E-mail: kkmaniii2014@gmail.com2Assistant Librarian, Dr. B.R. Ambedkar Central Library, Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi. E-mail: mahesh2233@gmail.com
link.abstract: The research paper tangibly explains the present status of awareness of plagiarism concept, its relevant aspects and other inevitable issues. It comprehensively explains the users’ know how and understanding about the concept, usage of anti plagiarism software and current information scenario. The work presents 100 users’ responses in terms of plagiarism and relevant aspects.
link.keywords: Plagiarism, Citation, Standard Citation Styles, Anti Plagiarism Software.

link.heading: Multifaceted Creativity of Satyajit Ray: A Bibliometric Study
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian, Visva-Bharati, Santi Niketan-731235, W.B. E-mail: raypartha1@hotmail.com
link.abstract: The article is a bibliometric study of the works of Satyajit Ray. It measures quantitavely Satyajit Ray's contribution to literature and filmography. It has found out the year-wise growth of publication and filmography. It identifies core communication channels for publication of articles. Lastly, it finds out the collaborators and their association with Ray's filmography.
link.keywords: Bibliometric study; Satyajit Ray.

link.heading: Information Seeking Behaviour of Physical Scientists of Assam University and Mizoram University: A Comparative Study
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, Mizoram University, Aizawl-796004, Email: manojdlis@mzu.edu.in2Assistant Librarian, Government Aizawl West Collage, Aizawl, Mizoram-796001, E-mail: rosa_mami@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: The present study is an attempt to compare the information seeking behaviour of physical scientists (i.e. teachers and research scholars) of Assam and Mizoram Universities. The scientists in university always need information to perform their duty and responsibility i.e. teaching and research. Information need is an aspect of information behaviour that represents the root of information search. A structured questionnaire was framed and distributed to physical scientists of these two universities to analyze their information seeking behaviour. The analysis revealed the frequency & purpose of visiting the library, use of library services, usage of formal and informal sources, purpose of seeking information, the category of information used and use of UGC-Infonet consortium by physical scientists.
link.keywords: Information needs, Information Seeking Behaviour, Information Seeking Habit, Searches, Use Study, Physical Scientists, Mizoram University, Assam University etc.

link.heading: A Study on Awareness, Usage and Satisfaction on Library Services: A Case of Private Unaided Education Institutions
link.authors: Dr. Gulati Dipti1, Dr Latwal Gopal Singh2
link.authorDes: 1Librarian, IITM, GGSIP University, New Delhi, India. Email: diptigulati83@gmail.com2Associate Professor, IITM, GGSIP University, New Delhi, India. Email: gopalsinghusl@gmail.com
link.abstract: The global changes, particularly, the Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) have profoundly impacted on the functioning of academic libraries across the world. The developments in ICT have transformed the users’ expectation from the libraries in various aspects. The methodologies adopted to build up collections and providing of services to the end users vary from the current previous practices. To meet the ever increasing demands of the end-users effectively, the libraries need to identify and adopt sound and worthwhile practices and benchmarks. This paper is a case study to assess the awareness, usage and satisfaction level of library services in the privately owned education institutions that receive no aid from any source.
link.keywords: Library, Library Services, User Satisfaction, User Awareness, Information Resources.

link.heading: Deep collaboration in libraries and the fifth law of library science
link.authorDes: Chief Librarian, India International Centre, New Delhi-110003
link.abstract: This articles is culmination of three different aspects which led to emerging concept of Deep Collaboration. It begins by giving importance to the Ranganathan's philosophy of Librarianship through his Five Laws of Library Science and compares one of the Laws, “Library is a Growing Organism” with Darwin's Theory of Evolution. It defines the emerging concept of Deep Collaboration; its principles; characteristics of deep collaboration; its values and the possibilities of user-centric collaboration including applying the same in Indian condition.
link.keywords: Five Laws of Library Science, Darwin's Theory of Evolution, Deep Collaboration, Characteristics of Deep Collaboration, Values of Deep Collaboration.

link.heading: A bibliometric study of Ph D theses accepted by Bangalore University in disciplines of zoology, botany and physics during 1969–2015
link.authorDes: 1Former Chief Scientist, CSIR-National Institute of Science, Technology and Development Studies (CSIR-NISTADS), Dr. K.S. Krishnan Marg, New Delhi-110012, India, gargkc022@gmail.com2Assistant Librarian, Venkateshwar Global School, Sector 13, Rohini, Delhi, 110085, mamtaduggal88@yahoo.com
link.abstract: An analysis of 511 theses accepted by Bangalore University, Bangalore in the disciplines of zoology, botany and physics during 1969–2015 indicates that the number of theses accepted during the period of study follow an inconsistent trend. Highest number of theses was accepted during the five year block of 1991–1995 in zoology and botany, while the highest number of theses in physics was accepted in the five year block of 1996–2000. Of the 511 accepted theses, 203 theses were by female scholars and the rest 308 by male scholars. The number of theses accepted by women scholars in botany was almost equal to the number of theses by their male counters. Highest number of theses supervised in zoology was by a female supervisor. No women supervisor could find place in the list of prolific supervisors in physics. In the discipline of zoology and botany, four women supervisors were listed in the list of prolific supervisors.
link.keywords: Bibliometrics, Doctoral dissertation, Bangalore University, India Shodhganga.

link.heading: Leishmaniasis: Scientometric assessment of global research output
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India. E-mail: sandhpandey79@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper investigates global leishmaniasis research output for the period 1997–2016 indexed by Science Citation Index-Expanded. Analysis indicates exponential growth in second ten year block. Study includes 14779 (article, article proceedings, letter, and review), out of 16198 records retrieved on various aspects of Leishmaniasis. The highest publications came from Brazil followed by USA and India. The publication activity increased for France, UK and USA and decreased for Iran, Belgium and Brazil. The average value of CPP is 23. RCI and CPP is more than world average for USA, UK, France, Germany, Switzerland, Canada and Netherlands. Fundacao Oswaldo Cruz, Brazil was the most prolific institution, Paracitology was found to be the most focussed sub-discipline and American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene, USA was the most prefered journal and Sundar Shyam, of BHU was the most prolific author. Brazil with USA shows strongest mutual strength and highest publications in collaboration with each other.
link.keywords: Leishmaniasis, Scientometrics, Salton's measure, RCI, CPP.

link.heading: A scientometric study of NSIT publications in science and technology during 2006 to 2015
link.authors: Choudhary Prabhat Kumar1, Dr. Singh K. P.2
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Librarian (Stage IV) Central Library, NSIT, Sector-3, Dwarka, New Delhi, 1100782Associate Professor Department of Library and Information, University of Delhi, Delhi, 100078
link.abstract: This paper analyses the research output in science & technology (S&T) in nine departments of Netaji Subhas Institute of Technology (NSIT), New Delhi during the year 2006 to 2015 using Scopus database. The authors of nine departments produced 1184 publications as articles, conference papers and reviews. The present study examines on formats of research outputs, growth pattern of output, author productivity, productivity per capita, transformative activity index, common journals used for publishing research results and identifies prolific authors. The average publication growth of NSIT is 10.9%. The maximum number of publications during study period is in the year 2015. Productivity per capita of the Institute is about 12.3 publications, the average productivity per author is 0.34 publications. Research output by single author has decreased in second block of 2011 to 2015. The transformative activity index of Biological Science and Engineering (BT) department and that of Instrumentation and Control Engineering (ICE) department have improved in second block of 2011–2015. Journals published from the United States of America were most preferred for publishing research result by NSIT authors.
link.keywords: Scientometrics, NSIT, Science and Technology, Co-authorship index, Productivity per capita.

link.heading: Evaluation of library websites of private universities in Delhi NCR-A preliminary study
link.authors: Kalra Jaya1, Dhingra Shweta2, Verma R K3
link.authorDes: 1Ex-Library Manager, IM, Cairn India Ltd., Gurgaon. Email: jayakalra29@gmail.com2Professional Assistant, Dr. B. R. Ambedker Central Library, Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi. Email: shweta1610@gmail.com3Ex-Chief Scientist, CSIR-NISCAIR, New Delhi. Email: sheri51verma@gmail.com
link.abstract: This study is an attempt to analyse the websites of 17 Private universities in Delhi NCR at macro level using a 12 checkpoint indicator. The paper goes on to analyse the usability checkpoints, to identify the similarities, differences, and gaps in displaying various information content on the web pages; and to highlight the role of librarians in information organization on the websites of university libraries. The check points wise analysis shows that most frequently sought after features viz. FAQ, Formatting, Announcements, Staff details with contact numbers whereas updation details have almost been neglected. One may argue that some of the information is available only for bonafide members over intranet but even then provision of at least some indicative information can promote the visibility of the websites. There are researchers outside the university looking for some basic data about the library resources, and services. For them the availability and access to required information on library website is the most convenient and reliable source. Only three universities have achieved average score for the presence of different checkpoints. From these observations the paper moves on to analyse and suggest ways to increase the visibility of the institutions and the role libraries play in aiding the increase of visibility. The role of librarian is of utmost importance as they only can take initiative by convincing the administration about a full fledged exclusive dynamic website where its services and resources are to be brought to the notice of all types of users besides their effective and efficient use. It should not be forgotten that this is the first and only source of information for most of the users before they physically visit the libraries. With a view to increasing visibility of the institution, librarians have to play the crucial role of creation and developing library websites in consultation and cooperation with all stake holders like administrators, IT professionals, and the users. To go a step further, librarians should adopt various strategies like designing an online feedback mechanism on a regular basis so that maximum utilization of electronic information services is achieved in an efficient and effective manner.
link.keywords: Library Website, University Library Website, Private University, Usability.

link.heading: Information seeking behaviour of nehru memorial museum & library (NMML), New Delhi readers: A case study
link.authorDes: Library and Information Officer, Nehru Memorial Museum and Library, (Ministry of Culture, Govt. of India), Teen Murti House, New-110011. E-mail: lioajitnmml@gmail.com; lio.nmml@gov.in
link.abstract: This study focuses on information seeking behaviour of the users of the NMML Library and also the uses of information resources available in Microfilm, Microfiche and Photographs by the research scholars at the NMML. The study shows the needs and expectations of the users and also describes how library full-fills the needs of the scholars. The overall purpose of the study is to determine the information needs and the awareness of users towards library resources available to them. This paper also discusses the changing scenario of library resources from traditional to electronic format.
link.keywords: Information Seeking Behaviour, Nehru Memorial Museum & Library, Library resources, Photographs, Microfilms, Microfiche.

link.heading: Human resource development in libraries: A literature review
link.authors: Tiwari Nivedita1, Dr Singh K P2
link.authorDes: 1Ph D Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, India2Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, India
link.abstract: Successful accomplishments of human resource functions have a crucial impact on the growth and development of individuals as professionals and library users. The present article is an attempt to explore the views/works on the constituent components of human resource development in various organisations in India and abroad. Comprehensive review of related literature is done and is divided into seven components identified to study Human resource development policies existing in various organisations like Human Resource Planning, Recruitment and Selection, Placement and Induction and Promotion and Motivation. Review starts with select writings on HRD/HRM component in general. The extensive search of literature indicates that HRD is just not the employer-employee relationship, but it is much more than that. It is actually directly related to the job of the individual and finally what we learn from the literature is that the development of any organization is possible if we show more concern to human resources while at the same time constant changes at the organizational level makes it difficult for employees to cope.
link.keywords: Human Resource Development (HRD)-HRD in Libraries-Human Resource Planning-Recruitment and Selection-Promotion and Motivation-Placement and Induction in Libraries.

link.heading: Weeding the printed collections in libraries: Policy and practice at IIT Delhi
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Librarian, Central Library, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi-110016, India. E-mail: vanita@library.iitd.ac.in2Librarian, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi-110016. E-mail: nabihasan@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper is a case study of policy and practice followed at Indian Institute of Technology Delhi for weeding the old/damaged/obsolete/unused library collections. The paper endeavors to highlight the barriers and the need of weeding in the library. It discusses the criteria used to weed the collections in the central library of IIT Delhi as devised by the Advisory Committee for Library (ACL). The study is limited to the weeding of books from Humanities and Social Sciences, Text Book and Book Bank sections of the Central Library, IIT Delhi. The weeding procedure at IIT Delhi not only makes the collections lively but also helps in marketing of the Central Library and its resources. This study will be very fruitful for those library professionals who wish to undertake weeding of their collections to make them lively and updated.
link.keywords: Weeding, Library Collection, Advisory Committee for Library (ACL), Collection Management, Collection Development, IIT Delhi.

link.heading: Acquisition and access of E-Books in academic libraries: Some concerns
link.authorDes: 1Deputy Librarian, Central Reference Library, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India2Shri Ram College of Commerce Library, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007, India
link.abstract: The present paper is an attempt to highlight the issues and challenges faced practically in academic library settings in acquisition and access of e-books. Defines the concept of e-book and outlines the comparative advantages and limitations of both print books and e-books. Deliberates the major concerns why, despite the inherent qualities of providing cost effective content that can be easily discovered, delivered anywhere, at any time to a variety of user friendly devices for consumption and reuse, e-books is still struggling to establish itself at par with e-journals in libraries.
link.keywords: E-books, Print-books, Electronic Resource, India, Electronic reading, E-book system.
