A Review On Open Data Repositories For Email Spam And Pre-Processing Methods
link.authorDes: 1Information Scientist, Cochin University of Science and Technology, Email: liny@cusat.ac.in2Professor(Rtd) Department of Computer Science, Cochin university of Science and Technology, Email: kpj@cusat.ac.in
link.abstract: Email spam data is a set of tagged messages that have been collected for email Spam research. It contains spam messages and legitimate messages received in different inboxes. This paper reviews different datasets available as open data in various learning repositories. This review also covers different preprocessing techniques applied to the datasets before doing actual filtering/classification.
link.keywords: Spam filtering, open data repositories, dimensionality reduction.

link.heading: Data Lake in The Big Data Era: An Overview
link.authorDes: 1Technical Officer, Centre for Water Resources Development and Management, Kozhikode-673 571. Email: sreesudeepk@gmail.com2Junior Librarian, School of Legal Studies, Cochin University of Science and Technology, Kochi-682 022. Email: ratheeshk1980@gmail.com
link.abstract: This Article gives an overview about the new concept Data Lake which is a unified data management system. A data lake has the facility to store, analyse and process personal data. The paper also gives a brief comparison of data warehouses and data lakes.
link.keywords: Data Lake, Big Data, Hadoop.

link.heading: Free and Open Source Software Tools For Implementation of Information Visualization in Libraries and Information Centers
link.authorDes: 1School of Library and Information Science, Central University of Gujarat, Gandhinagar, Gujarat2Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar, Gujarat3Assistant Professor, DLIS, Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University, Lucknow
link.abstract: Libraries generate and collect an enormous amount of data regarding usage statistics, circulation, visitor counts, budget, resource sharing data, Inter-Library Loan transactions, Document delivery statistics, etc. This collected data is interpreted for making policy decisions over library development and for the improvement of existing library services. Traditionally, libraries have been presenting the data using archaic tools such as simple graphics, tables, and charts. The recent phenomenon of Information Visualisation has provided tools and techniques for displaying information in innovative and creative ways to present abstract data. Considering the potential of Information visualisation, the tools and techniques provided by the field of Information visualisation should be exploited by the library and information centres for the presentation of library data. This paper presents an overview of various free and open source software tools available for better implementation of information visualisation in libraries for better decision making.
link.keywords: Information Visualization, Open Source Software, Libraries, Visualization Tools.

link.heading: YUJ: An Innovative Model for Sharing and Re-using the Elite Research data in the Big Data Environment
link.authors: Dr Beena C1, Dr. Archana SN2, Dr Sudhakaran Jinu3
link.authorDes: 1University Librarian (in-charge), University Library, Cochin University of Science and Technology; E-mail: beenacherukuth@gmail.com2Assistant Librarian, University Library, Cochin University of Science and Technology; E-mail: niharikamanakkil@gmail.com3Junior Librarian, University Library, Cochin University of Science and Technology; E-mail: jinusudhakaranvayalil@gmail.com
link.abstract: The advent of Information and Communication technology (ICT) has resulted in a remarkable change in the sharing and re-use of data among academic and scientific community. The wide spectrum of collaboration and interaction among the scientists and academia within the campus has extended further so that the research and research outcomes are shared globally. Conventionally it was done through research publications, and later through digital libraries and online repositories. These platforms fulfil the idea of sharing and reuse of data, but an exclusive platform for collaborative and collective representation of academic informatics is the need of the hour. This paper explains the features of an innovative and cost effective model for sharing and re-use of academic informatics developed by Cochin University of Science & Technology (CUSAT).
link.keywords: Research Data, Big Data, YUJ, Innovative model, Data sharing.

link.heading: A Comparative study of Open source data repository software: Dataverse and CKAN
link.authors: Mahato Shiva Shankar1, Gajbe Sagar Bhimrao2
link.authorDes: 1JRF-DRTC, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore. Email: shiva@drtc.isibang.ac.in2JRF-DRTC, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore. Email: sagar@drtc.isibang.ac.in
link.abstract: Research data management has been an important activity in perpetuity. Thus it is natural that greater attention is being paid in the academics and research institutions for the same and of late several platforms have emerged to support data deposits. Data repositories are the archives which hold research data and make them publicly available so that other researchers can reuse them for their re-purposing. Also depositing data in a repository ensures the long term preservation and availability. It may be important to know which type of repository and what kind of service best supports data repository. This study tries to evaluate the two data repository softwares-Dataverse and CKAN. The paper while delineating the general background about data repository and digital repository, it focuses on the importance of data repositories. The two softwares are discussed in general along with their features, followed by their evaluation based on some important identified criteria. The study concludes with the findings, along with preferential situation based on the software suitability
link.keywords: Data Repositories, Data Repository software, CKAN, Dataverse, Open Source.

link.heading: Application of Semantic Web Technologies for creating Linked Open Data in Information Retrieval
link.authors: Warrier Nirupama R.1, Dr Shivarama J2
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Centre for Library and Information Management Studies (CLIMS), Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Deonar, Mumbai-400 0882Assistant Professor, Centre for Library and Information Management Studies (CLIMS), Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Deonar, Mumbai-400 088
link.abstract: The field of Library and information sciences has gone through different stages of technological upgrades. The unprecedented growth and changes in the Information and Communication Technology (ICT) has influenced and changed the methods in which information can be retrieved and consumed. The changes have brought forth new challenges as well as new opportunities in the way these services are rendered and availed. This article explores the changes in the field of Library and Information sciences, from the time it started becoming digital and online. The article also discusses how the advanced information technologies including those made in the area of Semantic Web will help improve the Information Retrieval and how Big Data is important for Open Data initiatives.
link.keywords: Semantic Web, Web-based Services, Ontology, Linked Open Data, Big Data.

link.heading: Tools, Techniques and Resources for Development of Research Data Management in Libraries
link.authorDes: School of Library and Information Science, Central University of Gujarat, Gandhinagar, Gujarat1Adani Institute of Infrastructure Management, Ahmedabad, Gujarat
link.abstract: Research data management is an essential part of the modern scholarly debate in research life-cycle. Gathering, preserving and sharing research data through using proper research data management tools and techniques is the fulcrum of the responsible research. Sharing research data enhances the visibility of work, allows mutual data exchange. and makes research data recognizable as valuable resource for the other researcher. There are many research data tools, techniques and learning resources available for effective research data management. Therefore it's necessary for critical study that the best tools, techniques and learning resources are available for the use of RDM in libraries. This paper presents the overview of the list of tools, techniques and learning resources available for better managing the research data. The article will be helpful for critically analysing the various tools and techniques which are available and that can be used for better research data management.
link.keywords: Research Data Management, Tools and Techniques, RDM Resources, Data Curation, Libraries, Data Literacy.

link.heading: Open Government Data: User Requirements Substantiation and Compliance in the interfaces of Indian Initiatives
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian, Cochin University of Science and Technology, Kochi-22, Kerala. E mail: veerankutty@cusat.ac.in
link.abstract: The rise of social web and explosive growth of mobile internet created new requirements of services and information at the door step of citizens. There is increasing pressure on government to ‘open’ administrative data to public. At the same time, the presentation of data in a convenient way is as important as the decision to make data publically available. The author evaluates two Indian initiatives in Open Government Data based on user requirements verification.
link.keywords: Open Government Data, User Requirements Verification, India.

link.heading: Data Repository and Digital Curation for Futuristic Libraries: A Boon for Pragmatic Digital World
link.authors: Shivarama J1, Kumar Ashok2, Choukimath Puttaraj A3, Deepak A B4
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Professor, Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai-400088. E-mail: shivaramatoo32@gmail.com2Library & Information Officer, School of Planning and Architecture, New Delhi-110002. E-mail: informashok1984@gmail.com3Assistant Librarian (SG), Tata Institute of Social Science, Mumbai-400088. E-mail: choukimath@tiss.edu4Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai-400088
link.abstract: The rate of creation of information whether in digital or non-digital format has created a challenge of management and reuse of this information. The digital documents are gaining importance at world level. Thus the term digital curation receiving wider popularity among the community of information managers. This paper aims to explore the emerging interdisciplinary field of digital curation. The paper also focused on recent trends and development in the subject digital curation. It analyses and defines the term digital curation, role of libraries, archive, museums and other organisation involved in heritage management. The article explores some of the major projects, softwares, policies, standards that are being followed worldwide and the organisations engaged in the research in this domain. It concludes that effort needs to be made for the development of globally accepted standards, policies, and infrastructure for the conversion of digital content so that the digital curation skills of researchers and information professionals could be developed. Without achieving this target the existing efforts will merely fulfil the short term digitisation goals only.
link.keywords: Digital Curation, Data repository, Digital Preservation, FOSS, FreeBXML, Open Archive Initiative (OAI).

link.heading: Academics Perception Towards Data Repository: A Case Study Of Selected Departments Of Cochin University Of Science And Technology
link.authors: Dr Ray S Shibu1, Nair Sri Anish V2
link.authorDes: 1Assistant Librarian Sr. Scale, Cochin University of Science and Technology, Kochi-22 Email: shiburay@gmail.com2Assistant librarian, CUCEK, CUSAT, Pulimcunnoo-688504. Email: anish4vn@gmail.com
link.abstract: The potentials of research data, its curation and reuse are immense. Academic, research and development institutions and funding agencies recognizing its possibilities have intensified its efforts in the development of data repositories. Research data is abounded everywhere. Huge amounts of funds have been invested for research, and to have a holistic utilization of the amount spend, proper guidelines on how the research data should be stored for future use and a repository is necessitated. This paper discusses academics perception towards data repositories and the role of libraries in providing research data based services. Questionnaire method was adopted for the study. Study found that all the respondents are in favour of preserving data, and majority of them suggested that libraries can lead the development of data repositories.
link.keywords: Data repositories, Research data services, Data management plan.

link.heading: Data Citation: Challenges and Applications
link.authorDes: Junior Research Fellow, DRTC, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore. Email: subhranshubhusan@gmail.com
link.abstract: Idea of the paper is to give a thorough understanding of data citation and its challenges. An attempt has been made to focus on various elements of data citation and principles involved in creation of data citations. We have also intended to work out two scenarios, in which we have tried to portray the existing scenario in data citation domain
link.keywords: Data, Citation, Data Citation, DOI, Micro-citation.

link.heading: Open Educational Resources in India: A Study of NPTEL and its Usage
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian (Senior Scale), Department of Ship Technology, Cochin University of Science and Technology, Kochi, Kerala-682022. Email: nkscusat@gmail.com
link.abstract: The paper aims to provide an overview of development of Online Information Resources (OER) in India with special reference to National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning (NPTEL). The study also investigates undergraduate students’ usage and attitudes towards NPTEL video lectures in the field of Ocean engineering. A total of 114 students from the Department of Ship Technology, Cochin University of Science and Technology, Cochin participated in the survey and the results indicated that students used NPTEL at least once in a week mainly for supplementing their class room learning. The analysis revealed that the contents were very relevant to their course and they were satisfied with NPTEL videos and contents.
link.keywords: Open Educational Resources (OER), Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), NPTEL, OERs in Ocean engineering and India.

link.heading: Open Sources Software Tools for Managing 21st Century Libraries
link.authors: Chaudhari Panna1, Asjola Viral2, Shashikumara A.A.3, Manu T.R4, Muduli Prasanna Kumar5
link.authorDes: 1Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar, Gandhinagar, Gujarat2Indian Institute of Technology Gandhinagar, Gandhinagar, Gujarat3Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar, Gujarat4School of Library and Information Science, Central University of Gujarat, Gandhinagar, Gujarat5Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology, Gandhinagar, Gujarat
link.abstract: Open Source Software offers straightforward solutions to many libraries, which haveso for tied up with the commercial softwares. Software under the commercial platforms comes with a financial burden, security issue and locked source codes. Instead of customising the application to make it user-friendly, libraries alter their services/deliveries according to the software's limitations. To overcome these inherent issues of the commercial software, many libraries, technology developer, vendors emerged with Open Source Software Solutions for library services and activities. Open Source Software is available at free of cost, and most of them are allowing the users to customise and edit source codes as per their requirements. This term paper is intended to introduce available open-source software and their implementations in libraries. Information and communications technology have played a significant role in the development of the libraries. Since a decade, libraries have been entirely depending on computer applications to provide new services to their users. Various computer programs/applications are available in the market for libraries which substantially providing the solution of library services like library automation, design and management of library websites, creating digital libraries, learning management solutions, digital archives etc.
link.keywords: Open Source Software, Library Management, Digital Libraries, Learning Management.

link.heading: Growth of ETDs in India: An analytical study of top contributing Universities of Shodhganga
link.authors: Nanthini Ro1, Dr. Varghese Rekha Rani2
link.authorDes: 1Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, Pondicherry University. Email: violetsfun@gmail.com2Assitant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, Pondicherry University. Email: rekhatvm@gmail.com
link.abstract: Shodhganga has become one of the most preferred and trusted sources for research works of institutions across India because of its vast availability of ETDs contributed by 130 universities across the country. The present study is based on quantitative measurement of the contributing universities of Shodhganga to identify the major contributing institutions to the repository, language of ETDs contributed, departments that contribute more number of research works and the amount of research work undertaken by the Indian universities in the last decade. Results show that of all the contributing universities, University of Calcutta is the top contributor with 11025 ETDs out of which the university's Department of Science has contributed 2205 ETDs. Shodhganga also contains other language ETDs and majority of VBSPU's contributions are in languages other than English. However the one area in which the repository has to improve is to make availability of year-wise records for all the ETDs.
link.keywords: Institutional Repository, Shodhganga, INFLIBNET, ETDs.

link.heading: Scope of using Biological Metadata for Digitized Natural History Specimens in India
link.authorDes: DRTC, Indian Statistical Institute, Bangalore. Emial: dipanjan@drtc.isibang.ac.in. Mob: 8777268156
link.abstract: The natural history collections across museums can be depicted as the record of the history of life.Fossilized bones of prehistoric animals such as dinosaurs and ancient mammals, fossils of plants, arthropods, snails, starfish etc, pinned specimen of insects, glass jar specimen of animals and herbarium of plants are the prized collections of any natural history museum.In the modern scenario of 21st century due to the specimen digitization projects of several leading natural history museums around the world, these data are digitized and have since changed the entire complexion of specimen data accession. Now a person can access any type of data regarding the biological specimens from anywhere at anytime and also multiple specimens can be accessed across museums at a time.The natural history of India is rich. Fossil evidence suggests that different types of species from early invertebrates to dinosaurs once roamed the seas, air and land of this country. But the effort of digitizing these specimens are very less. So, it is extremely difficult for scientists, researchers, teachers, students and commoners to access these data from anywhere at anytimeThis paper focuses on what are the specimens that can be digitized in different natural history collections across India. Besides, attempt has been made to figure out what biological metadata schemas can be used for accessing and exchanging the digitized data
link.keywords: Specimens, Metadata, Museum, India, Collection, History.

link.heading: Biopic Review
Book Review
link.authorDes: Librarian, Ramjas College, Delhi, 110007

link.heading: News & Events
Open Access Initiatives: Reframing the role of Librarians
link.authors: M Sanjeeva eghana Manohar*, Dr Powdwal Sushama C**
link.authorDes: *Librarian, VES College of Arts Science and Commerce. E-mail: meghana.sanjeeva@ves.ac.in**Retired University Librarian, SNDT Womens University, Mumbai. E-mail: spowdwal@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper discusses the steps taken by librarians to implement OA in their respective institute libraries in Mumbai. It also identifies the advocacy role that librarians have taken up. It traces the development of OA and touching upon the international and Indian efforts of applying OA in scholarly communication. Charts the further path that librarians can take to support researchers in their scholarly endeavours.
link.keywords: Open Access, Scholarly communication, current models of Scholarly communication, Open Access publishing, Role of Librarians in Open Access.

link.heading: Indian Journal of Traditional Knowledge: A bibliometric study
link.authors: Dr Garg K C*, Singh Rahul Kumar**
link.authorDes: *Ex-Chief Scientist, CSIR-National Institute of Science, Technology and Development, Studies (CSIR-NISTADS), Dr K.S. Krishnan Marg, New Delhi-110012, India. E-mail: gargkc022@gmail.com**Junior Library and Information Assistant (JLIA), Nehru Memorial Museum & Library, Ministry of Culture, Government of India, Teen Murti House, New Delhi-110011, India. E-mail: rahulrakia@gmail.com
link.abstract: The present study provides a detailed bibliometric analysis of 1286 papers published in Indian Journal of Traditional Knowledge (IJTK) during 2002–2015. The analysis of data indicates that the flow of articles submitted to the journal has declined during the later period. The papers published in the journal were contributed by authors from 24 countries, most being from India. The Indian State of Uttar Pradesh contributed the highest number of papers. Among the institutions, the Central Agricultural University, (Pasighat, Arunachal Pradesh) contributed the highest number of papers. The number of papers published in the page ranges of 1–5 and 6–10 were almost equal. Based on the key words published in the journal Ethno-medicine and traditional medicine was the highest used key words. Gap between the receipt and publication of the paper was 17 months, lowest being in the year 2004. The paper also identified the most prolific authors as well as highly cited papers.
link.keywords: Bibliometrics, Indian Journal of Traditional Knowledge, Ayurveda, Siddha, Yoga, Unani, Naturopathy, Homoeopathy.

link.heading: Bibliometrics of Cited References Appended to Ph D and M. Phil. Dissertations Submitted to Aligarh Muslim University in the Discipline of Physics During 2010–2013
link.authorDes: Junior Research Fellow, Department of Library and Information Science, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh. Email: vaidyapriya26@gmail.com
link.abstract: An analysis of 1626 references in 22 theses submitted to the department of physics of the Aligarh Muslim University during 2010–2013 indicates that like other disciplines of science, the journal articles were the documents cited most. Most of the cited journals were published from the advanced countries of the West and 60 cited references were to Indian journals. The journals originating from the US topped the list of cited articles. Scholars cited the current literature and Bradford's law of scattering hold good for the list of cited references with only two journals constituting the core. Most of the cited authors were from abroad, however, top three cited authors were from India.
link.keywords: Bibliometrics, Doctoral Dissertations, Aligarh Muslim University, Citation Analysis, Physics.

link.heading: Content Analysis of Library Websites/pages of Central Universities of North India: A study
link.authorDes: Faculty of Library & Information Science, IGNOU, Maidan Garhi, New Delhi-110088
link.abstract: In the present scenario websites are more accessible to users than the libraries themselves. The present paper studies the contents available on the library websites of central universities of north India. The data was collected from the websites of the central universities by a checklist prepared for this purpose. The websites of the libraries were thoroughly scanned and analysis was done. Based on the analysis top five websites are identified. The main purpose of this paper is to guide the librarians in improving their library websites. The basic aim of this paper is to give suggestions for improving the contents of the library websites.
link.keywords: Content analysis, Library websites, Library sources and services, Central Universities.

link.heading: LIS Professionals Recruitment, Selection, Placement and Induction Practices in Select Libraries of Delhi
link.authorDes: *Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110 007. Email: meeradlis@gmail.com, Mob: 9818002377**Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110 007. Email: j.garvita7@gmail.com, Mob: 8882023568
link.abstract: This paper aims to provide the view of LIS professionals in select libraries of Delhi regarding the practices related to recruitment, selection, placement and their induction. Likert scale based questionnaire was used to obtain responses from the professionals working in eight libraries of Delhi which were categorized into four as special, technical, academic and public. Total 58 questionnaires were distributed, out of which 43 were returned back with response rate of 71%. Questionnaire was divided into two sections namely ‘Recruitment and Selection’ having 12 questions and ‘Placement and Induction’ consisting of 6 questions. First category, ‘Recruitment and Selection’ scored 75.8% with WAM 3.8 while second section ‘Placement and Induction’ got 72.7% and WAM of 3.6 which shows that the staff in the libraries under study have a positive perception regarding the practices being followed under both categories of human resource management.
link.keywords: Human Resource Management, Recruitment, Selection, Placement, Induction, Human Resources.

link.heading: User Study of Marketing of Library and Information Science Products and Services by Indian Institute of Technology Delhi Library
link.authors: M Kumar anish*, Dr. Singh K. P.**
link.authorDes: *Assistant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110 007**Associate Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110 007
link.abstract: This research paper tangibly explains the present status of application of marketing strategies, marketing tools and techniques being used by IIT Delhi library to make its users more aware and inform about the LIS products and services. It covers the steps taken by library authority in terms of library marketing planning strategies, marketing tools and techniques being used with futuristic approach. The study presents 108 users responses in terms of marketing of LIS products and services.
link.keywords: Marketing, Library, Library Products and Services, Marketing Tools, Indian Institute of Technology-Delhi, Marketing Strategies, LIS Products and Services.

link.heading: Scientometric Portrait of Professor MP Satija
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, Central University of Jammu. Email: cujammu.prerna@gmail.com, prerna@cujammu.ac.in
link.abstract: Prof. M.P Satija is an internationally renowned teacher and author in the field of library and information science field. This research aims to establish an understanding of Prof. M.P Satija's publications and collaboration profiles through the study of his published works. Scientometric analysis techniques were applied on his published works over a period of 37 years (1978–2015). His 487 published works, as of 2015, comprise of 55 books, 175 journal papers, 35 book chapters, 222 other publications (included book reviews and papers presented in other conferences). In the analysis it is found that Prof. M.P Satija fifty percentile age is 48, i.e. the time during which one-half of all his currently active literature was published.
link.keywords: Library science, Citation Analysis, h-Index, Research Publications, Collaboration rate, Scientometrics, M.P Satija.

link.heading: Assessment of Information Literacy Skills among Science-Post Graduate Students in Universities of Karnataka State: A Study
link.authorDes: *Librarian, Sir. M.V. Government Sciecne College, Bommanakatte, Bhadravathi, Karnataka, India-577 302. E-mail: swapna_ran@rediffmail.com**Professor & Chairman, Dept. of PG Studies & Research in Library & Information Science, Kuvempu University, Shankaraghatta, Karnataka, India-577 451. E-mail: bsbiradar53@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: Information literacy is considered as the crucial skill of the 21st Century in pursuit of knowledge. It is the ability to recognizing when information is needed and being able to efficiently locate, accurately evaluate, legally and ethically use and also clearly communicate information in various formats. The purpose of this paper is to investigate information literacy skills of the Science Post-Graduate students studying in Kuvempu University and Davanagere University of Karnataka State. The survey method is used to conduct the study. A structured questionnaire with 102 questions to measure 102 variables is used to collect the data. The major findings of the study are that majority (92.5%) of the students are skilled to define, develop and revise the information need on a topic, 83.6% identify the different types, formats and 80.2% identify purpose and target audience of information sources and 97.4% understand the organization and production of universe of knowledge. An average 74.1% of students are skilled to identity and use different information retrieval tools, 62.9% evaluate the information sources available both print and electronic formats and 68.1% able to determine the cost and benefit of acquiring information sources effectively; 51.7%of students are skilled to construct and use different information search strategies; 56.9% able to summarize, synthesize and validate the gathered information; 48.3% plan, develop and communicate the information product or performance, 45.7% able to use information ethically and legally and 36.2% able to acknowledge and document consulted information sources properly. On the basis of the findings, some suggestions have been put forward to improve the information literacy skills of the students.
link.keywords: Information Literacy, Assessment, Science Post-Graduate Students, Universities, Karnataka.

link.heading: Time Series Analysis of Research Output of Social Sciences in India During 2005–2014
link.authorDes: Scientist-B (Library Science), Information and Library Network Centre, P.B. No. 4, Infocity, Gandhinagar-382007, Gujarat. E-mail: mitesh@inflibnet.ac.in
link.abstract: The present study examines the pattern of growth of research in India during 2005–2014 in social sciences as reflected by the number of papers indexed by SCImago Journal & Country Rank portal. The study unveils that during the period of study contributions from the Indian social scientist in terms of research output in social science and allied disciplines have increased. However, the proportion of uncited documents has also increased. Average citation per document in the later period has declined. It is also observed that the international collaboration among the Indian researcher is increasing in terms of number of publications. Highest number of papers has been published in the discipline of geographical sciences.
link.keywords: Research Output, Time Series Analysis, Social Sciences, SCImago Journal & Country Rank.

link.heading: Comparison among Journal Quality Indicators of Sports Science Journals
link.authors: Dr. Waris Abu*, Ahmad Shakil**, Prof. Dr. Isam Ceng., Abdel-Magid Mohammed***, Dr. Hussain Akhtar****
link.authorDes: *Assistant Professor and Acquisition Librarian, Deanship of Library Affairs, New Central Library, P.O. 1982, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, http://library.uod.edu.sa**Lecturer and Technical Librarian, Deanship of Library Affairs, New Central Library, P.O. 1982, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, http://library.uod.edu.sa, E-mail: shahmad@uod.edu.sa; shakilahma@gmail.com***Chair Development and Training Unit of Deanship of Graduate Studies, Head Proof reading and Revision Department at the Centre of Scientific Publications, Professor of water resources science and environmental engineering at Environmental Engineering Department of the College of Engineering, Imam Abdulrahman Bin Faisal University, Box 1982, Dammam, 31451, KSA, E-mail: iahmed@ud.edu.sa, isam.abdelmagid@gmail.com****Librarian, King Saud University, Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, Email: akhtar.a47@gmail.com, ahusain.c@ksu.edu.sa
link.abstract: This article evaluates the quality indices of sports science journals with emphasis on Journal Impact Factor (JIF, SCImago Journal Rank indicator (SJR), Eigen factor Score (ES) and H-index. The 2015 JIFs and ESs are obtained from Journal Citation Report® (JCR) through WoS and the SJR from the SCImago Journal and country rank website. Efforts were made to relate JIF, SJR, ES and H5 quality indices for ranking and rating quality of sports science journals. Similarly, correlations between indices were depicted by using SPSS Pearson's and Spearman's statistical correlations. Considered sports science journals have the leading standard of quality as being indexed in marked and esteemed databases such as: Web of Science (WoS) and Scopus. JIF ranged between 0.163 to 6.724; ES varied between 0.0002 to 0.0416, JSR oscillated between 0.134 to 3.333 and H5 ranged between 4 to 81. A high Pearson's (r) statistical correlation occurred between JIF and SJR indicators for journals in this category (r = 0.892) and between JIF and H5 indices (r = 0.769), while it is rather moderate between JIF and ES values (r = 0.690). Spearsman's rho statistical correlation indicated an acceptable and identical correlation appeared between JIF and SJR indicators, JIF and ES rankings and between JIF and H5 for journals in Sports science (coefficient value = 0.905, 0.845 and 0.818, respectively).
link.keywords: Journal ranking, Bibliometric indicators, Impact factor, SCImago indicator, Eigenfactor score, H5-Index, Sports Science journals.

link.heading: Growing Threat of Predatory Publishing in 21st Century: A Study
link.authorDes: Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, Pondicherry University. Email: satya75pu@gmail.com
link.abstract: The evolution of predatory journal publishing is not so long ago; but the way of they spread is very dangerous in the near future of scholarly research. They misuse the open access publishing model and charge huge publication fees/Article Processing Charges to publish scientific papers without any peer review/little peer-review. These hoax publishing have been spamming authors mainly with emails, inviting them to submit research papers for publication. The wide spread of these journals are negatively affecting on the ethics of the admissible journals, the reputations of authors, academic organisations & research institutions, and even the researchers and students. This situation is very critical towards online open access publishing and how to stop these publishing is a big challenge for academic researcher. The reason behind the problems is not the publishers alone; some researchers are also to blame for creating such types of challenges. Authors should avoid this publishing firm to respect the real science and real research. This paper highlights an overview of predatory publishing, some predatory frequently used terms, reason behind these publishing and what are the precautions followed to controlling this type of fraud are the basic of the study.
link.keywords: Predatory Journal publishing, Open-Access (OA), Article Processing Charges (APCs), Predatory Publishers, Predatory Stand-alone Journals, Hijacked Journals, Misleading Metrics.

link.heading: Current Outreach Practices at Foreign Mission Libraries and Information Centers in Delhi: A Study
link.authors: Sharma Vikram Kumar*, Dr Chadha R.K.**
link.authorDes: * Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, Banashali University, Rajasthan-304022. Email: vikramk.sharma@gmail.com**Ex- Additional Secretary, Lok Sabha Secretariat, Parliament of India, New Delhi-110001. Email: ravichad@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper highlights the current outreach practices at Foreign Mission Libraries and Information Centres in Delhi. The FMLICs provide a gateway to a range of information and activities promoting mutual interest and understanding. The concept of outreach is not new to these libraries and information centres, it has been deeply embedded in the soul of their services, resources and existence. The FMLICs employ a variety of outreach tools and techniques to accomplish their goals. This study explores the present outreach practices employed by the FMILCs.
link.keywords: Library Outreach, Foreign Mission Libraries and Information Centres, Social Media Tools, American Library, British Council Library, Alliance Francaise, Instituto- Cervantes, Goethe -Institut, German Information Centre, Russian Cultural Centre, Canadian Studies Library, Korean Cultural Centre Library.

link.heading: Skilled Human Capital Requirement in Library and Information Services: A Case Study of Central University Libraries in Delhi
link.authorDes: *Research Scholar, Department of Library and Information Science, Banasthali University, Rajasthan-304022. E-mail: ak_13@rediffmail.com**Ex- Additional Secretary, Lok Sabha Secretariat, Parliament of India, New Delhi-110001. Email: ravichad@gmail.com
link.abstract: It has been noticed that in the past libraries have been the “repositories of knowledge”, and even today, libraries work as the hub of knowledge and provide access to information. LIS professionals are not able to cater to a wide diversity of users and handle all existing information on given subject due to availability of information limited in nature and out of date. Also, their mandate doesn't allow them to provide information to outside users. In IT era a great challenge appears worldwide to bridge the Digital Divide between the urban & the rural, rich and the poor, the educated & uneducated, information rich & information poor in view of collecting and disseminating information resources. This paper presents the required skills for LIS Professionals in Library and Information Services specially related to Central University Libraries in Delhi.
link.keywords: Human Capital, LIS Professional, Skills-LIS, Central University Library, Central Reference Library, Delhi University, Jawaharlal Nehru University Library, Indira Gandhi National Open University Library, Zakir Hussain Library, Jamia Millia Islamai University Library.

link.heading: An Overview of Scholarly Open Access E-resources in Medicine and Health Sciences
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian, University of Delhi, Delhi-110 007, India
link.abstract: Defines the concept of Open Access (OA) in Scholarly Communications. Analyses the three OA declarations commonly known as BBB declarations. Describes the types of OA publishing and explains the major advantages of it. Provides a brief over view of major OA electronic resources available world wide in medicine and health Sciences. Provides brief out line of each of these e-resources for e-journals, e-books, e-theses and other electronically available information resources on Internet. Highlights the highly used resources available in each of OA databases covered under the present study.
link.keywords: Open Access E-resources, Public Domain E-Resources, Open Access Scholarly Communication, altmetrics.

link.heading: Tour of Indian LIS through the pages of Annals of Library and Information Studies (ALIS)*
link.authorDes: Principal Scientist, CSIR-National Institute of Science Communication and Information Resources 14, Satsang Vihar Marg, New Delhi-110 067. Email: gmahesh@niscair.res.in
link.abstract: Annals of Library and Information Studies is the oldest English language Indian library and information science journal that is being published since 1954. Journals, by virtue of being primary sources of information, are important information sources. Founded by Dr. S. R. Ranganathan, the Annals of Library and Information Studies is currently in its 66th year of publication. This paper traces the evolution of library and information science in India as reflected from the pages of Annals.
link.keywords: Depth classification, Documentation, Information Systems, Automation, CD-Roms, Networking, Internet, e-Resources, Open Sources, Open access, Consortia.

link.heading: Operational Excellence of Library Professionals in The Present Day Information Technology (IT) Era
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, School of Computer Engineering, KIIT University, Bhubaneswar-24, Odisha. E-mail: beda_sahoo@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: Effective brilliance is the sign of respect and executive leadership quality in the process of better management and multi operational excellence process. In this regard, necessary factors like effective planning, skilled information technology oriented professionals and the adoption of computer gadgets in the management procedure, motivational factors, attitude towards the effective services are most important factors to lead the organisation more customer based. Furthermore, it is important to say that, management support for good organisational system and professional capabilities are two important factors to raise the organisation more operational. The aim of this paper is to find out and analyse the factors like operational excellence of the organisation and good client centric through the skilled professionals for customer satisfaction.
link.keywords: Operational excellence, Effective planning, Skilled professionals, Motivational factors, Customer based services, Library database, Online services, Internet, Social networking, Information technology.

link.heading: Exploring Library and Information Science Professionals’ Responses to Knowledge Management
link.authors: Thakur Pragnya P*, Yadav Akhilesh K S**
link.authorDes: *Tata Consultancy Services, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India. Email: pragnya.thakur@tcs.com**Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, India. Email: akhilesh.yadav@tiss.edu
link.abstract: Knowledge management is no more a buzzword among academic fraternities and in academic institutes. With the corporate world leveraging the benefits of knowledge management, academic institutes are not far behind. This is an attempt to figure out the current scenario of higher educational libraries and use of knowledge management in Bhubaneswar, to identify their growth stage, awareness level and scope of implementation. So, the main purpose of the study is to find out the knowledge management awareness among library and information science professionals and best practices in higher educational institutions of Bhubaneswar, Odisha. What tools are being used to manage their knowledge resources in their respective institute and how they are assisting their parent organization in fulfilling their motto of better education? In total 38 library staffs, from different higher educational institutions of city, have participated in this web survey research. Although most LIS professionals in managerial level and executive level are aware of Knowledge management, they find it difficult to implement due to lack of effort from individual, team and the organization.
link.keywords: Knowledge Management, Library Management, Digital Resource Management, Academic Library, Higher Education.

link.heading: Use of N-List Program by the Faculty Members of Four Post-Graduate Colleges of District Jalandhar (Punjab): A Study
link.authorDes: Librarian, Doaba College, Tanda Road, Jalandhar City-144 004 (Punjab). Email: jagjit020@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: Electronic resources have become an important part of the teaching and research. These provide a lot of information at the international level. Internet provides a single platform to access electronic resources for the teaching community. Electronic resources are available now in a large number of libraries mostly through the consortia approach. Electronic books around 1,35,000 in number and 6,000 e-journals are available at the college level under N-List program. The study covers various aspects of electronic resources through N-List program that has been accessed by the faculty members of four reputed colleges of the District Jalandhar (Punjab).
link.keywords: Use of Electronic Resources, N-List Program, Faculty Members, Colleges, Jalandhar.

link.heading: Acquisition of e-Resources: Issues, Challenges and Solutions
link.authorDes: University Librarian, Maulana Azad National Urdu University, Hyderabad. E-mail: akhtaronline@gmail.com
link.abstract: Through this paper, an attempt is made to spread awareness among librarians and information managers of the possible issues involved in the subscription of e-resources. With a mission to ensure that proper selection and acquisition of eresources are done to support teaching, learning, research, training and consulting needs of students, faculty, administration and staff, the paper aims at serving as a reference point for libraries in assessing and acquiring e-resources. The issues range from content selection, e-resources pricing, terms of licensing agreements, renewals, to compatibility and support
link.keywords: e-Resources Categories, Issues in Subscriptions, Terms of licensing, library consertia, Pricing of e-resources.

link.heading: Approaches Adopted By Users To Evaluate Blogs: Case Study of Banaras Hindu University
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian (In-charge), Central Library, Central University of South Bihar. Email: mayank.yuvaraj@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper examines the criteria and indicators that blog users consider important for evaluating the quality of blogs, and develops a user-centered framework for evaluating quality by conducting user surveys and post-survey email interviews. The personal characteristics that affect the users’ choices of criteria to evaluate the quality of blogs are examined as well. Keeping the objectives into consideration, to acquire users’ criteria for assessing the quality of blogs, the questionnaire was used as the instrument of the study. Descriptive statistics, exploratory factor analysis, an independent t-test, and a one-way ANOVA were employed to analyze data from the user survey. From an extensive literature review on the quality of information resources a list of common quality indicators was compiled. The collected quality criteria and indicators were transformed into hypothesized frameworks not tailored to any specific domain or demography. In order to gain better insight on the evaluation of blog quality and to identify the criteria that people consider crucial when evaluating the quality of blogs, online and face-to-face survey to rate the importance of indicators on a five point scale ranging from 1 (not important to all) to 5 (extremely important) was used. The sample included Banaras Hindu University faculty and staff members. The study's findings include 1) the criteria that users consider important when evaluating the quality of blogs are content quality, usability, authority, and blog credibility; 2) the indicators that blog users consider most important for evaluating the quality of blogs are understandability, accuracy, believability, currency, ease of use, and navigation; and 3) gender, education level, age, profession, purpose of use, and specific interests affect the user's choices of criteria for evaluating the quality of blogs.The study proposes various factors that users consider important while evaluating blogs. It also proposes a user-centered framework for evaluating the quality of blogs. Bloggers can give their concern on these factors to make their blogs popular among users.
link.keywords: Blogs, bloggers, user evaluation, blog use framework, Banaras Hindu University.

link.heading: Library Facilities in Higher Secondary Level in Kerala – An Analysis
link.authorDes: Assistant Professor, Department of Education, University of Calicut, Kerala, India. E-mail: drbaijukn@yahoo.co.uk
link.abstract: Acquainting knowledge is a lifelong process and library is the right type of agency for this purpose. A well equipped and well managed school library is the foundation of modern educational structure. The investigation aimed to assess library facilities at higher secondary level. Schools under various boards such as Navodaya Vidyalaya, Kendriya Vidyalaya, Kerala State Higher Secondary Schools, and Vocational Higher Secondary Schools of Malappuram district of the state of Kerala were included in the sample. The tools used were questionnaire for students, interview for person in charge of library, and observation schedule. The questionnaire consisted of 34 questions related to infrastructural facilities, reading materials, time schedule and teachers or librarian. Observation schedule helped to gather infrastructural facilities available for library. Percentage analysis and qualitative analysis were used for analyzing the data. The study found out that Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya and Kendriya Vidyalaya possess library facilities at satisfactory level.
link.keywords: Library facilities, Higher Secondary Level, Kerala.

link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, Central University of Jammu. Email: cujammu.prerna@gmail.com

link.heading: News & Events
Editorial
Dr S R Ranganathan: An Intimate Biographical Essay
link.authorDes: Grandniece of Prof., S. R. Ranganathan & Barrister, Lincoln's Inn, London. E-mail: csriram7@gmail.com
link.abstract: Dr SR Ranganathan is rightly hailed as the father of Indian Library Science and one of the most important information scientists to ever grace the field. He was also a tireless evangelist for education and accessibility to books and information. This biographical note explores aspects of his personal background and character, both of which had obvious influence over his professional life and his attitude towards his colleagues and students. It will also place his success in the context of some of the personal challenges he faced and overcame, amplifying his already monumental achievements.

link.heading: Records Standardization, Retention Schedule and Weeding Out of Documents: A Proposal for Indian Libraries
link.authorDes: Indian Institute of Management Indore, Prabandh Shikhar, Pithampur Road, Indore-453 556. e-mail: akhtaronline@gmail.com
link.abstract: Efficient record management practice is an integral part of every organization in performing their day-to-day functions. Though libraries follow best practices in managing user-centric records, it is observed that most of the libraries are not following any standard policy for administrative records retention or their weeding out. The paper argues that record retention policy will help librarians in taking an informed decision concerning the retention period of different type of records. The author opines that records retention schedule is fundamental to efficient records management of any organization. The paper also discusses various government guidelines in managing records and suggests a model record retention policy for libraries.
link.keywords: Record Management, Record Retention Policy, Record Retention Schedule, Record Weeding Out.

link.heading: Indian Contributions to Scholarly Publications on Environment and Ecology-A Bibliometric Study
link.authorDes: Librarian, St Stephen's College, Delhi-110007. E-Mail: raajchd@gmail.com
link.abstract: The study aims to map environment and ecology literature published by Indian researchers during 2001 to 2014. The dataset was obtained from Scopus, accessible at: http://www.scopus.com. The study revealed that 160 countries contributed papers in the area of study. India was ranked 10. Indian authors published 11447 papers which have been published in 160 journals. These papers have been cited 152696 times till December 31, 2015. The average citation per publication is ∼13.3. During fourteen years of the study period, papers were published with an average of ∼13.3 papers in 160 journals. Twenty-one most productive journals published 3313 (28.9%) of the literature with an average ∼157.7 papers per journal. The study found that ‘Environmental Monitoring and Assessment’ has published the highest number of papers, 495 (4.3%), and these papers received 5891 (3.9%) citations. Indian authors’ highest collaboration has been with United States 912 (8.0%), followed by United Kingdom 389 (3.4%). Top 16 institutions produced collectively 2854 (24.9%) papers. Remaining 144 institutions published 8493 (75.1%) papers. Indian Institute of Technology Delhi published the highest number of papers, 335 (2.9%), and attracted 6737 (4.4%) citations. Relative citations impact of Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology and Indian Institute of Technology (Kharagpur) (∼2.1) has been highest. Ravindranath, N.H. from Indian Institute of Science has published the highest number of papers, 41 (0.4%).

link.heading: Knowledge Dissemination and Development: Tagorean Perspective
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian, Visva-Bharati, Santiniketan-731 235, West Bengal. Email: raypartha1@hotmail.com
link.abstract: Rabindranath Tagore's concept of knowledge is based on his educational philosophy of fullness and conversion of individual fullness to social fullness. It can be achieved in an environment of complete freedom-freedom of mind, freedom of heart and freedom of will. But ultimate object of Tagorean concept of education for knowledge generation, dissemination and utilization was to serve the society for its development. Tagore believed education divorced from the stream of life and confined within the four walls of the classroom becomes artificial and loses its value. The present paper is an attempt to understand Tagore's concept of knowledge and methods he adopted to communicate it for societal development. It is observed that Tagore tried to give concrete shape of his ideas with the establishment of twin institutions at Santiniketan and Sriniketan for knowledge generation as well as dissemination. Besides library different traditional indigenous folk entertainment functions and festivals were instruments to communicate it to the masses for social consumption.
link.keywords: Rabindranath Tagore, Educational Philosophy, Knowledge, Knowledge-Dissemination, Development, Santiniketan, Sriniketan.

link.heading: A Study on Electronic Sources in Selected Engineering College Libraries in Acharya Nagarjuna University Area, Andhra Pradesh
link.authors: Reddy Hari Prasad*, Dr Reddy V. Pulla**
link.authorDes: *(Rtd), Librarian, Acharya Nagarjuna University, Ongole campus, Ongole-523001, Andhra Pradesh, India. Email: reddyharsith@gmail.com**Department of Library and Information Science, Sri Venkateswara University, Tirupathi-517502, India. Email: pullareddyv@gmail.com
link.abstract: Analysis of data collected from the librarians of seven selected engineering college librarians in Acharya Nagarjuna University area, Andhra Pradesh and 1300 users of the above librarians selected by random method using questionnaire reveals many findings with regard to adequacy of e-sources their utilization, their maintenance, the satisfaction of users with them, use of Internet facility and problems in using electronic sources. A few significant differences were found between the responses of students and faculty members of engineering colleges with regard to the various aspects of electronic sources. Finally a number of recommendations have been made to improve electronic sources in engineering college libraries.
link.keywords: E-Sources, Engineering College libraries, Acharya Nagarjuna University, Andhra Pradesh.

link.heading: Dengue Research in India during 1989–2015: Three Dimensional Bibliometric Assessments
link.authorDes: Post Doctoral Fellow, Department of Library & Information Science, Banaras Hindu University, Email: sandhpandey79@gmail.com
link.abstract: The present study is an effort to assess dengue research performance of India based on the publications output indexed by Web of Science during 1989–2015 using three components namely quantity, quality and consistency. The data indicates an exponential growth in publications output during the study period. The most productive authors, organisations, most influential journals and most functional sub-field in the area of dengue research have been evaluated. Activity index for world is more than 100 in most years, whereas lots of variation is observed in the activity index for India. Quality/Impact analysis of Indian dengue research gave the first rank to Chaturvedi UC as author, FEMS Immunology and Medical Microbiology as most preferred journal and King Georg Medical College, Lucknow as the best organisation and Microbiology as most favoured sub-discipline in dengue research.
link.keywords: Bibliometrics, three dimensional evaluation, indicators, quality, quantity, consistency.

link.heading: Books Published in Punjabi: A Case Study of Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab
link.authors: Dr. Singh K P*, Chander Harish**
link.authorDes: *Associated Professor, Department of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi. E-mail: kpsingh330@gmail.com**Research Scholar, Department of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi, E-mail: arora.hca@gmail.com
link.abstract: The study presents the contribution of Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab in publication of Punjabi books. The study shows bibliometric analysis of 1278 books published during the period 1953–2014 by the Bhasha Vibhag, Punjab. The study examines various bibliometric parameters such as authorship pattern, year/decade wise distribution, format and language wise analysis, subject distribution and pagination pattern. The results indicate that majority of the books produced by single authors and large amount of books were published on Punjabi literature.
link.keywords: Punjabi Language, Punjabi Literature, Bhasha Vibhag, Punjabi Dictionaries, Authorship pattern, Punjabi Books.

link.heading: Web 2.0, Usage and Self-Efficacy: A Study of Library Science Students and Professional Library Staff at Tribhuvan University Central Library of Nepal
link.authorDes: Part-time Teacher, Central Dept. of Library and Information Science, Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences, Tribhuvan University, Kirtipur, Nepal. Email: saritagautam2011@gmail.com
link.abstract: Web 2.0 applications play a vital role to establish two way communications with the help of networking system to create and share online information or materials. The study was based on survey using questionnaire method with the objective to investigate library science population and familiarity of concepts towards the Web 2.0 tools, to identify the common understanding and attitudes of library science population towards the Web 2.0 tools and technologies, to identify the barriers to the use of web 2.0 applications, to identify the library science professionals’ and library science students’ learning mode of Web 2.0 and its usage and adoption. Data were collected from two populations: library science professionals at TUCL and library science students of T.U. The majority of the respondents were female (60%), age group from 21–30 (52%), master degree holders (56%) and from library science students (60%). The study revealed that respondents had general level of understanding and usage of Web 2.0 tools in their field. The respondents (100%) agreed that the applications of Web 2.0 tools were helpful to develop their self-efficacy and provide interactive library services. Study has attempted to find the changing trend of usage of Web 2.0 tools of the library science populations. According to the findings, most of the library science populations define the Web 2.0 tools according to their need and capabilities. Most of them (88%) think that Web 2.0 tools are social networking tools. In these senses, the general concepts and perceptions towards Web 2.0 tools are very low. It also found that the majority didn't use some of the interactive Web 2.0 tools and services. Usage of web 2.0 tools between library science professionals and students were found some how different. Lack of the know-how and technical knowledge could be another reason for the low use of Web 2.0 tools and services in the library science fields. Some recommendations were highlighted to make maximum and beneficial use of web 2.0 applications among library science professionals.
link.keywords: Blogs, Information Technology, Internet, Library 2.0, Self-efficacy, Social Networking, Social Bookmarking, Web 2.0, Wikis.

link.heading: News & Events
Audio Books Evaluation and Production Criteria Based on Iranian Producers and Consumers in Iran
link.authorDes: *Dean of Library & Information Sciences, Department (now it is named Information Sciences and Knowledge Studies Department), University of Tehran (UT), Iran. Email: fahimnia@ut.ac.ir
link.abstract: This study aimed to devise evaluation and production criteria of audio books from the producers and users’ point of view.
link.keywords: Audio books, evaluation criteria of audio book, production criteria of audio book, Process of audio book production, Mixed-methods research.

link.heading: Use of E-journals by Faculty Members and Research Scholars in Area Studies: A Case Study of Select Area Studies Centres of Jawaharlal Nehru University
link.authorDes: *Assistant Librarian, Department of East Asian Studies, University of Delhi-110007. Email: tasnimzia@yahoo.com**Associated Professor, Departmanet of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007. Email: kpsingh330@gmil.com
link.abstract: This paper revolves around the use of e-journals with the objective to ascertain their relevance in research and teaching in the discipline of Area Studies in Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU). For undertaking this study, structured questionnaires were distributed among faculty and research scholars of select/three Area Studies Centres of JNU. The study brings out that e journals are getting popular for research and teaching in Area Studies. Another noteworthy aspect is that Consortia in Area Studies are gaining popularity amongst the specialists. The study indicates that if the users are imparted training through ILPs regularly, it would hone their skills and enable them to optimally use subscribed as well as open access databases.
link.keywords: E journals, Area Studies, Usage.

link.heading: Impact of E-resources on Budget Appropriation in Agricultural Libraries of Northern India
link.authors: Bhat Nazir Ahmad*, Dr. Ganai Shabir Ahmad**
link.authorDes: *Assistant Librarian, Central Library, Sher-e-Kashmir University of Agricultural Sciences and Technology of Kashmir, 190025. E-mail: bhatnazeerahmad@gmail.com**Sr. Assistant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, The University of Kashmir, Srinagar, 190006
link.abstract: A study was conducted to assess the proportion at which the budget is spent on acquisition of the print information resources (PIRs) and electronic information resources (EIRs) in academic libraries of India, so that we are able to understand the current trend in this regard across agricultural libraries of northern India. The survey method has been adopted as the method to conduct the study and questionnaire has been used as a main data collection tool for collection of data. The telephonic interaction and e-mail correspondence has also been used to seek clarifications, remove ambiguities and obtain data of higher significance. It is found that presently major chunk of the allocated budget is being spent on acquisition of print form of books and journals across all the seven libraries under scope of present study. As such the advent of e-books and e-journals seems to have not yet laid any prominent impact on budget appropriation. Though the libraries seem to have switched their focus towards e-journals than that of print, they are seen to avail their full text access through consortium subscribed platforms and do not afford to buy many e-journals of their own. The interest to subscribe bibliographical of abstract level databases, seems to have diminished across the libraries under study. Though the libraries are interested to procure good number and quality e-books the budgetary provisions do not support or allow them to fulfill this instinct. This is first work of its nature in northern India with domain as agricultural libraries. The findings will help the librarians and the financial authorities to make judicious allocation of budget and allow them to utilise it well in commensuration with the actual need.
link.keywords: Electronic Information Resources (EIRs), Print Information Resources (PIRs), Budget Appropriation, Impact of Advent of EIRs, Agricultural Libraries.

link.heading: Development of Open Access Publishing and Archiving: A Cross-Country Comparison
link.authors: Gohain Rashmi Rekha*, Dr. Angadi Mallikarjun**, Dr. Yadav Akhilesh K.S.***
link.authorDes: *Librarian, G.J. Advani Law College, University of Mumbai, Bandra (W), Mumbai, Maharashtra, India. Email: rashmirekha.gohain2013@tiss.edu**Deputy Librarian, Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India. Email: mallikarjun@tiss.edu***Assistant Professor, Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India, Email: akhilesh.yadav@tiss.edu
link.abstract: The paper provides a review of recent developments in electronic publishing in BRICS countries, with a focus on Open Access (OA). It describes the status of OA publishing with regard to OA repositories and OA journals by collecting data from ROAR, Open DOAR and DOAJ. Finally a comparison of the retrieved data of the five BRICS countries is presented. It is inferred from the comparison that the Open Access is getting momentum among BRICS countries. BRICS are taking different initiatives to boost up the open access movement. The study recommended developing the ICT infrastructure of BRICS to make OA successful in real sense.
link.keywords: BRICS Countries, Open Access Publishing, Scholarly Communications, Institutional Repositories, Digital Archives.

link.heading: Implementing Green Technology Practices and Culture in the Library
link.authorDes: *Librarian, Deccan College Post-Graduate & Research Institute (Deemed University) Yerwada, Pune-411 006, Mob: 09822173929, Email: moretrupti02@gmail.com
link.abstract: Libraries are social organizations and ultimately the responsibility of saving the environment equally lies on the part of libraries also, as they not only disseminate information on environmental sustainability, but also can create environmental awareness in the society with the implementation of green technology practices in the library. Introducing green culture into library certainly helps in reducing unnecessary waste and conservation of natural resources. Green technology practices and culture involve implementation of environmentally supportive and sustainable activities like construction of green library building, greening existing library facilities and services within the library. Accordingly, with all such greening practices libraries can act as a key factor in the environmental and sustainability movement. This paper gives examples dealing with the ideas of how to go green in the library.
link.keywords: Green library, green technology, green culture, sustainable library, green building, green collection development, green library initiatives.

link.heading: Webometric Analysis of Web-domains of Private Universities of Himachal Pradesh
link.authorDes: Librarian, Baddi University of Emerging Sciences and Technology, Baddi, Himachal Pradesh-173 205, India. Phone: 98728–42292, E-mail: librarian@baddiuniv.ac.in
link.abstract: The current study investigates and presents the webometric and technology analysis of websites of private universities of Himachal Pradesh on the basis of web impact factor, revised web impact factor, hyperlink analysis and evaluating technologies applied to build respective university website. The calculation and evaluation of extracted data represent access, usage and ranking of universities’ websites. The results show that private universities of the northern hilly region of India are significantly serving to student community. The study further suggests that a standardized evaluation process is required to assist information scientist for analyzing the storage, organization and structure of online contents of an academic website.
link.keywords: Webometric study, technology analysis, web impact factor, link analysis.

link.heading: ICT Contents in Bachelor's Degree of LIS Curriculum in Select Universities in India: A Study
link.authorDes: *Librarian, Vallabhbhai Patel Chest Institute, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007. E-mail: tyagiuma@yahoo.com**Faculty, School of Social Sciences, I.G.N.O.U, Maidan Garhi, New Delhi-110068. E-mail: zuchamo@gmail.com
link.abstract: Evaluation of curriculum is an essential part of the curriculum development because it helps in identifying the areas for further development, if any. This paper analyses the ICT contents in LIS curriculum in India. It evaluates the LIS bachelor's degree courses offered in different universities in India. Emphasis has been made to determine the outcomes of the existing curriculum in different universities across India, to ascertain the need for revision of the ICT course contents, to help in future development of the curriculum contents for continuous evaluation and improvement. It has been observed that requirement of innovating and inclusive contents are imperatively needed in LIS curriculum.
link.keywords: ICT Course Contents, Curriculum, LIS, Universities, LIS Education, Bachelor's degree.

link.heading: Measuring Information Literacy Skill: A Case Study of Post-graduate Students of Khwopa College, Bhaktapur (Nepal)
link.authorDes: *Bhaktapur-17, Nepal, E-mail: lalichyai@gmail.com
link.abstract: The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of information literacy on academic performance of post-graduate students of Environment Science of Khwopa College, Bhaktapur (Nepal). It aimed to examine the searching capabilities on searching online databases and to know students’ knowledge on organizing the information that students had retrieved. Here a practical study was conducted to investigate skills on information literacy among post-graduate students. Out of 23 students and faculty members, 13 students of Environment Science at Khwopa College, Bhaktapur were taken for this study purpose. They were asked pre-test and post-test questions. After having their pre-test response, a two days training was conducted on online database searching and Mendeley reference management software was taught. These two topics were taught within one week difference, so that students’ get time for practice. Soon after training, the students were made to fill post-test questionnaire. Data was collected from the answer sheets of these participants. All 13 students filled the questionnaire. From the data analysis, it was derived that t-test for paired samples between result of pre-test and post-test (p = 0.02) supported students obtained good knowledge on information literacy and use in their work after the information literacy training. They understood better about information sources (by 100%) and made improvement in information searching. Moreover they learnt the organization and management of information sources. However the study showed students got difficulties in exploiting search strategy tool; hence need further training for them on search strategy. College library must provide better information services that support information literacy for college students.
link.keywords: Information literacy, information sources, search strategy, post-graduate students.

link.heading: Reading Habits of Teacher Trainees in Education
link.authorDes: Technical Assistant, Mahatma Gandhi University Kottayam, E-mail: indirab575@gmail.com
link.abstract: Reading habit among teacher trainees is very essential as it not only improves their own knowledge base but also indirectly influences the students whom they are about to teach. Poor reading habit leads to low quality of education in students. A survey was conducted among 191 B. Ed students under nine optional subjects. The findings prove that B. Ed students like reading and majority of them spend 1–2 hour daily for reading. But the influence of electronic medias like TV, Computer, Internet etc have reduced the time they spend for reading.
link.keywords: Reading habit, Teacher trainees, Education, Influence of electronic media.

National Mission for Revival of Ranganathan Legacy (NMRRL): An appeal

link.heading: Charity on the Web: An evaluation of an Iranian Charity Organization Website
link.authors: Riahinia Nosrat1, Azimi Ali2,*, Moradi Fatemeh3, Mirhosseini Mahdiyeh4, Chitsaz Mahdiyeh5
link.authorDes: 1Full professor of, LIS, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran, sara_purriahi@yahoo.com2PhD student of, LIS, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Mashhad, Iran3MA of, Scientometrics, Shahed University, Tehran, Iran, fatemehmoradi66@gmail.com4MA of, LIS, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran, mirhosseini.mah@gmail.com5MA of, LIS, Kharazmi University, Tehran, Iran, nasrin.chitsaz.66@gmail.com
