link.heading: Benefits of RFID technology for libraries: An Indian perspective
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi-110016, India. Email: hasan@library.iitd.ac.in
link.abstract: The paper provides an overview of Radio Frequency IDentification (RFID) technology, its importance in the library management system and working. It describes the important components and their uses. The benefits of using the technology like self charging-discharging, renewing, high speed inventorying, theft detection, automated materials handling, reliability, people counter, etc. have been highlighted. The merits of RFID over Bar code and EM have been enumerated and the scope of the hybrid technology has been explored with special reference to Indian environment. The paper also lists the important RFID vendors and also the libraries, using the system in India.
link.keywords: RFID, Radio Frequency Identification, Library Security System, Library Authentication System, Tagging.

link.heading: Determining the Information Literacy Competence (ILC) of MA students in Tarbiat Moallem University, Iran
link.authorDes: Tarbiat Moallem University, Tehran, Iran.
link.abstract: The main goal of the study was to determine Information Literacy Competency (ILC) of MA students in Tarbiat Moallem University in Iran. The study implemented a descriptive analytical method. The study tool was a researcher design questionnaire. All M.A. students in Faculty of Education and Psychology were selected as statistical population for the study (n=145). The results showed that the students’ ILC mean for recognizing their information need was 3.65, for bridging previous knowledge with the current obtained information 3.39, for being acquainted with information resources and databases 2.7, for information search strategy 3.05, for information retrieving 2.87, for information evaluation and assessing 3.02, for organizing information 2.97, and finally for managing citations 3.06.The research reported studied students’ ILC status as 3.22 which is higher than the average. Overall, the ILC status is reasonable and it seems that students could handle their scientific needs. Nonetheless, the studied students are far beyond the optimum status desired by the university authorities.
link.keywords: Information Literacy (IL), ACRL standards, MA students, Tarbiat Moallem University (TMU), Faculty of Education and Psychology, Iran.

link.heading: Use of E- Resources by Chemists and Physicists: A case study of Punjab University, Chandigarh
link.authorDes: * Research Scholar, Department of Library & Information Science, KU, Kurukshetra. Email: Sakshiarora_13@yahoo.co.in** Assistant Professor, Department of Library & Information Science, KU, Kurukshetra. Email: Joginder_burman@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: E- Resources play a vital role in all subjects. The study was based on survey using questionnaire method with the objective to identify the familiarity of eresources of 96 respondents with the percentage rate of 87.27%. The study reveals that all the faculty members and research scholars were familiar with e- resources. 100% faculty members use e- resources for the purpose for their research and education and preferred both print and electronic media for searching information. More than 50% PG students use internet at the university library. Google is the most used search engine. 59.38% respondents were satisfied with e- resources and a majority of respondents i.e. 85.42% face the common problem of slow speed in accessing e- resources. Some suggestions are highlighted to make maximum use of e- resources.
link.keywords: E-resources, Information resources, Chemistry, E-resources, Physics, E-resources, Panjab University, E-resources.

link.heading: Use and Assessment of Digital Information Resources: An User's Perspective of GGSIP University Library
link.authorDes: Assistant Librarian, University Information Resource Centre (UIRC), Guru Gobind Singh Indraprastha University, Sector 16-C, Dwarka, New Delhi-110075; Email: akdeval@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: This study highlights some of the facts associated with the use and assessment of digital information resources and focuses on the usefulness of digital information resource collection for the university library. Therefore, it is very important from the point of view of guiding the administrator of the library, in developing and maintaining the collection of digital information resources.
link.keywords: E-resources, Digital information resources, Electronic database, Academic resources, Information resources.

link.heading: Network of Rural Libraries in Madhya Pradesh: A Study
link.authors: Dr Sharma Arvind K.*, Jayant Jaswant Singh**
link.authorDes: * Assistant Professor, Department of Library and Information Science, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior- 474009. Email: arvindksharma22@gmail.com** Naka Chandra Vadni, Gwalior- 474009.
link.abstract: This article deals with the Network of Rural Libraries in Madhya Pradesh established by Government of Madhya Pradesh under the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA). Since 26 January 2003, libraries are being established in villages. Government has determined an amount of Rs. 12,500 for establishing a rural library/cultural centre. Total number of rural libraries established were 604 in Gwalior district, 572 in Datia district and 1300 in Shivpuri district during 2003 – 2008. Sixty questionnaires were sent to select 20 libraries of each district of Datia, Gwalior and Shivpuri. Out of these, only 57 (97%) libraries responded. Major finding are: preraks or in charge of rural libraries, majority of library-in-charges have passed Higher Secondary (43.86%), only Rs. 500/- to Rs. 1000/- were paid to the in charge, majority of rural libraries (98.25%) have books, these libraries have no library management software or network connection. The collected data indicated that majority (84.21%) of libraries have television.
link.keywords: Networks, Library networks, Rural Library Networks, Rural Libraries, Madhya Pradesh.

link.heading: State of Libraries and Librarianship in Odisha: An Observation
link.authors: Dr. Mahapatra Rabindra K.*, Dr. Jena Kamal Lochan**, Dr. Swain Dillip K.***
link.authorDes: * Chief Librarian, Central Library, Odisha University of Agriculture & Technology (OUAT), Bhubaneswar -751 003. E-Mail- rkm_02@yahoo.com/rkmahapatra60@gmail.com** Librarian, College of Engineering & Technology (CET), Bhubaneswar -75116. E-mail-kljena@redifmail.com*** Assistant Librarian, KIIT University, Bhubaneswar-751024. E-mail-swaindk_69@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: Studies the organisational functioning and library system in the State of Odisha. The study covers library education, librarian's qualification, professional opportunities, continuing education avenues and role of library associations in the state. Concludes that development of libraries has to be considered in right direction to ensure efficient education, learning and culture of the state.
link.keywords: Libraries, Librarianship, Libraries, Odisha, Library System, Odisha.

link.heading: Use of Critical Incident Technique for Collecting Data in Health Care Settings of Nepal
link.authorDes: Associate Professor, Central Department of Library and Information Science, Tribhuvan University, Kathmandu, Nepal. E-mail: mpradhan@healthnet.org.np
link.abstract: The objective of this paper is to explore the utilization of Information Technology to fulfill the information needs of physicians in Nepal. Critical Incident Technique as an open ended questionnaire were used for collecting data. Three taxonomies were used for this purpose. This study reveals that patient care issues have motivated searches information through Internet by physicians. The reasons span among treatment, prognosis, diagnosis and preventing disease. It can be concluded that time access and retrieval of information is beneficial for knowledge update and life saving in many cases. The other benefits include reduced cost of care, the advancement of research and medical education by physicians.
link.keywords: Critical incident technique, information needs of physcians, health care settings, healthnet Nepal.

link.authors: Dr Apeji E-Adeche*, Obe Precious Iziegbe**
link.authorDes: * Nigerian Educational Research & Development Council P.M.B. Garki-Abuja.** Pugeo Shelters Ltd, Awolowo Way, Utako-Abuja.
link.abstract: The problem of scarcity of scholarly books has become intractable in Nigeria. Students and faculty do not have access to books that are relevant to their programmes. In an attempt to find solutions to this problem a survey was conducted. The survey revealed the reasons for the scarcity. These reasons are discussed and solutions recommended.
link.keywords: Scarcity, Scholarly Books, Book Publishers.

link.heading: An Analytical Study of Literature on Information Literacy
link.authorDes: *Phulshing Naik Mahavidhyalaya, Pusad-445 216, Dist. Yavatmal (MS) (India). Member of Senate, (SGB Amravati University, Amravati) (MS), E-mail: ppdeshmukh_bnce@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: The researcher has analyzed data on Information Literacy collected from different sources. 3901 articles were found from 1981 to 2010. The analysis shows trends in publication have increased from 2003 onwards. Foreign authors are more in number than Indian author. Journals are most favoured category of researchers. Single author contributes 61.55% articles and out of 3901 articles 385 articles are on Information Literacy in Higher Education. 3901 articles are published in 23 international languages.
link.keywords: Information Literacy, Library literacy, Model Information Literacy, Librarian Information Literacy.

link.heading: Periodicals Use Pattern by Faculty Members of JNN College of Engineering, Shivamogga
link.authors: Dr Biradar B S*, Professor, Kumar K T Santhosh**, Assistant Professor, Kumar C Chetan***, Librarian
link.authorDes: *Department of Library & Information Science, Kuvempu University, Jnanasahyadri-577 451, Shimoga, Karnataka.**Department of Library & Information Science, Sahyadri Arts College, Shivamogga-577 203, Karnataka.***, CMR Institute of Management Studies (Autonomus), Kalyan Nagar, Bangalore, Karnataka.
link.abstract: The study investigates the utilization patterns of periodical literature amongst the faculty members at JJN College of Engineering. About 110 questionnaires were distributed and 96 were received back. The study found that equal number of users (40.62%) use both Indian and Foreign periodicals once in a week. As far as purpose of using periodicals is concerned, as first preference updating the latest development (55.68%) followed by gaining deeper knowledge (54.54%). 48.95% of users rated as excellent for printed version, whereas 28.12% for electronic version and 60.41% of users preferred both print and electronic version.

link.heading: Public Library Scenario in North East India with Special Reference to Mizoram
link.authors: Saini Surbhi, Research and Teaching Assistant (RTA)
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, School of Social Sciences (SOSS), Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU), Maidhan Garhi, New Delhi-110068. Email: innovation.surbhi@gmail.com
link.abstract: The study deals with the Public libraries in India as well as tries to highlight the public library system in the North East Region. The study deals with Raja Rammohun Roy Library Foundation's (RRRLF) role in the development of public libraries. As the library legislation is widely recognized as a helpful means for the establishment and development of public libraries as it provides the smooth financial support for the proper functioning of the libraries. The paper deals with the present status of public libraries in internet environment. The public library services should be re-engineered to meet the changing electronic environment. The paper also discusses about the need of re-engineering public library services, and presents scenario of public library in Mizoram and role of Young Mizo Association in public library development.

link.heading: Growth of LIS Research During Golden Jubilee of Maharashtra State
link.authors: Dr Chikate Anil Nanaji*, Deputy Librarian, Dr Lihitkar Shalini R.**, Assistant Professor and Head, Dr Gadge-Chikate Sharmila***, Researcher
link.authorDes: *Central Library, North Maharashtra University, Umvinagar, Jalgaon (MS) 425001. E-mail: anchikate@nmu.ac.in**Department of Library and Information Science, Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University (RTMNU), Nagpur. e-mail: shanwaghmare@yahoo.com***Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University (RTMNU), Nagpur E-maiI: sharmilichikate@rediffmail.com
link.abstract:
Maharashtra state celebrated 2010 as its Golden Jubilee year. The authors point out the relevance between growth and development of Maharashtra and development of research in LIS schools of the state. The growth in the number of supervisors during the Decade, and the increase in the number of students registering for doctoral studies and awarded of the degree of Ph Ds shows that the research in library and information science discipline is at cross roads in LIS schools of Maharashtra State. In all 130 awarded Ph. Ds in LIS have been analyzed keeping using various parameters like gender, guide, subject, university and most favoured areas of research in LIS. The authors have traced LIS research trends in Maharashtra during last fifty years and also suggested some measures to improve the quality of LIS research.
Keywords.: LIS, LIS education, Research, Doctoral Research, Maharashtra

link.heading: Ahlcon International School Book Week (2010–2011)
Evidence-based Librarianship: Implications for Indian Librarians
link.authors: Dr Marolia Perin V, Co-ordinator, Networking and Information Dissemination Cell
link.authorDes: UGC Project on Capacity Building of Women Managers in Higher Education, SNDT Women's University Library, Mumbai, 400020
link.abstract: Evidence-Based Librarianship (EBL) provides a process for integrating the best-available scientifically generated evidence into making important decisions. The present article aims to introduce the basics of EBL, summarizes the steps involved, and presents the implications for the Library and Information Science profession in India. The EBL process involves specifying the problem, finding the evidence to answer the problem, appraising the evidence, applying the results, evaluating the outcome and, if necessary, redefining the problem. One begins the process by identifying and clarifying what exactly one is aiming to do, for which EBL can be applied. The next step is to search for the evidence and examine it critically followed by applying the evidence that has been collected and evaluated. It is practical to prepare an Action Plan at the outset. An important part of this stage is also to evaluate the effect of applying evidence-based practice in the given situation. Therefore, the evaluation process must be planned as part of evidence based practice, before implementing the evidence-based decision. It is suggested that Indian librarians should integrate EBL into their professional practice. In the initial stages, at the practical level, the following initiatives should be considered: Library and information professionals should carry out more action research; initiatives should be taken by apex bodies such as Library Associations, University Departments of Library & Information Science, the National Library and other similar institutions to develop systems for sharing of evidence; and a culture of evidence based practice should be promoted across the L&IS profession.
link.keywords: Evidence Based Librarianship.

link.heading: Evaluation of the Scientific Productions (SPs) of the Faculty Members (FMs) in Iran: A case study
link.authors: Dr Riahinia Nosrat*, Associate Professor of Library and Information Science, Associate Dean for Research, Dr Asemi Asefeh**, Assistant Professor, Head of Library and Information Science, Dr Zandian Fatemeh***, Assistant Professor of Library and Information Science
link.authorDes: * Faculty of Psychology and Education, Tarbiat Moallem University, Tehran, Iran, sara_purriahi@yahoo.com** Department in University of Isfahan, Isfahan, Iran, af_asemi@yahoo.com*** Head of LIS Department in Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran, zandian@modares.ac.ir
link.abstract: The main objective of this paper is studying SPs of FMs at the Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tarbiat Modarres (UTM), Tehran, (Iran) during years 2001–2006. The research considers the amount of SPs in the forms of book, journal paper, seminar/conference papers, research project, and thesis supervision. The survey method is applied and data is collected through questionnaires. The statistical population consists of 62 FMs. The results show that 98.4% of FMs are male and 1.6% are female. 30.6% have Ph D and 69.4% have Ph D with specialization. Responses reveal that out of 5508 national and international scientific productions, 1987 journal paper titles, 2420 seminar paper titles, 169 titles of books compilation and translation titles, 149 research project titles and 783 theses supervision cases. The results showed a significant relationship between the academic rank of professors and their scientific outputs and there is no significant difference between different fields of study in the research population in terms of scientific productions.
link.keywords: Scientific products (SPs), faculty members (FMs), University of Tarbiat Modarres-(UTM), Faculty of Agriculture, Iran.

link.heading: Open Access Movement for Managing Intellectual Informatics
link.authors: Dr Beena C*, Assistant Librarian, University Library, Archana N S**, Junior Librarian, University Library
link.authorDes: Cochin University of Science & Technology.
link.abstract: The present work focuses on various facets of open access movement for managing intellectual output that eventually becomes available and accessible in public domain. Thus, purpose of this paper is to document and share the real time experience of managing and sharing of intellectual wealth of academia of Cochin University of Science & Technology by using open source platforms. This paper is trying to explore different intellectual information resources in the current era and also aims to suggest cost effective strategy of implementing new open access tools and technology for effective managing of intellectual informatics.
link.keywords: Open Access Movement, Open Access Tools, Intellectual Informatics.

link.heading: Use of Social Networking Sites by the Research Scholars: A Study of Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar.
link.authors: Dr Singh KP*, Senior Assistant Professor and Principal Investigator, Gill Malkeet Singh**, Ph.D Scholar
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi (India).
link.abstract: The innovation in the Web applications and Internet Technology has brought new avatar of two way communication which is usually referred as web.2.0. The web 2.0 based applications such as wiki, blogs, RSS, SNSs, IMs, etc brings new paradigm shift in the e-communication and learning by the people of all age groups and genders in real time round the clock. The present study is an attempt to determine the use and effectiveness of such applications in education and research by the research scholars. The study conducted through a structured questionnaire administrated among the research scholars pursuing their research at GND University Amritsar. The study finds that majority of the respondents were found to be aware and making use of such applications in their research affairs and it was revealed from the study that Facebbok is the most popular SNS by all category of research scholars.
link.keywords: Social Networking Sites, ICT, Social Software, Web 2.0 application.

link.heading: Confetti of thoughts on library and information science: Essays in honour of Prof (Dr) C V Raman Pillai.
link.authorDes: Delhi Library Association, cpv_36@yahoo.co.in

link.heading: Towards The Provision of Information Needs and Library Services for Rural Community Development: Challenges For Democratic Government in Nigeria
link.authorDes: University of Ado-Ekiti, Nigeria
link.abstract: The paper looks at the provision of information needs and library services for rural community development: challenges for democratic government in Nigeria. It focuses on information needs of rural dwellers which library or information centre assists them in meeting. It looks at the concept of rurality and the nature of rural library, identifies the information needs for rural community development and highlights the problems of information flow in rural communities. It states the challenges for democratic government of providing information needs and library services for rural community development. It gives recommendations and conclusion by affirming the role of a democratic government in Nigeria in the provision of information needs and library services for rural community development.
link.keywords: Information Needs, Library Services, Rural Community Development.

link.heading: Electronic Databases: Provisions of Protection
link.authors: Dr Vyas S D*, Librarian, Rai Priya**, Deputy Librarian
link.authorDes: * Nalsar University of Law, Hyderabad, 500078.** National Law University, Delhi, New Delhi, 110078.
link.abstract: In the era of digital divide, the information in the form of electronically searchable databases has given birth to a new profit making industry. Process of creating databases involves considerable cost and is undertaken for generating revenue, but on the other hand it has proved extremely useful to research and educational purposes. Increasing production of digital born databases raises legal issues relating to Copyright and intellectual property in cyberspace environment as there is no globally accepted International copyright law that would take precedence over local laws. The article provides an overview about the legal protection of databases at national and international level. It concludes that librarians should tell their concern about its costing as well as go for national law network for academic law universities.
link.keywords: Electronic Databases, Digital Born databases, Copy Right Protection, Berne convention, WIPO, TRIPS, IPR.

link.heading: Faculty Image of Librarians: How They See Us?
link.authors: Dr Joshi Manoj K, Associate Professor
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, 136119. manojkj01@yahoo.com
link.abstract: University and college faculty of Haryana attending an orientation and a refresher course were surveyed for their views on different aspects of the personality of librarians. The results show that the five highly possessed qualities of librarians in faculty's view were: competent, approachable, friendly, helpful, and enthusiastic. The university faculty viewed librarians more approachable while college faculty viewed them as competent. Female faculty viewed them more knowledgeable and enthusiastic while in the male faculty's view librarians were helpful and organized. Concludes that except competent all other highest ranked characteristics are personal in nature.
link.keywords: Faculty image of Librarians.

link.heading: LIS Education in India: Challenges For Students and Professionals in The Digital Age
link.authorDes: Kalasalingam University, Krishnankoil-626190, Tamil Nadu, India. senthur85@gmail.com
link.abstract: The paper deals with the Library and Information Science (LIS) education and LIS professionals in India. Currently both the traditional libraries and the digital libraries coexist in India. LIS education in India has not become receptive to the new emerging situation. The library schools have failed to develop the required knowledge and skills relating to the use of information technology among students. As a result, the graduates from the LIS departments have little competitive potential in the information market. The paper discusses the challenges in LIS education in the Indian context. It deals with preparing LIS graduates for leadership and management roles to support national and economic development in India, as well as the collaboration and resource sharing among LIS schools. It also discusses the recent emphasis given on e-learning in LIS education in India, the impact of LIS education on the work and career of graduates, the job market for LIS professionals, competencies needed and continuing professional development of LIS professionals.
link.keywords: Library and Information Science (LIS) education, Library Schools, Library professionals, Information professionals, ICT in libraries.

link.heading: Technological March from Web 1.0 to Web 3.0: A Comparative Study
link.authors: Dr Singh K P*, Senior Assistant Professor,  Bebi**, Research Scholar, Gulati Dipti***, Research Scholar
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India.
link.abstract: This paper deals with the technological march from Web 1.0 to 3.0 for managing the web information. Authors have discussed about the concept of web 1.0 to 3.0. A shift from web1.0 to 3.0 has also been shown. A comparative study has been drawn on these three concepts on certain parameters such as: Technology, advancement, networking, users etc.
link.keywords: Web 1.0, Web.2.0, Web 3.0, Web Technology.

link.heading: Preservation And Conservation of Manuscripts: A Case Study of A. C. Joshi Library, Panjab University, Chandigarh
link.authors: Dr Vohra Ranjana*, Professor, Sharma Aarti**, Assistant Librarian
link.authorDes: * Department of Library and Information Science. Panjab University, Chandigarh.** Mohinder Singh Randhawa Library. Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana.
link.abstract: This study explores the issues of conservation and preservation of the rare manuscripts collection in Panjab University Library, Chandigarh. The Library has a good collection, comprising of one thousand four hundred ninety three manuscripts. The data about the collection, acquisition, organization, preservation and conservation, infrastructural facilities and digitization of manuscripts was obtained from library staff. The library has manuscripts in Hindi, Sanskrit, Punjabi, Persian, and Urdu. Some measures have been taken for the preservation and conservation of these precious items for the benefits of future generations.
link.keywords: Manuscripts, preservation, conservation, Digitization.

link.heading: Unravelling the Mystery of Our Role Model
link.authorDes: Delhi University. H.No.842 GF, Dr. Mukherji Nagar, Delhi, 110009. srg2001@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: A new concept - “Role Model for Librarians” is introduced. The libraries are the service institutions, and the librarians being the servants of library patrons, therefore, identifies the area of their role model in the universe of ‘Master-Servant relationship. Never asked question was raised by the author in a class of library science students at Bombay University. The answer to the pertinent question revealed Shree Hanuman of Ram Charit Manas. Discusses the criteria for selection, and on the touch stone, Hanuman appears as an omnivorous servant in the service of Master, Lord Ram. The test for omnivorous servant is the same as that for becoming a librarian. Besides possessing the basic faculties, the librarians should provide selfless service to the master, should belittle self-promotion and always engage to serve others, should be intelligent and rational, honest and sincere, be a bond of master-servant relationship with singular devotion. We, the librarians, should emulate Hanuman to take our calling to the top of the professions world.

link.heading: Leadership Skills
link.authors: Binwal J C, Prof., Ex Professor of Library & Information Science
link.authorDes: NEHU, Shillong.
link.abstract: Maintains that libraries of the 21st century are undergoing a dynamic phase of transformation. Four key issues – quality, service, innovation and productivity facing other organizations are equally applicable to libraries. To meet the demands of these issues, an organization has to maintain balance between technology, management and leadership. Leadership is very crucial to the effective management of libraries. Deals with five fundamental elements of leadership. They are:- vision, mission, values, environment and behaviour. Describes theories and styles of leadership, Explains leadership skills under six broad groups. These include formulation of vision, mission and value statements; communications skills; team building skills; initiative and innovative spirit; motivation and feedback skills; and positive attitude.3

link.heading: Indian Citation Index (ICI): A Dream of Indian Research Community Comes True
link.authorDes: *B-13, 3rd. Floor, Block A, Ring Road, LSC, Naraina Vihar, New Delhi110028. E-mail:  prakash@indiancitationindex.com
link.abstract: This article presents the points which necessitate the development of Indian citation index (ICI) for portraying comprehensive and realistic picture of country's research. Also, describes the contents organization and process of Indian Citation Index (ICI). It portrays the number and corresponding percentage of Indian journals in Science Citation Index from 1961 to 2009. The ICI is abstracts and citation database available to users at www.indiancitationindex.com
link.keywords: Indian Citation Index, ICI, Citation Index, Research Community, Citation Index Construction.

link.heading: Equitable Library Services and Information Support for Distance Education
link.authors: Dr Tripathi Manorama*, Deputy Librarian, Jeevan V K J**, Deputy Librarian
link.authorDes: *Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Mehrauli Road, New Delhi- 110067, email: manoramatripathi2@yahoo.com**Indira Gandhi National Open University, Maidan Garhi, New Delhi- 110068, email: vkjj@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: In a knowledge economy, the significance of knowledge and education is universally acknowledged. Economic competitiveness and prosperity of a country depends upon the strides made in the field of Education and Training. The conventional system of education is not able to cope with the increased demand for training, education and updating knowledge. Distance learning has emerged as a viable option for lifelong learning and as a means for human resource development in the country. It is acquisition of knowledge and skills through mediated information and instruction. It covers all technologies and facilitates the pursuit of lifelong learning for all. This massive popularity in distance education has eventually resulted in the libraries attaining an enormous importance; their role in the effective delivery of distance education has increased manifold. The paper presents the prevailing status of library operations in different open universities of the country. It discusses how Information Communication technologies should be harnessed by libraries to supplement and complement distance education in the country. The paper further endeavours to compare them with library practices adopted at other open Universities (such as Hong Kong Open University, Athabasca Open University of Canada, Open University of United Kingdom), Sheffield Hallam University, UK, and Jones International University, USA. which have emerged as pioneers in library and information intrinsic delivery of distance education. The paper suggests an equitable access model, which may be adopted by open Universities’ libraries across the country for providing effective distance education in the country.

link.heading: Evaluation of an Educational Website Based on a Well-structured Standard
link.authors: Dr Riahinia Nosrat*, Attaran Mohammad*, Asemi Asefeh**
link.authorDes: *Tarbiat Moallem University, Tehran, Iran**University of Isfahan, Iran
link.abstract: The main goal of the present stydy is evaluation of an educational website based on a well-structured standard. The standard developed is based on a deep review through the literature in the field. After having validated by a group of experts, the standard was conducted for evaluation of ‘Roshd’ educational website.Roshd is an educational website affiliated to the Iran's Ministry of Education. The website provides educational and instructional contents for students of various levels up to university level. The standard was then distributed among a population of university experts who were asked to evaluate the Roshd website based on the standard criteria.In all 10 participants evaluated the Roshd in respect of the standard items including the website quality and suitability of contents, conformity of contents with the website goal, and presenting interactive content, etc.
link.keywords: Educational website, Roshd, Evaluation, Iran.

link.heading: Prescriptive/Diagnostic Assessment of Information Literacy Competency of Science, Engineering and Technology Students of Higher Education Institutions in Delhi
link.authorDes: *Ramjas College, University Enclave, Delhi110007. Email:  tjoshi@ramjas.du.ac.in
link.abstract: Lots of information is available, but finding this information, retrieving and using it effectively is a big challenge that the students face at university level. Assessment of information literacy competency of such students needs to be done, before the development of information literacy training module for them, to find the baseline of their information literacy competency.
link.keywords: Information Literacy, Assessment.

link.heading: A Study of Library Users With Special Reference to B.S. Abdur Rahman University Library, Chennai
link.authorDes: *B.S. Abdur Rahman University. G S T Road, Vandalur, Chennai. e-mail:  pspanneerselvam@gmail.com
link.abstract: Library is the centre for knowledge and it has to be well maintained to nurture generation next people for the better social order. In an educational institution, the library is more responsible and value since the younger generation are to grow from here. The library has to be updated by modern systems and services. These services should reach its users. Study of library users is very much needed to know their requirements and to serve them better. The present article is written based on the study at the institution about the users, their needs and the library services.

link.heading: Issues and challenges of Indian Library Education and Service in a Knowledge Society
link.authors: Dr. Kumar Sunil, Senior Lecturer & Head
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Documentation, State Council of Educational Research & Training (SCERT), Varun Marg, Defence Colony, New Delhi-110024. e-mail: sk_n66@hotmail.com.
link.abstract: This paper discusses the issues and concerns relevant to Library Education and Service in India. Briefly, describes the background of library science education in India. Gives an overview of UGC's contributions in development of library education in India. States the present position of library science education and efforts made by the Government of India in appointing various library committees from time to time, and recently National Knowledge Commission (NKC), 2005 for providing guidance and directions to all types of libraries to achieve the national mission on libraries in India. Concludes with some possible suggestions for future library education in India in the changing society.

link.heading: Assessing Information Literacy Competency of ISLM Graduate Students of Dhaka University: An analysis
link.authors: MD. Islam Anwarul1, Lecturer, Dr Chowdhury Salma2, Chairman & Associate Professor
link.authorDes: 1Department of Information Science & Library Management, University of Dhaka, E-mail: anwar_81du@yahoo.com.au.2Department of Information Science & Library Management, University of Dhaka, E-mail: salmachy@yahoo.com.
link.abstract: Information literacy is one of the most important terms which covers all the techniques related to the information. The ability to search, evaluate and use information effectively is more commonly known as Information Literacy. It is a new type of skill that arises as a demand of the information era. In the age of information explosion, it has created a new demand for proficiencies and capabilities to deal with information. The aim of this study is to assess the information literacy competency of ISLM graduate students and also focus on the strengths and weaknesses of students. In general it was found that students had limited skills in the area of information literacy as most of the IL courses were not available in their syllabus. Based on these findings, a series of recommendations were proposed to help develop information literacy competency. This study urges that incorporation of information literacy programme in the course curriculum, more and more writings, discussion and other relevant issues will make ISLM graduate students more information literate.
link.keywords: Information literacy, Competency, Assessment, Retrieval technique.

link.heading: Information Literacy in Indian Agricultural Universities: A study of Punjab Agricultural University
link.authorDes: Mohinder Singh Randhawa Library, Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana, 141004, Punjab, India, e-mail: yogita_sharma@pau.edu.
link.abstract: The present study assesses the ability of the users of Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana in using information efficiently and effectively. The study was focused to ascertain the present status of the users in the process of information gathering, to determine the factors affecting the process and recommend improvements thereof. The study was conducted on post-graduate students, teachers and research fellows. The data was collected using a questionnaire and simple random sampling without replacement was used. The data so collected was analyzed using MS-excel. It was found that majority of user was able to access, use and organize the information efficiently. It was recommended that collaborative approach of librarians and teachers must be encouraged to improve information literacy skills amongst the user. In addition to this including information literacy as a mandatory part of course-curriculum was strongly felt. In this process librarians have a vital role to play by organizing information literacy programmes frequently.
link.keywords: information literacy, information skills, information literacy skills, agricultural universities, agricultural university libraries.

link.heading: Are Librarians Ready For The Future of Librarianship In View of The Development of Organisations
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Ch. Charan Singh University, Meerut (UP).
link.abstract: This paper describes the challenging role of librarians in the development of organizations in information age. The author argues how the traditional system of librarianship has completely been whitewashed with the advent of new technologies in the present information seeking environment. The transition of information from paper to electronic media, complexity in information needs and the increase in the cost and quality of information has also been discussed. The paper discusses the requirement of minimum facilities in libraries for the maximum utilization of library resources and to satisfy the maximum demands of the clientele. Highlights the problems faced by libraries these days. Finally discusses the qualities of the librarians that are essential for the survival.

link.heading: Use of E- Resources in College Libraries of Delhi
link.authors: DR Singh Gurdev, Librarian, Arora Taruna, Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Sri Guru Gobind Singh College of Commerce, University of Delhi.2Modern Public School, Shalimar Bagh, Delhi. E-Mail: drgurdevsingh@hotmail.com and tarunaarora11@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper describes the use of electronic resources by the students and teachers of various college libraries of Delhi. The survey was particularly conducted to know the use of e-resources and awareness of electronic resources in various college libraries of Delhi. The analysis of the data collected covers various types of e-resources, purpose of use of e-resources, problems faced by the users in using the e-resources, satisfaction level of users and finally it highlights the suggestions made by the users for further improvement of use of e-resources in various college libraries of Delhi. This study has also shown the preferences and importance given to e-resources by the students and teachers of various college libraries of Delhi.

link.heading: Design and Development a Web-Enabled Directory of Library and Information Science Teachers in India: A Proposed Model
link.authors: Singh KP1, Senior Assistant Professor and Principal Investigator, Moirangthem Esther2, M.Phil Scholar, Negi Nandi3, Research Associate
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007. E-mail: singhkp_1972@yahoo.co.in; kpsngh@aerodirindia.com.2Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007.3AR&DB/DRDO Research project C/o Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007. E-mail: nandinegii@gmail.com.
link.abstract: Directory is the vital reference tool for finding various sorts of information related to an organization, institution, company, persons, etc. These sources become more beaming and significant for the users when they are available in E-form and accessible Online. The present study is an outcome of an M.Phil research work carried by the authors. Data for the study were collected through a specially designed questionnaire administered manually and electronically. The collected data was scrupulously analyzed, organized, validated and then used for the development of a web enabled directory. The directory aims to provide at one stop all the possible information related to library and information science faculties in the country.

link.heading: Problems and Prospects of Reading Habits of Early Teenagers
link.authorDes: C/o. Biswnath Mandal, Village Sultanpur, P.O. Bowai, District Bhrdwan, 713 423, (WB), E-mail: mandalpsm@gmaii.com.
link.abstract: Reading is primarily an intellectual activity and reading habit is a sort of attribute of human beings. Like other habits, the reading habit in an individual develops during the course of time. This paper discusses what is reading habit, objective of reading habits and the cause of the lack of reading habits.
link.keywords: Reading habits, Function of reading habits, Cause of the lack of the reading habit, Suggestion for developing reading habits.

Towards an Integrated Rural Development Information System in India
link.authors: Rawtani DR M R1, Associate Professor and Head, Ahuja JPS2, Manager
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur 302 004.2Central Statistical Information Department, NABARD, Head Office, Bandra Kurla Complex, Mumbai 400 101.
link.abstract: This paper examines several ongoing projects that aim to provide IT-based services to rural population in India. These projects are distinguished by the goal of commercial sustainability, which supports scalability and, therefore, more widespread benefits. The analysis highlights the common building blocks required for successful implementation of a Rural Development Information System in India.

link.heading: Library And Information Centres In Maharashtra: A Comparative Study
link.authorDes: DLISC, RTM Nagpur University, Nagpur 440010. shanwaghmare@yahoo.com, shalini_lihitkar@yahoo.com.
link.abstract: Present paper is the outcome of the Research work leading to the award of PhD degree by the Rashtrasant Tukadoji Maharaj Nagpur University, Nagpur. The study surveys the various existing services rendered by the 38 Information Centres in Maharashtra. The study is based on the responses received from the centres and the published literature available through primary, secondary sources and their respective homepages. The majority of institutions have good libraries, which provide a range of library services, maintain special bibliographic databases in their areas of interest. The study also examines the status of library automation and networking of LICs in Maharashtra.
link.keywords: Information Centres, Information Systems, Libraries, Library and Information Centres, Maharashtra..

link.heading: State of Primary School Libraries in Uttar Pradesh: A Study of Azamgarh District
link.authors: Upadhyay DR MP1, Bajpai RP2, Senior Lecturer
link.authorDes: 1SPA Deshbandhu College Library (Evening), Kalkaji, New Delhi 110 019, E-mail: Upadhayay.mangala@yahoo.com2Department of Library & Information Science, MGCGV Chitrakoot, Satna, Madhya Pradesh. E-mail: rpbajpaimgcgv@gmail.com
link.abstract: Even after 63 years of independence the condition of primary school libraries in the country remains highly neglected. Primary schools in city suburbs and rural areas are running without any libraries. The situation of primary school libraries in Uttar Pradesh is among the worst in the country. There is no consistency in the growth and development of primary school libraries in Uttar Pradesh. This shows that the State Education Department has not given due importance and priority to the development of libraries at primary school level. The study emphasizes the role of libraries in primary school education and highlights the problems faced by school libraries. The study highlights the recommendations and/or suggestions contained in reports of different Committees, Commissions, Working Groups, Seminars in this regard, particularly in primary school libraries. This study investigates existing state of primary school libraries in Uttar Pradesh with reference to District Azamgarh by using the questionnaire method and finds out the existing state of collection, analyses problems using tables, and finally ends with valuable suggestions. The study shows that proper library policy, book selection methods and library hours are not followed in primary schools selected for the study. In primary schools, usually some teachers are entrusted with the additional duties of a librarian. Under these circumstances, almost all the primary school libraries fail to develop good reading habits among children. The study concludes that the purpose of primary school libraries is identical with the purpose of the primary school education, and this realization needs yet to be understood in our country.

link.heading: Library 2.0: are Shillong Libraries Ready for It?
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, NEHU, Shillong-22, Meghalaya. E-mail:jiarlikhongtim@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: This paper discusses about Library 2.0. In Library 2.0 users’ participation is a must where the users can participate in designing of the library services. They can give their feedback and suggestions for the improvement of the library as a whole. It also discusses the situation of the libraries here in Shillong whether they are ready to become a Library 2.0 or not.
link.keywords: Library, Library 2.0, Web 2.0, Library Services, Library Users, Users Participation.

link.heading: The Digital Library: Its Future Has Arrived
link.authors: Suryakant DR1, Chief Librarian, Singh O S Shekhar2, Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Sampurnanand Sanskrit University, Varanasi 221 001, Uttar Pradesh.2Navodaya Vidyalaya, Mewat (Old Gurgaon) 122 108, Haryana.
link.abstract: The article discusses the concept of digital library, its need, objectives and advantages as compared to traditional library system in e-learning environment. Also highlights the role, limitations, use of digital resources information in the present scenario.

link.authors: Vashishth C P, Editor, Library Herald
link.abstract: D Jegat Ishwari: Raja Ravi Varma - Oleographs Catalogue. Published by Shri Parsuraman., 21/11, Bharathiyar Street, Metha Nagar, Aminjikarai, Chennai 600 029. ISBN: 978-81-910026-1-4. Rs. 2480/- (55 US$ Approx.) 11"×8.5", 149 colour and 3 black and white illustrations of 264 pages.

link.heading: School Library of Future
link.authorDes: Delhi Library Association, Naraina Vihar, Delhi-110028.
link.abstract: In view of recent ‘Right to Education’ Act passed by the Indian Parliament, it is all the more important to have a proper ‘Role and Goal’ assigned to School Library in new ICT enabled environment. They will have to be treated as priority item in the scheme of things. Necessary norms, guidelines and standards for their day today running on modern lines will have to be developed at a proper forum of school librarians to make them meaningful and indispensable component in scheme of things. The status, pay scales, emoluments and service conditions will have to be matched with their teaching colleagues in the institution. Library collections, operations and services need to be comparable with their counter parts in other developed countries to allow exchange with other schools and free movement of pupil from one school to an other whether in India or abroad. Concludes with a Road map for libraries to follow.

link.heading: Collaboration in Research Publications in Library and Information Science
link.authors: Dr Jeevan V K J, Deputy Librarian
link.authorDes: Indira Gandhi National Open University, Maidan Garhi, New Delhi, 110 068, E-mail: vkjj@rediffmail.com.
link.abstract: This paper reports the extent of collaboration in research publications in library and information science based on the papers published in two successive years in the proceedings of conferences of CALIBER, the annual conference organized by INFLIBNET Centre in 2003 and 2004, the conference of Indian Library Association (ILA) during the same years and the conference of Society for Information Science (SIS) in 2003 and 2004. The study also estimated the same for two consecutive volumes of journals, volume 22, issues 1–6 for 2002 and volume 23, issues 1–6 for 2003 of DESIDOC Bulletin of Information Technology and volume 47, issues 1–4 for 2002 and volume 48, issues 1–4 for 2003 of IASLIC Bulletin. The data collected is presented in tabular format with results and discussion.

link.heading: Insights into the Library: Professional Competencies, Responsibilities and Interpersonal Skills of Today's Librarians
link.authors: Md. Rahman Ziaur1, Assistant Professor, Nausheen Sabahat2, Lecturer
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library Science, Assam University, Silchar, 788 011, Assam, India, E-mail: ziaurnbu@gmail.com.2Department of Library and Information Science, North Bengal University, Raja Rammohunpur, Darjeeling, 734 013, West Bengal, India, E-mail: sabahat0802@yahoo.co.in.
link.abstract: To help manage the uncertainty has become an enduring aspect of the today's professional environment. In librarianship and information services we are going through a radical redefinition of the task and nature of work where the interpersonal relations, the challenges, the conflicts, and strains that are involved require for good peer relationship. This paper is aimed at examination of generic human aspects of library and information work in this conjecture. The paper focuses on to explore the role of individuals to interact effectively with each other to bring collegiality in work place. It deals briefly the behavioral competencies, the core professional competencies and the interpersonal skills of the workers specially the librarians. The paper briefly mentions the library curricula and the workplace etiquette for healthy work place environment in the library.
link.keywords: Behavioral Competencies, Core Competencies, Library School Curricula, Interpersonal Skills, Workplace Etiquette, Management Fad.

link.heading: Comparison of Online Information Providers’ Relevance: Scientific Publishers and Information Vendors
link.authors: Zandian Fatemeh1, Assistant Professor, Dr Riahinia Nosrat2, Associated Professor
link.authorDes: 1LIS, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran2LIS, Tarbiat Moallem University, Tehran, Iran, E-mail: Sara_purriahi@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Originality: Online services are also exposed to users’ daily evaluation. Online information providers could be grouped into two categories: information vendors and scientific publishers. Possible differences between information vendors and scientific publishers are investigated, while their relevance is major consideration.
link.keywords: Information providers, Scientific publishers, relevance, false drop, information retrieval.

link.heading: User Satisfaction in Public Libraries of Raipur City: A Survey
link.authors: Dr Verma Maya1, Lecturer, Patel Santoshi2, M.Phil. Student
link.authorDes: 1SoS in Library & Information Science, Pt. Ravishankar Shukla University, Raipur (CG).2SoS in Library & Information Science, Pt. Ravishankar Shukla University, Raipur (CG).
link.abstract: Public library can act as catalyst to socio-economic changes as it provides lifelong means of self-education. It also functions as an alternative to formal education, keeping users well informed and supplying a food exercise. The present study examines the finding of a survey of users of public library in Raipur City (C.G.). It identified the demographic characteristics of the users of the public libraries. This study demonstrates and elaborates the types of sources used in public library and the library location is one of the factors of public library uses.

link.heading: Public Libraries In Jammu & Kashmir State: An Overview
link.authorDes: PG Department of Library & Information Science, University of Jammu, Jammu, (J&K), 180 006, India, E-mail: dhar_meghna@rediffmail.com.
link.abstract: Starting with the historical background of education in J&K state, the article gives an overview of growth, development, functions and services of Public Libraries in J&K state covering both pre and post-independence period. Also highlights the current scenario of public libraries in the state.

link.heading: Job Satisfaction and Organizational Commitment of Academic Librarians in Nigerian Universities
link.authors: Owolabi K A, Salaam M O
link.authorDes: Nimbe Adedipe Library, University of Agriculture, Abeokuta, PMB, 2240, Abeokuta, Ogun State, Nigeria, E-mail: yomiowolabi2000@yahoo.com and queensalaam51@yahoo.com.
link.abstract: The study examines job satisfaction and organizational commitment of academic librarians in Nigerian Universities. Stratified random technique was used to select eighty academic librarians from seven universities in the country. Questionnaires were used as the main instrument for gathering of data. The finding revealed that majority of the academic librarians were satisfied with their jobs, that attractive salary and wages were the major factors that influence job satisfaction and also that age is the major determinant of organization commitment. Recommendation was made which include the need for library management to provide good working environment for academic librarians and also the need for special salary and wages for them in all the universities in the country.

link.heading: MCB Group Acquires ASLIB
Poor Reading Culture: A Barrier to Students Patronage of Selected Secondary School Libraries in ADO Local Government Area of Ekiti state, Nigeria
link.authorDes: University of Ado, Ekiti, Nigeria.
link.abstract: The paper examines poor reading culture: A barrier to students patronage of Selected Secondary School Libraries in Ado Ekiti Local Government Area of Ekiti State. The design for the study is descriptive survey which utilizes questionnaire to collect data. Oral interview was also conducted. Tables and simple percentages were adopted in the data analysis. Results of the analysis show that computer and other media, harsh economic reality, societal demand for materialism, inadequate library materials among others are causes of poor reading culture of students in secondary schools. It also reveals that materials in secondary school libraries are not organized, inadequate, not relevant, school librarians not readily available among others constitute the reasons for poor patronage of secondary schools libraries. Concludes by giving recommendations towards the improvement of reading culture of secondary school students and the enhancement of the patronage of their school libraries.

link.heading: Role of Academic Law Libraries with Special Reference to NALSAR (National Academy of Legal Studies and Research) University of Law Library, Hyderabad
link.authorDes: NALSAR University of Law, Hyderabad, 500 078.
link.abstract: Deliberates academic law libraries’ role which were set up under autonomous national law universities during the past two decades. Discusses integrated legal curriculum prescribed in the national law universities. Explains NALSAR University Library – its collection (print as well as electronic) and special features like use of software, various electronic databases, RFID technology and other facilities. Proposes need, objectives and advantages of Lawnet. Concludes that academic law libraries must provide quality library services to teachers and students, and also reference service in real time environment as well as develop faith in co-creation of library facilities.

link.heading: Iranian Academic Library Buildings: A Study Of Library Facilities And Status
link.abstract: Academic library buildings should be built basically according to the academic library building standards and their especial roles in the university curricula. The study investigates the suitability of the facilities and status of the Iranian academic library buildings. Therefore, based on the available standards, the Iranian academic library building facilities were examined through five-point evaluative criteria. Every criterion consisted of some sub-criteria, in which a total of 33 subcriteria were identified for evaluation of academic library building facilities. The study population was all academic universities in Tehran, in which 7 state universities were sampled randomly. Every criterion had unique sub-criteria, thus for each criterion a specific score was assigned, for example, the interior design condition criterion had 13 sub-criteria, therefore it had 13 scores. Other criteria had 4,9,3 and 4 sub-criteria, respectively. All library buildings were evaluated based on the total scores they gained of the total criteria. According to the study, library buildings of the University of Tehran and Tarbiat Moallem University had the best and the worst status respectively.

link.heading: Apartment Libraries: A Proposal
link.authors: Dr Sornam S Ally*, Associate Professor & Head, Chandru P**, Alumnus, Franklin J***, Librarian
link.authorDes: *Department of Library and Information Science, Bishop Heber College (Autonomous), Tiruchirappalli, 620 017.**Department of Library and Information Science, Bishop Heber College(Autonomous), Tiruchirappalli, 620 017.***Self-financing Section, Bishop Heber College (Autonomous), Tiruchirappalli, 620 017.
link.abstract: Apartment house is a building containing more than one dwelling unit, each designed for housekeeping. Most of the apartments have facilities like lift, community hall, parking lots, dish antenna, cable connection, gym, swimming pool, walking space, garden, water and electricity supply, but not library. The apartment builders never consider the provision of library while planning to build apartment. Hence, a study has been organized to collect opinion about the provision of library in the apartments. Hope, this article will bring an awareness about library in the apartments to both builders and residents of apartments.

link.heading: Use of Rare Materials in Select Libraries in Karnataka: A Study
link.authors: Dr Sarasvathy P.*, Senior Assistant Librarian, Giddaiah D.**, Assistant Librarian, A Selvaraja***, Junior Research Scholar
link.authorDes: *University Library, Mysore University, Mysore, E-mail: sarapull@rediffmail.com.**University Library, Mysore University, Mysore.***DOS in Library and Information Science, Mysore, University, Mysore, E-mail: selvaraja@yahoomail.com.
link.abstract: Karnataka is rich in terms of arts and cultural heritage resources (including manuscripts, works of arts and artifacts), it is therefore, important to preserve rare materials to accesses to users more effectively. The present study revealed that there are more than 80000 rare materials in 9 libraries covered under study, the study shows different category of users like students, scholars, writers etc.Further, the study covered institution wise rare book collection, types of rare documents available, the total number of users of the institutions covered under the study and the number of users with reference to rare materials and the average number of users of rare materials per day are investigated and on this basis the findings and suggestions drawn.This paper would be stimulant for further research on the need of digital preservation of rare materials, such as palm leaves, manuscripts, out of print books and so on.

link.heading: Evaluation of Websites Used By Social Scientists of North East India
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, North Eastern Hill University(NEHU), Shillong-739022, Meghalaya, E-mail: bikitariang@gmail.com; bikilaloo@rediffmail.com.
link.abstract: Social Science researchers including faculty and research scholars in two universities of North East India were asked to list their most used websites for the purpose of this study. The websites were then evaluated to find out the quality of their design and content. It was found that websites produced from North East India and relating to the Social Sciences were well designed and contained relevant and up-to-date information.
link.keywords: Social Science, Researchers, North East India, Evaluation, Websites.

link.heading: Use of Web Resources by the Students of Zakir Hussain College of Engineering and Technology, AMU Aligarh
link.authors: Haridasan Sudharma*, Associate Professor, Khan Musheer Ahmad**, Research Scholar
link.authorDes: *Department of Library and Information Science, AMU, Aligarh, E-mail: sudharma.haridasan@gmail.com.**Department of Library and Information Science, AMU, Aligarh, E-mail: musheerahmadkhan@gmail.com.
link.abstract: Web resources are considered a vital part of human life in the 21st century. It has tremendously changed the way of seeking information. It is today important to learn and know the techniques for searching quick information.The study aims at assessing the use of web resources among the students and faculty of the Zakir Hussain College of Engineering and Technology, AMU, Aligarh. The study reveals that web resources are useful to engineering students and elaborates on the problems faced while accessing and utilizing web resources. The study helps in planning, developing and extending the computer and Internet facilities.This study has a vital significance in redesigning the policy frame work with more emphasis on information technology and providing access to information.The survey helped a great deal in identifying the areas, which need to be looked into and stresses on the importance of providing better internet services to students and faculty members of the Engineering College.

Web 2.0 and Library 2.0: Innovative Technologies for Building Libraries of Tomorrow with Examples of their Applications at the INFLIBNET Centre*
link.authorDes: INFLIBNET Centre, Ahmedabad, Gujarat.
link.abstract: The concept of Library 2.0 is borrowed from that of Web 2.0 and Business 2.0 and follows some of the same underlying philosophies. Library 2.0 encompasses a range of new and contemporary technological tools and techniques that are used for evolving collaborative environment required for Library 2.0. These tools and techniques can broadly be grouped into five categories, i.e. i) Synchronous Communication: Instant messaging; ii) Content Delivery: RSS Feed, HTML Feed, Streaming Media, Podcasting, Vodcasting and SMS Enquiry Services; iii) Collaborative Publishing Tools: Blogs and Wikis; iv) Collaborative Service Platforms: Social Networks, Tagging, Social Bookmarking Services; and v) Hybrid Applications, Programmes and Programming Tools: Mashups, AJAX, API and Toolbar. These tools and techniques are useful for libraries in providing new services and making existing services available in new and interesting ways. Implementation of some of these tools and techniques are likely to improve reputation and standing of libraries in the community. Some of them may successfully attract new patrons to the library, others may help to retain existing members or make libraries even more important as centres of the culture and history of their cities and academic institutions. Some of the new services may remain unused. However, since feedback and public opinion is a vital component of Library 2.0, such services may be abandoned in favour of other services that are better accepted by the users. Some of those changes may be viewed as disruptive, while others may not be feasible or applicable to all libraries. These new services and ongoing changes are likely to make libraries more interesting, more relevant, and better acceptable place.Applications of Library 2.0 has promise to bring revolutionary changes in libraries that are bound to bring about conceptual, cultural and physical changes in libraries to keep pace with the changes in communities and their information seeking behaviour. Applications of Web 2.0 technologies in libraries will result in a meaningful and substantive change in libraries, its collection, services and methods of delivery of services. The library's collection will change, becoming more interactive and fully accessible. The library's services will change, focusing more on the facilitation of information transfer and information literacy rather than providing controlled access to it. The implications of these revolutionary technologies are enormous and are discussed in the paper along with their examples as applied in the INFLIBNET Centre.

link.heading: Web Credibility of Autonomous College Websites in Tamil Nadu: A Study
link.authors: Rao P Nageswara1, Librarian, Kumar A M Narendra2, Babu B Ramesh3, Professor
link.authorDes: 1Society for Electronic Transactions and Security, #21 Mangadu Swamy Street, Nungambakkam, Chennai, 600 034. E-mail: nageswar_p77@rediffmail.com.2Hexaware Technologies Ltd, Ambattur, Chennai, 600058. E-mail: narendrakumar_am@yahoo.co.in.3Department of Information Science, University of Madras, Chepauk, Chennai, 600005. E-mail: beeraka_r@yahoo.co.uk.
link.abstract: The influence of ICT in developing countries makes more demand for web based and reliable information. Many users’ studies confirm that, being able to trust the information on a site is very important in deciding to visit a web site. Application of ICT and web hosting in academic environment has increased gradually in the recent decades. This paper aims to study and analyse the various aspects of the credibility of autonomous college web sites in Tamil Nadu. The analysis of the data represents the extent and the level of credibility possessed by the autonomous colleges in Tamil Nadu.

link.heading: Evaluation of the Teaching and the Effect of Library Use Course at the Federal College of Education, Abeokuta, Nigeria
link.authors: Ajegbomogun Fredrick Olatunji, Readers’ Services Librarian
link.authorDes: Nimbe Adedipe Library, University of Agriculture, Abeokuta. E-mail: Nigeria.ajegbomo@yahoo.com.
link.abstract: This paper evaluates the teaching and effect of library use course at the Federal College of Education, Abeokuta, Nigeria. Questionnaire method was used to obtain data in the five (5) schools in the college. Out of 550 copies of questionnaires sent out to students, 540 were returned giving a response rate of 98% and 100% for librarians. The result showed that professional librarian give adequate instructions to users despite limited facilities.Of the user survey on the library use course and its relevance to their course of study showed that student have adequate knowledge of use of library; and the use of OPAC and CD-ROM facilities improved their reading habit, but are lacking in the area of internet use. This indicates that the use of the library as a course has positive and meaningful impacts on the students. The study recommends networking the operational system of the library with online services and internet connectivity in order to enhancing teaching of the library use course.

link.heading: Use of the Libraries of Colleges of Education in Punjab
link.authorDes: Guru Gobind Singh Khalsa College for Women, Jhar Sahib (Ludhiana)-Punjab. E-mail: nirmal02@yahoo.co.in.
link.abstract: This paper is based on the results of a study carried out to ascertain the use of the libraries of colleges of education by the students of M.Ed. course in Punjab. A survey was conducted through a questionnaire to know the opinion of 144 students of 15 colleges about their libraries. Responses on various facets like, users’ frequency of visit to libraries, purpose of visit, awareness about library services, use of documents and services, awareness about use of computers, satisfaction with resources and services etc. are discussed. Survey revealed that most of the users were visiting libraries frequently for research work. Majority of the users were not familiar with referral, inter-library loan and reservation services. On the basis of this study various suggestions have been made to improve library services of these colleges.

link.heading: Information and Communication Technology (ICT) Literacy among the Staff of Banaras Hindu University Library System: A Case Study
link.authors: Singh Rajesh Kumar, Assistant Librarian (Professional Junior), Agarwal Anil, Assistant Librarian (Professional Junior), Lal Jawahar, Assistant Librarian (Professional Junior)
link.authorDes: Central Library, BHU, Varanasi, 221 005.
link.abstract: Indian University Libraries are now focusing their attention on the inevitable impact of ICT on their operations, in an effort to keep pace with developments in education, information and communication technology around the world. This study is a part of those worldwide developments, in which it tries to reveal the state of ICT literacy among staff of Banaras Hindu University Library System ranging from professionals, semiprofessionals and non-professionals.In this study questionnaire method is followed. At present there are 41 professional, 88 semi professional and 67 non professional staff working in BHU Library system. Out of 41 professional staff, 22 (53.65%) staff are ICT literate and only 19 (46.34%) staff are ICT illiterate. Out of 88 semi professional staff, only 34 (38.63%) staff are ICT literate and 54 (61.36%) are ICT illiterate and out of 57 non professional staff, only 20 (28.86%) staff are ICT literate and 47 (70.14%) staff are illiterate.The conclusion of the case study is that Professional, semi professional and non professional staff of BHU library system should acquire an enhanced level of ICT literacy: Both training and adequate ICT infrastructure.

link.heading: Automating Islamia College of Science and Commerce Library, Srinagar (India) Using SOUL Software
link.authors: Bhat Mohammad Hanief, Senior Librarian/In charge automation
link.authorDes: ICSC, Srinagar (J&K), India-190002. E-mail: mhanief30@yahoo.co.in.
link.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to share the experience of automating a college library in one of the smallest states of India having limited staff and resources. The study is based on the experience of the Islamia College of Science and Commerce, Srinagar library in implementing automation with the use of CDS/ISIS and SOUL software. The case study will be useful for libraries planning automation in the country having limited staff and finances. It shows that automation could be initiated with limited infrastructure and staff provided the staff is enthusiastic.
link.keywords: Automation, College Library, Libraries, India, SOUL, CDS/ISIS, Jammu & Kashmir.

link.heading: Forthcoming Conferences/Workshops/Seminars/Extension Lectures
Delhi Library Association: Report on the Activities During 2008 – 2009
Income & Expenditure Account for the Year Ended 31st March, 2009
Use of Electronic Resources in Learning: Some Constraints
link.authorDes: Delhi Library Association.
link.abstract: Discusses the impact of e-resources on learning and scholarship. Points at the new role of LICs in new technology environment. Benefits apart it brings out the bad effects of reading computer screens for long and the problems of safe disposal of e-infrastructure, gazettes and peripherals. Concludes that it a necessary evil and we have to live with it.
link.keywords: Impact of Internet, e-learning, e-Journals, E-waste.

link.heading: Scholarly Engineering Journals in Iran: From Readers to Authors
link.authors: Zandian Fatemeh1, Ph D., Assistant Professor of LIS, Riahinia Nosrat2, Ph D., Associate Professor of LIS
link.authorDes: 1Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran.2Tarbiat Moallem University, Tehran, Iran. E-mail: sara_purriahi@yahoo.com.
link.keywords: Scholarly Engineering Journals, Publication Status, Online Access, Advisory Boards.

link.heading: Development of Public Libraries in Goa
link.authors: Satpute B B, Senior Assistant Librarian
link.authorDes: Goa Engineering College, Farmagudi - Ponda - Goa. E-mail: bbsatpute@yahoo.co.in.
link.abstract: Presents an exhaustive picture of movement for library legislation in Goa State. Enumerates the advantages and disadvantages of Goa Public Libraries Act. Describes the intricacies of Goa Public Libraries Act, its impact on development of Public Libraries. Highlights the need for Directorate of Public Libraries and Director of libraries. Highlights the need of maximum support from Government. Highlights the necessity of establishment and spreading a network of rural public libraries in each and every village to take knowledge to the doorstep of the rural community to educate them. Highlights the necessity of public libraries as a potential instrument of smoother and faster development of Goa State. Highlights the necessity of the provision for strong and efficient administrative set up to build and maintain public library services of high order to spread network of village libraries in Goa State. Brings out the importance of library facility as the medium for sustaining the increasing rate of literacy in Goa.
link.keywords: Public Libraries, Library Legislation, Goa Public Libraries Act, State Library, Central Library, Village Libraries.

link.heading: Wipo Treaties on IPR
link.authors: Gadkari Manjusha1, Librarian, Ahirwade Mangala2, PhD., Lecturer
link.authorDes: 1Bhiwapur Mahavidyalay, Bhiwapur.2Department of Library and Information Science, RTM Nagpur University, Nagpur.
link.abstract: The present paper discusses the WIPO Treaties on intellectual property rights. World Intellectual Property Organization is an International treaty making body. It administers total 24 treaties on intellectual property rights, which are working for various purposes. These treaties are divided into three categories viz. IP Protection, Global Protection System and Classification. The present paper covers a brief introduction about each treaty. It also focuses on the number of participating countries in each treaty and lists the treaties in which India is a contracting party.

link.heading: Symptoms and Strategies of Technostress among the Students of SNCET College Library: A Study
link.authors: Sangeetha K1, Assistant Librarian, Kumar K Vijaya2, Chief Librarian, Nithyanandham K3, Special Officer
link.authorDes: 1Madras School of Economics, Chennai, 600 025.2Sri Nandhanam College of Engineering, Thriupattur, Vellore District, Taminadu, 635601.3University of Library, Anna University, Chennai, 600 025.
link.abstract: Studying the impact of technostress among the students is an interesting area. The students agreed that computers were an important part of daily life and they agreed to learn more about them and gain competency to use them. This research particularly highlights the symptoms of technostress faced by them. The students viewed their suggestions and measures that they would take in daily routine to overcome technostress. Thus this research is undertaken in view to minimize technostress among the students who use the library.
link.keywords: Technostress-Symptoms, Technostress-Strategies, Technostress-Studies, Computerphobia.

link.heading: Measuring Impact of Web Sources in ILA Conference Proceedings: A Citation Analysis
link.authors: Chikate R V1, Junior Library Assistant, Patil S K2, PhD, Librarian & Head
link.authorDes: 1Jayakar Library, University of Pune.2Department of Library & Information Science, University of Pune. E-mail: skpatil@univpune.ernet.in.
link.abstract: Citation analysis of 790 citations from 94 papers published in 48th ILA Conference proceedings, shows that journals are most cited form of communication amongst the Library and Information Science discipline. The form of literature “Journal and Websites” are the most cited publications. This study confirms about the impermanence of web citations. One of the most compelling results of this study is confirmation that impact of web citations (24%) are relatively in proceedings papers. Web sites are also most preferred source of getting information in Library and Information Science professionals. The Number of Websites cited by the authors were second in highest number of web citations in these groups of papers are a surprising result.
link.keywords: Bibliometrics, Citation analysis.

link.heading: Proceedings of the First National Conference on Financial Management of Library and Information Centres (LICs) in e-Environment
Role of School Libraries in Quality Education*
Workshop on Soul 2.0 Version
Libraries’ Role in National Development
link.authorDes: 28-B, Pocket ‘A’ MIG Flats, Ashok Vihar Phase III, Delhi, 110052. E-mail: cpv_36@yahoo.co.in.
link.abstract: National Development itself includes whole array of Human Activities be they social, economic, commercial. industrial, educational, professional, political, cultural, and others. Out of the three Ms of Money, Material, and Man, the development and harnessing of manpower i.e.. Human Resources is most crucial as they are the driving force behind any activity. As such their all round development has been in the focus of the Governments of the day globally. To achieve this goal the governments at all level create necessary infrastructure by way of schools, colleges, universities, research laboratories and support them with necessary Library and Information support centers equipped with up-to-date information resources in different kinds and types of medias such as print, digital, electronic with 24x7 Internet connectivity with the required bandwidth. For example UGC Infonet Digital Library Consortium is facilitating 159 universities to have access to 5584 full text corejournals in different subject fields through 19 website besides giving bibliographic access to 9 other websites. In order to assess the impact of LIes their resources, their services; their personnel-number-level of education and training - skill competencies, depth of subject knowledge - ease in handling different subject databases - familiarity with major search engines - work culture - user friendliness need to be looked into.

link.heading: Developing Reading Habits and Skills in Schools
