link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Ambrose Alli University, Ekpoma - Nigeria.
link.abstract: The teacher-librarian plays a leading role in the learning process - a process that emphasizes inquiry-discovery methods. A clear point that has emerged from this method is that students must necessarily develop a love for voluntary reading cultivating in a reading culture. It is argued in this paper that the teacher-librarian is in a good vantage position to help students to develop reading habits and skills that will promote a reading culture. The processes for developing such habits and skills are also discussed.

link.heading: Information Seeking Behaviour of Teachers and Students in Selected Schools
link.authors: Rani Poonam1, Library, Jeevan V K J2, Deputy Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Delhi College of Arts & Commerce, Netaji Nagar, New Delhi, 110 022. E-mail: poonammandar@yahoo.com.2Indira Gandhi National Open University, Maidan Garhi, New Delhi, 110068. E-mail: vkjj@rediffmail.com.
link.abstract: The study attempts to gather the information seeking habits and behaviour of teachers and students in schools, to identify the information sources used by teachers and students and to ascertain the problems faced in using the school library. The questionnaire survey method used in the study reveals that informal channels are more frequently used for information gathering. Books are used more than other types of information resources, both by teachers and students. Journals are preferred for formal source of information while preparing course/teaching materials. The study focuses on how teachers and students utilize the various resources available in the library for enabling the teaching learning process. The findings of the survey are summarized and implications for libraries are discussed.

link.heading: Students’ Use of Various Information Sources and Need for Information Literacy Education in Kurukshetra University*
link.authors: Dr Joshi Manoj K, Reader, Dr Sharma Sanjeev, Lecturer
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, 136 119.
link.abstract: Describes a questionnaire-based survey of first year Postgraduate students in four departments of the university, to know their need for Information Literacy education. The students most frequently needed information for general subject study (46.8%). More than 95% needed information every week. The library (74.3%) and teachers (55%) were the main sources used for this purpose. Students needed assistance for document search (75.5%), document use (79.6%) and Internet use (70.2%). Their self-searching efforts yielded very low success rate for both printed and Internet resources. 75.3% cited the documents they used for assignment preparation, and 77.8% were able to use MS-Word. The present provisions are insufficient and a full course on IL should be introduced.

link.heading: Making Sense of the Retrieval Effectiveness of Web Search Engines
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, North Eastern Hill University, Umshing, Mawlai, Shillong - 739022, Meghalaya. E-mail: bikitariang@gmail.com.
link.abstract: This is a review of the literature covering the retrieval effectiveness of Internet Search Engines. Literature is reviewed under appropriate headings and subheadings and includes mostly literature published from the 1990s onwards. The sources consulted for the purpose of this literature review were mostly journals though relevant websites were also accessed. The more used journals were Information Today and JASIS.
link.keywords: Internet, Search Engines, Retrieval Effectiveness, Evaluation, Information Retrieval, Queries, Searchers.

link.heading: A 2003–2007 Citation Analysis of Library Herald
link.authors: Dr Riahinia Nosrat, Associate Professor of Library and Information Science
link.authorDes: Tarbiat Moalem University, Tehran, Iran. E-mail: Sara-purriahi@yahoo.com.
link.abstract: Citation analysis of papers published in Library Herald in a five-year span is presented here. Citation analysis is discussed particularly as a means of assisting researchers in clarifying formal communication patterns among papers of Library Herald, a quarterly journal of Delhi Library Association. As a means of studying formal communication processes, Library and Information Science researchers have used journal citation analysis in a number of ways to discover new knowledge related to the intellectual structure of the field. The study represents a new method of citation analysis, that is studying only sole journal citations. In this new method, the researcher seeks to find scientific and intra-discipline communication relations among the papers of Library Herald, being published during a five-year period. For such a goal, the author extracted required data to answer questions like, what was the most interesting topic during the studied period?, who has received the most citations and for which topic and what is the journal's current dominant scope? Is the journal welcomed by international contributors, or it has just dealt with local interests?The finding shows that among 130 examined materials we had a mean of 26 materials for each year. The journal has published 120 original papers during five years. 88% of contributors were from India. The journal had only 16 international contributions during the course of five years. As a scientific journal, the author thinks, Library Herald is a prestigious journal in the field of LIS which is worth to be subscribed by university libraries. Few numbers of international contributors have provided an opportunity to young researchers to submit their manuscripts.

link.heading: TORRAS (Maria-Carme) and SAETRE (Tove Pemmer)
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar, 143 005, India. E-mail: satija_mp@yahoo.com.

link.heading: Formcoming Conferences, Workshops/Seminars
Impact of Information Communication Technology in Rural Areas of Uttar Pradesh: Bridging the Divide
link.authors: Shukla Saurabh1,2, Research Scholar, & Assistant Library and Information Officer, Dr. Gautam J N3, Professor
link.authorDes: 1Jiwaji University, Gwalior.2Ministry of Rural Development, New Delhi.3School of Study Library and Information Science, Jiwaji University, Gwalior (MP).
link.abstract: Rural India is at a critical stage. It is large in size; problems are aplenty, the challenges are daunting and thus can present a scary picture to an outsider. But if enabled, it has the potential to transform itself quickly. Technologies exist today to provide telephony and Internet in every village. Today ICT applications permeate all human activities i.e. education, health, agriculture, community development, livelihood activities, entrepreneurship development, governance, emergencies to name a few. Inventions across these sectors lead to propriety-social, economic, cultural and political at large-that entails wider ramifications for human development at large. Such developmental promises of ICT encourage us; firstly to elaborate the role knowledge plays in human development; secondly to explore the critical inter-linkages of ICTs with various facets of rural development. Rural Development is seen as a catalyst for their socio-economic transformation. Development applications of ICTs need to understand and build on the patterns of communication behaviour established within target beneficiary communities-offering new opportunities and supplementing communication choices where this is possible and appropriate, but also recognising the behavioural patterns and preferences of the communities within which new opportunities are made available. Successful initiatives in this area need to be “people-” rather than “technology-centred”.

link.heading: Community Information Services in Bangladesh: A case study on Community Information Centre (CIC)
link.authors: Islam Md. Anwarul, Lecturer, Dr Mezbah-Ul-Islam Muhammad, Associate Professor
link.authorDes: Information Science & Library Management, University of Dhaka, Dhaka 1000. E-mail: anwar_81du@yahoo.com.au, mezbah2000@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Information is power and a driving force for all the activities in the society. Information only has a value when it becomes accessible. Community needs information to make the best use of resources available to them and get direct or indirect help in solving their day to day problems. In Bangladesh, majority of population lives in villages. It is experienced that many of government programmes and services do not reach to common people who is living in villages. Sometimes, community people get information through traditional library system. But rural communities do not get the ICT facilities due to absence of ICT features in the traditional library system. This study focuses the problems associated with the provision of community information services through public library and need the establishment of ICT based community information centre. An attempt has been made to assess how the community information Centres are giving modern information facilities and explores how CIC (Community Information Centre) can be strap up to promote development of rural communities in Bangladesh. It believes that establishment of CIC will make community people life easier to enter information arena through ICT and ensure overall development of Bangladesh. The findings also advocate to make a sound coordination with CIC and rural libraries and suggests some effective measures for the improvement of community information services in Bangladesh.

link.heading: Information Needs and Search Strategies of the Co-Ed College Students in Shillong: A Case Study
link.authors: Khongtim Jiarlimon, Lecturer, Marbaniang Ridalak, Student
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, North Eastern Hill University (NEHU), Permanent Campus, Shillong, 793 022, Meghalaya, India. E-mail: jiarlikhongtim@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: This study discusses the information needs and search strategies of the co-ed college students in Shillong. It covers the different sources of information used by them and it also tries to bring out the problems they face during the search attempt for information. In this study we also tried to find out whether the students are using the library as one of the main sources of information or not, if not then what are the barriers that discourage them from doing so.
link.keywords: Information Needs, Search Strategies, Seeking Behavior, Information Used, Information Search.

link.heading: Physical Science Reference Sources on the Web: An Evaluative Study
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, Kuvempu University, Jnana Sahyadri-577 451, Shimoga, Karnataka, E-mail: sampathbt_2001@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: Access to Internet particularly the Web sources has already influenced and changed the way that the scholars and faculty members used to retrieve and disseminate information for their academic work. This study focuses on how the academics evaluate the web sources and what are the opinions of the academics regarding the authority, coverage, currency, permanence, usefulness of web sources. The results of the present study clearly show that the majority of respondents rated the web reference sources as ‘good’ against the selected evaluation criteria and the respondents are satisfied with the current status of web reference sources. But the majority of respondents felt that the Web sources are not prestigious than the printed sources.
link.keywords: Internet, World Wide Web, Web sources, Physics, Evaluation.

link.heading: Libraries Through the Ages in Delhi: A Historical Perspective
link.authors: Dr Bhatt R K, Reader & Head
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi - 110007.
link.abstract: Military occupations accompanied by pillage and rapine, altered the course of Delhi city's fortunes, both materially and culturally-Captured by Qutubuddin Aibak in 1192 or 1193, Nadir Shah's capture of the city in 1739, followed by its occupation by Ahmad Shah Durrani, the British in 1803, and the destruction which accompanied the uprising of 1857. Unfortunately, the libraries were made victims of plunder and destruction during the invasion of the kings and the ignorance of the Britishers to the cause of library development perhaps is the resultant, the Delhi does not provide much information on the dissemination of information and the role libraries must have played in different settlements. In the post-independence era, Delhi witnessed tremendous changes which has made it a nucleus of educational and library activities converting Delhi into a knowledge hub. The present article is an in-depth attempt which clearly reflects the actual position of libraries of that era and its changing scenario in the present circumstances.

link.heading: Platinum Jubilee Celebrations of ILA
Impact of Information Communication Technology in Rural Areas of Uttar Pradesh: Bridging The Divide
link.authors: Shukla Saurabh1, Saurabh Shukla, Research Scholar, Gautam J N2, Dr., Professor
link.authorDes: 1Jiwaji University, Gwalior, also working as Assistant Library and Information Officer in Ministry of Rural Development, New Delhi.2School of Study Library and Information Science, Jiwaji University, Gwalior (MP).
link.abstract: Rural India is at a critical stage. It is large in size; problems are aplenty, the challenges are daunting and thus can present a scary picture to an outsider. But if enabled, it has the potential to transform itself quickly. Technologies exist today to provide telephony and Internet in every village. Today ICT applications permeate all human activities i.e. education, health, agriculture, community development, livelihood activities, entrepreneurship development, governance, emergencies to name a few. Inventions across these sectors lead to propriety - social, economic, cultural and political at large – that entails wider ramifications for human development at large. Such developmental promises of ICT encourage us; firstly to elaborate the role knowledge plays in human development; secondly to explore the critical inter-linkages of ICTs with various facets of rural development. Rural Development is seen as a catalyst for their socio-economic transformation. Development applications of ICTs need to understand and build on the patterns of communication behaviour established within target beneficiary communities– offering new opportunities and supplementing communication choices where this is possible and appropriate, but also recognising the behavioural patterns and preferences of the communities within which new opportunities are made available. Successful initiatives in this area need to be “people-” rather than “technologycentred”.

link.heading: Public Libraries in Delhi Satisfying Information Needs of Their Users
link.authorDes: 1F-17/12, Sector 8, Rohini, Delhi-110085.2Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi-110007.
link.abstract: The paper is the outcome of M Phil research work. It states basic functions of public libraries as stated in Unesco Public Library Manifesto, 1994 and by Public Library Enquiry Committee (UK). States problems of study and hypotheses. Discusses questionnaire based research methodology and variables for data collection from eight public libraries in Delhi. The review of literature gives user needs and pattern of use of public libraries in advanced countries. Highlights the information needs of public library users and their information gathering habits. The paper discusses major findings and gives suggestions for the improvement of public libraries in terms of collection, services and facilities.

link.heading: AStatistical Analysis of Cited Books Occurring in LIS Postgraduate Dissertations
link.authors: Riahinia Nosrat1, Dr (Mrs) Nosrat Riahinia, Ph D., Associate Professor & Head, Zandian Fateme2, Lecturer of LIS
link.authorDes: 1Department of Educational Technology, Faculty of Psychology and Education Sciences, Tarbiat Moallem University, Tehran (Iran) E-mail: sara_purriahi@yahoo.com2Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran (Iran). E-mail: Zandian@modares.ac.ir
link.abstract: The study examines the relationship between use of print and digital books in English and Farsi language Library and Information Science Dissertations.The measures of postgraduate student use of books in their dissertations were collected from 2001 to 2006, and using Tukey and Levene's HSD tests the data was weighed to test the citation behaviours among universities. The study population was chosen from all universities in Tehran holding high graduate courses in their schedules. Five universities were of this study's population and all dissertations related to LIS students supporting the study. The results supported the high use of print Farsi books versus print and digital English books; the researchers found no Farsi digital book use. For the case of measuring the relation of citations with the age of dissertations, the authors set three categories for dissertations: as the oldest dissertations were 6 years old and newest ones were 1 year old, so the authors divided 6 by 2 and thus 3 categories were generated: 1–2 years old, 3–4 years old, and 5–6 years old. It was found that there is significance between newest dissertations with digital English book use. In terms of interrelation of citation between universities dissertations, no significant correlation emerged.

link.heading: An Examination of The Effectiveness of Personnel Management In Nigerian University Libraries
link.authorDes: Osun State College of Education, Ilesa, Nigeria
link.abstract: The study examines what constitutes effective personnel management and the level of effectiveness of personnel management in academic libraries of two Nigerian Universities. A total of one hundred and thirty (130) staff were used. Questionnaire was the main research instrument for the collection of data. The data were subjected to both descriptive and chi-square analysis. The findings revealed that possession of certificate in Library studies is crucial to effective personnel management. The result also showed that personnel management is effective in Nigeria academic Libraries.

link.heading: Information Use Pattern by the Academicians: A Case Study of NIFT Centres In India
link.authors: Gopalakrishnan S1, Head, Babu B Ramesh2, Professor, Gopalakrishnan S3, Assistant University Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Resource Centre, National Institute of Fashion Technology, NIFT Campus, Rajiv Gandhi Road, Taramani, Chennai 600 113, E-mail: gopusg@yahoo.com2Department of Information Science, University of Madras, Chepauk, Chennai 600 005, E-mail: beerakarameshbabu@gmail.com3Madras Institute of Technology, Anna University, Chrompet, Chennai 600 044, E-mail: gopallong@gmail.com
link.abstract: Information explosion has necessitated the way to seek information in an increasing variety and diversity at different levels, frequency, volume and use. The use of information is so complex that there cannot be a single system to cope up with the task of effective retrieval without assessing their specific needs. This is applicable to every discipline such as social sciences, humanities and science and technology. The information use pattern by the academicians of Fashion Technology has been taken into consideration in this study. In India, education in fashion technology has been given due importance at the national level. The Ministry of Textiles, Government of India constituted a group of seven institutions exclusively for fashion technology related studies. Hence for this purpose, these seven centres of National Institute of Fashion Technology in India situated in different parts of India have been identified for this paper.

link.heading: Library Security Systems: Metamorphism
link.authorDes: 1Central Library, IITB, Powai, Mumbai 400 076, E-mail: skulkarni@iitb.ac.in2SHPT School of Library Science, SNDT Women's University, Mumbai 400 020, E-mail:spowdwal@gmail.com
link.abstract: Libraries are the important institutions for human development and progress. The advancement in knowledge and technology is a vital issue for increasing the patron demands and resources in the libraries. To safeguard these resources for posterity, libraries are adopting various security measures. Unfortunately even after introducing technology driven security solutions, the problem of library security is unresolved. This study analyzes the various dimensions of existing security measures and those which may be adopted in libraries. It also provides the guidelines to handle this most sensitive but still important issue of library management.
link.keywords: Library security, Library security policy, Library security systems..

link.heading: The Impact of Open Access on Scholarly Communication and its Future
link.authors: Kumar Shiv1, Library Assistant, Bansal Jivesh2, Assistant Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Panjab University Library, Chandigarh 160 014, E-mail: shiv1977@yahoo.com2Panjab University Library, Chandigarh 160 014, E-mail: jivesh@pu.ac.in
link.abstract: With the dawn of 21st century, the Open Access (OA) has given a new challenge to scholarly communication and publishing world. Increase in journals’ prices and constant budget for the last two decades have posed a challenge for libraries to maintain their journal subscriptions up to a sufficient level to support their research and development activities. In the meantime, publication of scholarly articles in public domain through Web has provided new ways to scholarly world. Various means of OA have been discussed with supporting business models. Authors have gone through various studies which were made in the recent past to show impact of OA towards its use and citation in scholarship and research. The studies have shown that OA helps to increase the citation impact of journals and is helping to make scientific research more visible and accessible, thus affecting tremendously the scientific communication. Authors hope that OA will have a bright future.

link.heading: The Goa Public Libraries Act, 1995: A Critical Study
link.authorDes: Central Library, Goa College of Engineering, Farmagudi, Ponda, Goa.
link.abstract: Traces history of library legislation in Goa. Discusses the objectives of the Goa Public LibrariesAct and the features of the Act. The author gives his assessment of the Act.

link.heading: Tackling Digital Divide in Kerala and the Possible Role of Libraries
link.authors: Abraham Laila T1, Assistant Librarian, Nikesh N1, Reference Assistant
link.authorDes: 1Mahatma Gandhi University Library, Priyadarshini Hills, Kottayam, Kerala.
link.abstract: Describes the phenomenon of digital divide, challenges and initiatives in bridging the digital divide by giving special emphasis to Kerala state. Various efforts taken in Kerala as part of different national projects and at the state government level are discussed in detail. The article also examines the status of rural libraries in Kerala and their possible role in working as Community Information Centres for the bridging of digital divide among the rural community.
link.keywords: Digital device, Kerala, E-governance, Rural libraries..

link.heading: Managing Conflict in Central University Libraries in Delhi
link.authorDes: South Study Centre Library, School of Open Learning, University of Delhi 110 021.
link.abstract: The present survey is about managing conflict by the Library Professionals in Central University Libraries in Delhi with their superiors, peers and subordinates. It is found that the library professionals of ZHL prefer obliging, while dealing with superiors and integrating is being utilized most by the respondents while dealing with the peers and subordinates. It is concluded that in DULS and JNUL the most adopted method for managing conflict is integrating, while in ZHL the preference of library professionals is obliging.

link.heading: Library in a Network Environment
link.authors: Rajput Prabhat Singh1, Lecturer, Naidu G H S2, Librarian & Head
link.authorDes: 1School of Library & Information Science, Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya, Indore (MP). E-mail: prabhat.t82@gmail.com2School of Library & Information Science, Devi Ahilya Vishwavidyalaya, Indore  (MP). E-mail: head.cl@dauniv.ac.in
link.abstract: Nowadays network services are reality in India for providing better library services. At this concern paper attempts an assessment of successful library networks in the country like INFLIBNET, DELNET, NICNET etc. Explains the definition, need, objectives and uses of networks. Discusses global information networks, computer communication networks and networks development in India. Finally, examines the types of networks and briefly introduces of major library networks.

link.heading: Book Numbers: Indian and Cutter by M P Satija
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi, India. Singhkp_1972@yahoo.co.in: 9818057510; 9968009585

link.heading: Conferences/Sendnars/∼Orkshops/Lectures
Autonomous College Libraries in Chennai: A Survey of Faculty Perception
link.authors: Rao P Nageswara1, Librarian, Babu B. Ramesh2, Professor
link.authorDes: 1Society for Electronic Transactions and Security, # 21, Mangadu Swamy Street, Nungambakkam, Chennai 600 034, E-mail: nageswar_p77@rediffmail.com2Department of Information Science, University of Madras, Chepauk Campus, Chennai 600 005, E-mail: beeraka_r@yahoo.co.uk
link.abstract: This paper presents an overview of autonomous colleges and their libraries in Chennai. The major objectives of the study are to survey the faculty background of the Autonomous Arts and Science Colleges in Chennai, responses on the provision and the use of library services, resources and facilities in their respective colleges and to analyse their satisfaction or otherwise on the library services, resources and facilities provided by these autonomous colleges. For this purpose a total of 375 faculties were taken from 25 autonomous colleges in Chennai. The responses have been analysed and based on their perception, few suggestions were given to improve library services of these colleges.

link.heading: Students and Faculties’ Searching Behaviour and the Internet: Use of Search Engines for Retrieval of Scholarly Information
link.authors: Biradar B S1, Rajashekar G R2, Kumar B T Sampath3
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Kuvempu University, Jnana Sahyadri 577451, Shimoga. E-mail: biradarbs53@rediffmail.com2T.C.S, G.R. Tech Park, K.R. Puram Roam, Bangalore.3Department of Library and Information Science, Kuvempu University, Jnana Sahyadri 577 451, Shimoga. E-mail: sampathbt_2001@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: The article explores on university students’ and teachers’ perceptions regarding their use of search engines for retrieval of scholarly information. Examines the use of search engines, use of popular search engines, factor that influenced on search engines use, use of search strategy for information retrieval and also to know the methods of learning search strategy by students and faculties in the university environment. Result of the study shows that 100% of the students and 97.91% of faculties used search engines for retrieval of information on the Internet. Google and Yahoo received the highest overall ratings. It also reveals that majority of respondents took help from their friends and used help message of search engines to learn the search strategy.

link.heading: The Contribution of Philanthropic Organizations to Collection Development in Nigerian Academic Libraries
link.authors: Oshinaike A B1, Bankole O M1, Oyelude A A2
link.authorDes: 1Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Ago-Iwoye, Ogun State.2Kenneth Dike Library, University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Oyo State.
link.abstract: Discusses the contribution of philanthropic organizations to collection development in libraries in South Western Nigeria. Questionnaires, structured interview, and observation methods were used in gathering the required data. Using random sampling techniques, five tertiary institutions were selected from the seventeen in the Southwest. The study reveals that book donations from philanthropic organization have positive impact on collection development by increasing the volumes of books in their collection. It was also discovered that the major donor to the libraries was Book Aid International and that the books donated sometimes do not cut across all disciplines. Acquisition by purchase is not seriously affected by the donations as the libraries continue to acquire in spite of outside help. It is recommended that the donors in a way involve the receiving or benefiting universities in the selection exercise so as to meet the desired needs of the institutions.

link.heading: Information Environment in Rural India: Impediments to Free Flow of Information
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior 474 009, E-mail: arvindksharma22@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: This article deals with the impediments to the free flow of information in rural areas of Gwalior district of Madhya Pradesh. Total 667 schedules were received back from respondents. Major findings are: 83.05% of respondents prefer to study reading material in Hindi language; money and lack of time are coming in the way of obtaining required information in rural areas; only 4.34% respondents (29 out of 667) are familiar with the Internet in this I T age. While 18.14% of respondents (121 out of 667) are familiar with computer. 241 (36.13%) of respondents are familiar with mobile; 13 (1.94%) respondents have taken the benefit of Internet technology for fulfilling their information need. Majority of respondents 267 (40.02%) have not taken benefits because they have not received information timely.

link.heading: An Evaluation of the Role of University Grants Commission on the Development of College Libraries with Special Reference to Nagpur University Area
Library and Information Support Services for Socio-Economic Development of Bangladesh
link.authors: Roknuzzaman1, Assistant Professor, Munshi M Nasiruddin2, Associate Professor
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Rajshahi, Rajshahi, Bangladesh.. E-mail: mrkzaman@yahoo.com2Department of Information Science & Library Management, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, 1000, Bangladesh. E-mail: ramanasir@yahoo.com
link.abstract: In Bangladesh, there are more than 665 special libraries and information centres working in the field of health, agriculture, rural development, science and technology, education and research, development studies, and other areas of socio-economic development. The study aims at identifying the areas where information can contribute to the socio-economic development process. Explores the availability of socio-economic information system in Bangladesh. Determines the impact of library and information services on socio-economic development on the basis of some selected libraries and information centers of the country. The study reveals that these libraries support socio-economic development process by acquiring information resources, providing library and information services, adapting different programmes, and promoting information activities on socio-economic issues. Finally, an attempt has been made to suggest some effective measures and future directions for further improvement of the condition.

link.heading: Electronic Journals: Impact on Scholarly Communication, User and Library
link.authorDes: 1Panjab University Library, Chandigarh
link.abstract: Electronic journals are increasing day by day. The changes are taking place in infrastructure of libraries due to electronic journals’ related issues. This paper deals with different aspects of electronic journalsand their impact on users, authors, indexing services, scholarly communication, accessibility and libraries. The academics are still in the process of adopting this medium. There is variation in the use of electronic journals from discipline to discipline. Researchers have positive attitude towards electronic journals. Budget allocation for journals has been shifting from print to electronic form, which has necessitated a change in collection development policies of libraries. Thus, the article describes all such aspects of electronic journals.

link.heading: User Education in Networked Environment with special Reference to National Institute of Technology Libraries in India
link.authors: Shrivastava Jitendra1, Assistant Professor, Nandwana H B2, Associate Professor
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Maharani Laxmi Bai Government College of Excellence, Gwalior (Madhya Pradesh) India 474 009, E-mail: jitendra_shrivastava@rediffinail.com.2Department of Library and Information Science, Vardhman Mahaveer Open University, Kota  (Rajasthan), India.
link.abstract: Describes User Education, need and objectives of user education programmes, the networked environment NIT in Libraries. Traces origin, history and development of RECs in India (now named as NITs). States the status of User Education Programmes in NIT Libraries of India. mentions issues and challenges of user education programmes. Recommends that the user education programme should be run on regular basis and must be included in all the courses of studies in all the NITs of India.

link.heading: Evaluation of the Library Software Course Instructions in Tehran Universities and Comparison Between DOS and Windows Based Pars Azarakhsh Library Software
link.authors: Riahinia Nosrat1, Assistant Professor and Head, Azimi Ali2, Student of Medical Library
link.authorDes: 1Department of LIS in Tarbiat Moalem University. E-mail: Sara_purriahi@tahoo.com2Information Science in Iran University of Medical Sciences. E-mail: azimia@gmail.com
link.abstract: This paper studies the condition of Library software instructing in universities of Tehran. For performing the study, a descriptive survey was used and a self-designed questionnaire was prepared for the study. For validity, the questionnaire was referred to some informants to evaluate the items. Then, the questionnaires were distributed through LIS students of Tarbiat Moalem and Shahid Beheshti universities and finally 68 valid questionnaires returned. The findings showed that there is a significant relation between the theoretical instruction of library software and the practical training. It was revealed that the kind of library software affects to the LIS students’ satisfaction. The study concluded that despite the lack of financial resources, LIS departments should acquire some up to date library software for practical training, because the theoretical instruction is insufficient and will cause fostering inept librarians.

link.heading: Information Technology Challenge for University Library Personnel
link.authors: Kaur Manjit1, Assistant Librarian, Singh Sewa2, Professor
link.authorDes: 1Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar.2Department of Library and Information Science, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar.
link.abstract: Discusses the changing culture of university library in the age of information technology and use of internet in solving problems of users to access library resources through networks. With a result, the role of librarians has changed to that of an active communicator and networker of data and information from conventional methods and manual system.

link.heading: Information Seeking Behaviour of Agriculture Scientists working in the Select ICAR Institutions in Delhi, and the Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana: A Study
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi.

link.heading: Special Libraries in the Electronic Environment by S P Singh & Krishan Kumar.
link.authorDes: Delhi University, S-11, Parwana Vihar, Sector-9, Rohini, Delhi-110 085, India

link.heading: Rural Information System Initiatives in India
link.authorDes: Former President of Indian Library Association and Professor of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi.
link.abstract: The paper explores rural information system initiatives in promotion of public library movement in small towns and villages through Raja Rammohun Roy Library Foundation (RRRLF), Rajiv Gandhi Foundation (RGF) and NGOs in setting up rural libraries to facilitate education, recreation and practical information at the door of rural people. Suggests the possible role of RLCRCs, information material for rural masses, linkage with schools in reshaping library service at grassroot level in India.

link.heading: Agricultural Information Communication and Adoption of Innovative Practices: A Review
link.authors: Naga Moses M1, Longchar A Alem W2
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, North Eastern Hill University, Shillong 793 014, Meghalaya, India. E-mail: moseszhaimai@yahoo.co.uk2Department of Library and Information Science, North Eastern Hill University, Shillong 793 014, Meghalaya, India. E-mail: awlongchar@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: Emphasizes that information is a vital resource in every sphere of human activity capable of determining and improving the quality of human life. Stresses that an effective agricultural information communication system is very crucial in successful and meaningful diffusion and adoption of agricultural innovations. Highlights the trends in agricultural information communication and adoption of innovative practices. Suggests that an immediate emphasis can be given on exploring possibilities towards effective information communication on agricultural innovations through appropriate media and format to the rural farmers.

link.heading: Non-Users of Circle Libraries in Chennai: A Survey
link.authors: Babu B Ramesh1, Professor, Kumar S K Asok2, Assistant Librarian, Reddy P Govinda3, Professor
link.authorDes: 1Department of Information Science, University of Madras, Chennai 600 005.2The Tamil Nadu Dr. Ambedkar Law University, Chennai 600 028.3Department of Anthropology, University of Madras, Chennai 600 005.
link.abstract: This paper presents the results of the research conducted at the Department of Library and Information Science, University of Madras sponsored by the University Grants Commission under the Minor Research Projects grants. An overview of Public Libraries in Tamilnadu is outlined. The emergence of Circle Libraries in Chennai established by the Department of Public Libraries, Government of Tamilnadu is presented. Survey the non-users of one of the Circle Libraries of Chennai located at the Adyar, Gandhi Nagar. A total of 112 non-users were surveyed and the reasons for the non-use of the library were analyzed statistically using Chi-square and Cluster Analysis. Users expectations and information requirements are also solicited. Suggestions for the improvement of library services are given.

link.heading: Use of Collection and Services of TIRC of DRDE Gwalior: A Case Study
link.authors: Verma Neerja1, Professor & Head, Tamrakar Rajnish2, Research Scholar, Shrivastava Mridulata3, Officer Incharge Library
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior (MP) 474 009, E-mail: neerja_verma@rediffmail.com2DLIS, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior (MP) 474 009, E-mail: rajtam2003@yahoo.com3Defence R & D Establishment (DRDE), Jhansi Road, Gwalior (MP) 474 002.
link.abstract: Gives a brief overview about the Defence Research & Development Establishment (DRDE), Gwalior and Services of the Technical Information Research Centre (TIRC) of DRDE provided to their users. In this paper an attempt has been made to study the use of collection and services of the TIRC and to find out the gaps of collection and other required services by users. In the end, suggestions and conclusions have also been made for further improvement in the collection and services for the benefits of the users.

link.heading: Medical College Libraries of Punjab: A Study
link.authors: Kaur Amritpal1, Reader, Kaur Navneet2, Consultant
link.authorDes: 1Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar.2National Institute of Panjab Studies, New Delhi.
link.abstract: This paper aims to examine the use of information in the medical college libraries of Punjab related to modern medicine, i.e, Allopathy. Gives brief overview of Medical Science Education in India with special reference to Punjab.

link.heading: Library Management in Electronic Environment.
link.authorDes: Delhi University, S-11, Parwana Vihar, Sector-9, Rohini, Delhi 110 085.

link.heading: Public Library as Rural Community Resource Centre
link.authorDes: Former President of Indian Library Association and Professor of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi.
link.abstract: Brings out the importance of library as self learning centre. Discusses the steps taken by the successive governments so as to bring the books to the door steps of rural people. Describes the empowerment of village panchayat/samiti panchayat/parishad panchayat by the centre through 73rd amendment in the constitution so as to take appropriate decision to provide library and information services to residents of the village. Discusses about the new challenges and new role of public library in view of the ‘open school’/‘open university’ system, which is becoming quite popular in all parts of the country. Examines the sphere of activities to be under taken by rural library community centre. Cites an example of British experience in this regard.

link.heading: Price Rising Trends in Periodicals at DRDE Library, Gwalior: A Case Study
link.authors: Verma Neerja1, Tamrakar Rajnish2, Shrivastava Mridulata3
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior (M P) 474 009, E-mail: neerja_verma@rediffmail.com2DLIS, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior (MP) 474 009, E-mail: rajtam2003@yahoo.com3Defence Research & Development Establishment (DRDE), Jhansi Road, Gwalior 474 002, E-mail: geetam_s@yahoo.co.uk
link.abstract: This paper analyses the price rising trends of 23 foreign and 10 Indian periodicals, acquired by DRDE library, Gwalior during 1997–2006. An attempt has been made to view rising trends in subscription rates of periodicals individually as well as in group (publisher wise). Average growth in price per year has been given in tabular form with the help of graph. Concludes that all periodicals foreign as well as Indian have increased the subscription rates from time to time therefore budget must be increased accordingly and to maintain the collection of periodicals in DRDE, Library, Gwalior.

link.heading: Multimedia and its Elements for Modern Library System
link.authorDes: Netaji Subhash Chandra Institute of Technology, New Delhi.
link.abstract: Multimedia is the integrated collection of text, audio-video animation and graphics to bring the interactive environment. Today's desktop computer is awarded with multimedia software packages. The concept of paperless society is effective with multimedia only. In this article various elements, minimum hardware requirement, software requirement, etc of multimedia have been discussed. Mentions the design, production and distribution of multimedia and importance in today's library i.e. modern paperless.

link.heading: RSS Based Information Services in Libraries: A Study
link.authors: Harinarayana N S1, Senior Lecturer, Kumbar Mallinath2, Reader and Chairman, Pradeep P3, Student
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Mysore, Mysore. E-mail: ns. harinarayana@gmailcom2Department of Library and Information Science, University of Mysore, Mysore. E-mail: mallinathk@yahoo.co.in3Department of Library and Information Science, University of Mysore, Mysore
link.abstract: This article is a study about RSS (Real Simple Syndication) and its application in libraries. RSS is an XML-based format for content distribution. Webmasters create an RSS file containing headlines and description of specific information. The technology is similar in concept to the traditional Current Awareness Service (CAS) and Selective Dissemination of Information Service (SDI) offered by the librarian of yesteryears. Number of RSS feeds available differ significantly from libraries to libraries. This is significant in exploring the various possibilities of RSS in libraries.

link.heading: Changing Role of Information Professionals in Digital Era
link.authorDes: Veeranga Jhalkari Bai Centre for Women's Studies & Development, Bundelkhand University, Jhansi.
link.abstract: The present article is an attempt to explain the impact of information technology on library services in virtual library environment. Points out the concept of virtual library and use of digital resources effectively. Describes the role of information professionals in handling information and technology skills to cope up with the demands of knowledge society.

link.heading: Emerging Trends in Medical Librarianship–Proceedings of Medical Library Association of India-2006: An Analysis
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian (Off.) at Baba Farid University of Health Sciences, College of Nursing, GGS Medical College Hospital Complex, Sadiq Road, Faridkot, India. E-mail: rajeevmanhas@yahoo.com
link.abstract: In this article an attempt has been made to analyse the proceedings of Medical Library Association of India for the purpose to know the role of medical library professionals in the field of organizing and disseminating of health care information.

link.heading: Public Library and Tourism Information: A Congenial Approach
link.authorDes: Central Building Research Institute, Roorkee 247 667, E-mail: cbrilibrary @rediffmail.com
link.abstract: Presents a brief overview of public library system in India. Discusses the role and importance of public library in the field of tourism industry to provide information and to promote domestic tourism in India.

link.heading: Use of Library Manager Free Ware Administrative Software: A Practical Out Look
link.authors: Nikam Khaiser1, Reader in library and information science, kumara Jaya2, Librarian
link.authorDes: 1University of Mysore, Mysore 570 006, E-mail: khaiser.nikam@gmail.com2B N Bahadur Institute of Management Sciences, University of Mysore 570 006, E-mail: jaya_bims@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: The present paper is an attempt to give an overview of the use and application of Library Manager free ware as used in the Sadvidya pre university college library. The paper aims at giving realistic examples taken from various library operations as experienced at the library. It may be observed in the following paragraphs how effective and simple it is to apply this software in a in-house library set up. The software helps a upcoming, new library professional to easily understand and initiate various library operations without much dependency on others. From the screen shots one can understand how the data entry, issue and deposits, report generation and search functions can be carried out. It may be noted that, at present this software has been made commercial. When the authors experimented it was a free ware software.

link.heading: Public Libraries in Tehran (Iran): Conditions and Issues
link.authors: Riahinia Nosrat, Assistant Professor of LIS
link.authorDes: Psychology and Education Faculty, Tarbiat Moalem University, Tehran, Iran. Email: Sara_pourriahi@yahool.com
link.abstract: This article investigates the conditions of public libraries’ in Tehran (Iran), which are managed either by the Municipality or the Iranian Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance. A descriptive survey research was performed using a structured questionnaire and distributed for data gathering. The population of this study consists of public libraries in Tehran which are around 80 in number. Of these, 60 libraries were selected randomly and distributed among these identified sixty libraries. Of these sixty libraries, 38 libraries responded and returned the filled questionnaires. Findings of the survey reveal that these libraries do not have any independent policy. Library managers of these libraries believe that public libraries need more professional manpower to organise effective library services. As of today most of the public library buildings are not suitable for organising library services. At the end, some suggestions are made for improving the prevalent condition of public libraries in Tehran.

link.heading: Management of Library Personnel in the University Libraries of J & K, Punjab, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh and Chandigarh
link.authorDes: Department of Library Science, University of Jammu, Jammu.

link.heading: Emerging Trends in Medical Librarianship - Proceedings of Medical Library Association of India - 2006: An Analysis
link.authorDes: Deputy Librarian (Off) at Baba Farid University of Health Sciences, College of Nursing, GGS Medical College Hospital Complex, Sadiq Raod, Faridkot, India. E-mail: rajeevmanhas@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Health care library professionals increasingly rely on modern information systems to assist health care professionals in providing quality care. This is an age of information and in this it formation-based society, people are more conscious about their health that resultant to increase in demand of health care information. Medical and health science associations are playing key role in organizing conferences and lectures and providing latest information sources in the field of health science. In this article an attempt has been made to do the analysis of proceedings of Medical Library Association c f India for the purpose to know the role of medical library professionals in the field of organizing and disseminating of health care information.

link.heading: Knowledge Society: Implications for the Indian Society
link.authorDes: 342 East End Apartment, New Ashok Nagar, Mayur Vihar, Phase I Extension, New Delhi 110 096.
link.abstract: In a Knowledge Society, knowledge is the powerful resource that would provide the bones and sinews for socio-economic development of a country. While historically all societies have thrived on the basis of knowledge, it is only from the second decade of the 20th century, knowledge has taken the central place in all the developmental process. It is because of the huge investments in knowledge creation and use, through Information and Communication Technology. A new Knowledge Universe is perceived which comprises Knowledge created by R & D, tacit knowledge of individuals and embedded knowledge in natural resources and artifacts.The Indian Society is poised for economic growth with the liberation economic policy of the Government. Economic pundits predict India will emerge as a strong economic power in the next few decades. Despite numerous problems which are threatening the pace of economic growth, the government has established the National Knowledge Commission (NKC) (2005) to create the Knowledge strength for application in the diverse spheres of developmental activities. A knowledge Pentagon is visualized with five focal areas viz., Access, Concepts, Creation, Applications and Services which constitute a Knowledge base. Concrete proposals for E-Governance have been recommended to reengineer the government machinery to be citizen centered.One of the Working Groups of NKC is for Libraries and Information Services. Ten recommendations have been made with 5 special annexures in an elite group of professionals and experts. It is likely that a new class of professionals would be turned out in the next few decades who will manage Library and Information Services in the light of socio-economic development processes suggested by NKC. The Knowledge Society of the 21st century will throw new opportunities and challenges to the library and information professional community.

link.heading: Open Access Journals - A Myth or Reality
link.authorDes: Raman Research Institute, Bangalore; and Education & Training Consultant, Informatics (India) Ltd, New Delhi.
link.abstract: Presents a brief overview of print journals. Defines open access movement and explains the reasons for existence in current scenario. Open access movement deals also with promoting creation of institutional archives and usage of open source software and digitization programmes. The article also highlights the areas of open access journals and to an extent open archives and present limitations of OAI movement.

link.heading: Patents and Patenting in India: Some Aspects
link.authors: Gohel B M, I/c Assistant Librarian
link.authorDes: Bhavnagar University Library & Co-ordinator Bachelor of Library and Information Science PG Centre>, Bhavnagar University, Bhavnagar.
link.abstract: Defines patents and other issues of concerns in the country. States procedure for grant of patents, patents specifications, legislation and administration, examination and publication and rights of patentee with special reference to India.

link.heading: Automate Your Library
link.authorDes: NCERT, Sri Aurobindo Marg, New Delhi 110 016, Email: murtimati@hotmail.com
link.abstract: The article highlights the meaning, need of library automation, and expected approaches for the same. Mentions the parameters for planning to automate the house keeping operations of a library. Deals with one's experience in automating a college library within the required dateline. The experience of automating the house-keeping operation includes acquisition, cataloguing, circulation and serial control section of the library along with stock verification with the help of DCU.

link.heading: Network Information System
link.authorDes: KMV, B Noor B Library
link.abstract: The Libraries of 21st century have to be conceived not merely as the storehouse of knowledge but an effective mechanism to facilitate dissemination of knowledge, promoting information and knowledge sharing while, at the same time, supporting the growth of knowledge of intellectual property. The libraries of 21st century should facilitate the transition of today's literate society to a knowledge-based society of tomorrow. We have to create local area networks, national networks and also to link local and national network of Libraries and Information systems so as to facilitate global access of knowledge sharing. Networking, therefore, is one of the frontal areas of focus for the libraries of 21st century. The article describes the major activities of INFLIBNET with respect to academic and research libraries in the country.

link.heading: Impact of Internet on Library and Information Services
link.authorDes: BLIS Course, (Dr. Zakair Husain Library), Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi 110 025.
link.abstract: This paper discusses about the role of Internet in Library and Information Centres in the context of changing environment. Gives an overview how can the use of Internet help the library staff in providing better library services to the users. Also, explains the different services provided to the users with the assistance of internet.

link.heading: Reading Habits of Rural Under-Graduate Students
link.authors: Kaushik Sanjay K1, Senior Assistant Librarian, Khanchi Jaswant Singh2, Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Maharshi Dayanand University, Rohtak 124 001, email: kaush s@rediffmail.com2Banwari Lal Jindal Suiwala College, Tosham, District, Bhiwani, Haryana
link.abstract: The present study investigates the reading habits of rural undergraduate students through a structured questionnaire. The results indicate that ninety respondents (57.69%) read newspaper daily and fifty-two respondents (33.33%) read newspaper occasionally. A majority of respondents (58.33%) read general magazines, 14.73% respondents read magazines on films, 16.67% respondents read magazines relating to various Competitions. More female under-graduates have been found reading Novels/Poetry/Stories books, whereas more male have been found reading religious and competitive books. The female undergraduate students have been found devoting more time for reading at home (during normal college days as well as during exam days) as compared to male under-graduate students. The use of INTERNET by rural under-graduate students is very low, which is matter of great concern for librarians. Only sixteen respondents out of one hundred fifty six use the INTERNET.

link.heading: Bibliography Usage and Practice: A Study through Tehran's Academic Counselling Centres
link.authors: Riahinia Nosrat1, Head of LIS, Azimi Ali2, Postgraduate student of Medical L&IS
link.authorDes: 1Department, Psychology and Education Faculty, Taribiat Moalem University (TMU), Tehran. E-mail: sara_purriahi@yahoo.com2Management & LIS Faculity, Iran University of Medical Sciences (IUMS), Tehran. E-mail: azimia@gmail.com
link.abstract: Bibliotherapy currently has played an important role in a variety education and counselling areas such as family counselling, social skills development and the curriculum planning for gifted as well as helping children coping with relationships and embarking on career paths. The present survey studies the bibliotherapy usage and practice in Tehran's Academic Counselling Centres and tries to get in on counsellors’ ploys in dealing with bibliotherapy treatment. For that exploration, a descriptive survey performed and for data gathering a questionnaire designed and carried out. The population includes all academic counselling in Tehran, in which 4 centres have been choosen by random as following: (1) Tarbiat Moalem University Counselling Centre; (2) Shahid Beheshti University Counselling Centre; (3) Tehran University Counselling Center and (4) Alzahra University Counsellng Centre. Assessments and analyses were conducted via a self-designed questionnaire. Results of the present study confirmed bibliotherapy usage as an adjunctive method of treatment dealing with social disasters including divorce, family disorders, and low depression, and also suggests that librarians can play an active part in bibliotherapy.

link.heading: KUMAR (PSG), Fundamentals of information science.
link.authors: Prof Kumar Krishan*, Former Dean & Head
link.authorDes: Deptt of Lib & Info Sc, University of Delhi, K-14, Rajouri Garden, New Delhi-110027

link.heading: Awareness and Use of Digital Resources in the Libraries of Isfahan University of Medical Sciences, Iran
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, Isfahan University, Isfahan, Iran. Email: af_asemi@yahoo.com2Library Information Science, Psychology & Education Faculty, Tarbiat, Moalem, Iran. Email: Sara_purriahi@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The present survey investigates the relationships between awareness and use of digital resources among students in Isfahan University of Medical Sciences. To carry out the survey a questionnaire was designed for collecting data. Results indicate that 70% of students are aware of digital resources available in university database, but 69% of them do well to using the resources. 62% are aware of offline databases whereas, only about 19% used them through Central Library (CL) LAN Network. About 70% are aware of online databases accessible via Central Library website and about 53% of respondents have used them as well. 64% are aware of “Central Library Books & Journals Database” whereas more than half of them i.e. 54% have referred to mentioned database. 87.2% of students feel that the available digital resources meet their information needs. Concludely, students aqre less eager to use omine databases, attributed to factors such as infrequent periodic orientation and lack of education on use of offline databases and limited number of terminals connected to the center in CL. Users are facing some problems like low speed connectivity and shortage of inadequate hardware facilities

link.heading: A Study of Serials Management Practice in a selected Nigerian University Library
link.authorDes: University of Ilorian Library, Ilorin, Nigeria.
link.abstract: Serials are the bedrock of research activities. When ill-managed, they cause dissatisfaction and distrust in the users. The study aims to find out the art of serials management practice at University of Ilorin Library, Ilorin, Nigeria. The data was collected through interview of the staff, examination of records and observation of activities serials section. The organization of serials functions was centralized while the access to the shelves was mixed. The materials were acquired by subscription through overseas agents, purchases and gifts. Their preservation is done with the help of binding, exit control and photocopying. The practice generally conforms with serials management reported in literature. However, there is still room for Improvement.

link.heading: Metadata Harvesting Services in India
link.authorDes: 1Shivaji Science College, Congress Nagar, Nagpur. E-mail: hirwade2004@indiatimes.com2Seminary Hills, Nagpur-6 and Contributory Lecturer, Department of Library & Information Science, R.T.M. Nagpur University, Nagpur. E-mail: hirwade2004@indiatimes.com
link.abstract: Today more and more information is created in digital form. One of the key challenges faced by today's information managers is the need to interrelate different sources and types of information with different formats, data structures and description standards. Using metadata to record data about information sources allows an initial assessment of compatibility and provides an avenue for merging information or for exchanging information between systems. Another service has gained momentum nowadays is the Metadata Harvester. Metadata Harvester provides indexes or harvests metadata, from different open access archives and open access journals. This paper describes Metadata, Open Access Initiative Protocol for Metadata, Harvesting (OAI-PMH) and major Metadata Harvesting Services in India.

link.heading: A Study of Internet Usage by Students and Faculties in Kuvempu University
link.authors: Biradar B S1, Reader and Chairman, Rajashekar G R2, Kumar B T SAMPATH§, Lecturer
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Kuvempu University, Jnana Sahyadri 577 451, Shimoga. Email:bs_biradar@yahoo.com2Indian Business Academy (IBA), Kanakapura Road, Tataguni Post, Bangalore.§Department of Library and Information Science, Kuvempu Uni:versity, Jnana Sahyadri 577 451, Shimoga.
link.abstract: The study presents the results of user studies of Internet usage among students and faculties conducted at Kuvempu University. The results focus on the use of Internet, factors influenced on Internet use, amount of time spent on the Internet use, purpose & place of Internet use, methods of learning internet skills and also to know demerits of Internet sources and services. It reveals that majority of faculties (96%) and students (76%) exposed to Internet use. Email is still one of the most popular services because 78.94% of students and 64.58% of faculties used this service for less than 1 hour. While 66.66% of faculties and 52.63% of students used Internet for study/teaching purpose. Students used Internet in the university library (63.15%) followed by commercial centres (42.1%) where as faculties used Internet to some extent in the library (37.50%) followed by office/department (33.33%).

link.heading: Trends in Information Resources and Need for Rethinking in Professionals Preparedness: A Case Study of Indian University Libraries
link.authors: Kumbar BD1, Reader, Hadagali Gururaj S2, Research Scholar
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Karnatak University, Dharwad, Karnataka State. E-mail: bdkumbar@yahoo.com2Department of Library and Information Science, Karnatak University, Dharwad, Karnataka State. E-mail:gururaj_hadagali@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: The emergence of electronic information resources has led to an increased demand on libraries to deliver more in terms of services and products, and to do so faster the enhanced services offered by libraries have raised the expectations of patrons. Technologically sophisticated patrons are frequently knowledgeable about the new resource and their capabilities, often well before a library's staff. The versatility offered by electronic resources may also lead patrons to have unrealistic expectation about what technology can provide. The proliferation of electronic resources demanding professionals to assume greater responsibility far keeping pace with technology. As the library become the provider of information in a variety of formats, it is essential that librarians should know how to use the new technology required to access the information in those new formats particularly when that technology has been available to patrons whom the librarian may very well need to assist. This article is an attempt to explore some of the conceptual and theoretical issues raised by the proliferation of electronic resources and also highlights the importance of Collection Development, Consortia and the Role of Library professionals.

link.heading: Electronic Information Use Among the Faculty
link.authors: Koovakkai DINESHAN1, Lecturer, HANNA NOOR KV2, MLISc student
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Calicut Kerala, India 673 635, E-mail: dineshkoovakkai@yahoo.co.in, dineshank@gmail.com2Department of Library and Information Science, University of Calicut, Kerala, India 673 635.
link.abstract: Electronic information is gaining more and more importance in the academic activities with the drastic change in the pattern of dissemination of knowledge. As teachers in universities play a vital role in providing up to date information with latest technologies, they have to be good users of such information. Hence, it is worth studying the use of electronic information by the university teachers. The necessary data for the study was collected from a sample of 50 university teachers. A pre-structured questionnaire was used to collect the data. The study reveals that the availability of electronic information and the satisfaction of the teachers in the available resources are not high. Non-availability of full text, lack of time and lack of system speed are the most important barriers for the teachers in using the electronic information.

link.heading: Role of Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan in Promotion of Literacy & Rural Library Development in Madhya Pradesh
link.authorDes: Dept of Library and Information Science, M.L.B. Govt College of Excellence, Gwalior-4740l1. E-mail: arvindksharma22rediftmail.com
link.abstract: The article deals with the role of Sarva Shiksha promotion of literacy & rural library development in Madhya Pradesh. Describes the objectives of SSA and Padna Badna Movement. The prime motive of Padana-Badana Sangh (PBS) movement is to generate and develop reading habits among rural community to make system or policies so that villagers can regularly study in library. States the role and responsibilities of Social Animator in PBS. In the field of library development the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan has done a wonderful job with the help of Padhna Badhna Sangh. Because each Padhna Badhna Sangh runs a library in rural areas of M.P. and now more than 47,000 such rural libraries in the state are established to make the people aware. In the end some suggestions are given.

link.heading: Performance of World Wide Web Search Engines: A Comparative Study
link.authorDes: Central Library, University of Delhi, Delhi. INDIA. rsingh@duls.du.ac.in
link.abstract: The paper is an outcome of the study made for evaluating the performance of four WWW search engines - Google, Altavista, Aeoma and Alltheweb. Discusses the need and objectives; review of related literature; methodology adopted; findings and recommendations of the study.

link.heading: Current issues in collection development: Italian and Global perspectives: proceedings of international workshop on collection development, 18th February 2005.
link.authorDes: Dr B R Ambedkar National Institute of Technology (Deemed University), PO REC, Jalandhar 144011, (Punjab), E-mail: kaurs@nitj.ac.in

link.heading: Mastery Learning: A Pedagogical Strategy in Support of No Child Left Behind Act
link.authorDes: Kharazmi (Teacher Training) University, School of Psychology and Education, Mofateh Avenue, P.O. Box 15614, Tehran, Iran. Email: motamedi@saba.tmu.ac.ir
link.abstract: The No Child Left Behind (NCLB) Act of 2001 sets forth a requirement that all school districts must address the issue of student failure by assuring that all students reach a level of proficiency by the year 2013–14. It requires that schools take action that may require curriculum adjustments and/or changes as well as providing choice to leave a failing school to one that is meeting NCLB criteria. This article describes how mastery learning principles applied throughout the curriculum can support the NCLB legislation. Mastery learning has been a proven strategy to maximize students’ effort in achieving proficiency in learning. NCLB legislation is aimed at assuring that all children reach a level of proficiency in their learning. But the legislation does not determine how school districts can accomplish this task. The paper suggests that by implementing mastery learning principles each student can reach a level of proficiency and therefore will support effectiveness of NCLB legislation.

link.heading: Iranian Websites on the Internet
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Ferdowsi University, Mashhad, Iran.2MA in Library and Information Science. Department of Library & Information Science, Ferdowsi University, Mashhad, Iran.
link.abstract: The websites of each country are regarded as a gateway of information. The purpose of this research is to evaluate Iranian websites on the Internet. General quality criteria was used for the evaluation to study ownership and authorship, type of websites, purpose and scope of the sites, language, links, domain types, currency/updating of information, accessibility, services and facilities. 328 websites were selected using five search engines and resources: Yahoo, Google, lycos, Iran digest, and A Guide to Iranian website, to conduct searches in May and June 2004. A check list was drawn up to review the information from the tools. The research reveals that among Iranian websites providing information on the internet, private sites were much more likely to be of poorer quality compared to sites of governmental organizations.

link.heading: Study of Websites of Library and Information Networks in India
link.authors: Lihitkar SHALINI1, Lecturer, Sarode PRATIBHA1, Student of MLISc II year
link.authorDes: 1DLISc, RTMNU, Nagpur.
link.abstract: The paper deals with 18 websites of Library and Information Networks in India. The home pages of these networks were studied by using selected criteria like contact details, authority, hyperlinks, content coverage, ease of nagivation, database, and E-Journals in the websites.

link.heading: Use of Online Public Access Catalogue by the Research Scholars in Panjab University Library, Chandigarh: A Survey
link.authors: Nath AMAR1, Assistant Librarian, Sharma AARTI2, Assistant Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Sant Longowal Institute of Engineering and Technology (SUET), Longowal, District Sangrur (Punjab), E-mail: sharmago4amar @yahoo.co.in2Punjabi Agriculture University Library, Ludhiana (Punjab).
link.abstract: Information technology (IT) holds the key to success in modernizing information services, which ensures not only new ways of information handlings but also aims to introduce new ways in the life style of the users. In the domain of library information service, information technology is meant to use or application of various technologies such as computer, telecommunication and other electronic devices for storage, retrieval, reproduction and dissemination of information in library environment. IT applications have brought dynamic change in the total scenario of information storage, access and dissemination. It has also changed the ways of providing services to users community. Online Public Access Catalogue (OPAC) is one of the services that are being provided by the modern libraries. When we are using the advanced technologies, it therefore becomes necessary to know how far the users are utilizing the services. The present study is an attempt to know the use of OPAC by the research scholars in AC Joshi Library, Chandigarh for this purpose with the help of questionnaire an attempt has been made in the present paper to identify the research scholar's opinion on the use of OPAC. Further an attempt has been made to highlight the findings of the study and based on the analysis of the data a few suggestions have been given.

link.heading: Supporting the Support: Involving Unqualified Staff in the Automation Process
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, North Eastern Hill University (NEHU), Mawlai, Umshing, Shillong, 22, Meghalaya, India. E-mail:bikilaloo@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: The focus of this paper is the involvement of support staff in the automation process in a library. The management at a Central University library in North East India, taking a bold step, decided to do just such a thing and found to its pleasant surprise that it was the right move despite the risks encountered. The author interviewed staff at different levels in the library to find out what happens when support staff are allowed into the ‘hallowed’ area of automation. As it turns out, the librarian and other officers are reaping the good fruits of their decision and the phenomenon experienced in this library can serve as a model for others.

link.heading: Current Issues and Strategies of Academic Library System in Orissa: An Overview
link.authors: Seth MAHENDRA KUMAR1, Parida BAMAN2, DR
link.authorDes: 1Library & Documentation Division, Regional Laboratory, (CSIR), Bhubaneswar 751 013, E-mail: mkseth@rrlbhu.res.in2Department of LIS, Utkal University, Vanivihar, Bhubaneswar 751 004, E-mail: parida_baman@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The paper highlights the present status of academic libraries in Orissa with some burning external and internal issues. Some basic problems are given with its regenerating ways for the development of libraries. The author also discusses some solutions to be undertaken in the state for its modernisation.

link.heading: Care and Preservation of Library Documents in Universities, Archives and Colleges of Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh
link.authorDes: Bhai Gurdas Library, GND University, Amritsar-143 005.

link.heading: Information Accessibility and Utilization as Factors Influencing Decision-making of Managers in Commercial Banks in Nigeria
link.authorDes: Department of Library, Archival and Information Studies, University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Nigeria.
link.abstract: The present study investigates information accessibility and utilisation as factors influencing decision-making of managers in commercial banks in Nigeria. Single stage random sampling with equal allocation method is used to select 550 managers from the 66 licensed commercial banks. It reveals that there is a significant positive relationship between academic qualifications and information utilisation in decision-making of the respondents (r = 0.88, P < 0.05). Information accessibility and utilisation, when taken together significantly influences decision-making of the respondents (F = 48.67, df = 2; 507, P < 0.05). Also, each of the two factors independently has a significant influence on decision-making of the respondents information accessibility (= 0.6214; df = 507, T = 10.71, P < 0.05) and information utilization (= 0.8246. df = 507, T = 12.49 P < 0.05). The study also shows that information utilisation has a greater relative influence than information accessibility on decision-making of the respondents. Information accessibility and utilisation have significant positive multiple relationship with decision-making of the respondents (R = 0.8428, P <0.05). It is therefore recommended that the management should make relevant information accessible on time for the use of managers for improved decision-making in the Nigerian commercial banks.

link.heading: Information Support in Combating Fatal Superstitions in Rural Society
link.authorDes: Establishment Section, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur. E mail: biswanath_jri@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: This paper carefully examines newspaper reports on various untested preconceptions prevailing among marginalized sections of people and others in the form of numerous magical practices. Explains on how the sentiments of the group members are exploited to achieve vested interests of the few by blaming and punishing innocent fellows through black magic. Emphasizes to unearth the main causes and motives behind the social unjust and categories the causes. Suggestions are made to uproot those evil practices by means of scientific information support.

link.heading: Right to Information
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Andhra University, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh.
link.abstract: Presents a brief overview of Right to Information (RTI). Discusses the need for the Right to Information in a society and national and international efforts made to fulfill this dream in present day. The author also describes the Right to Information Act, 2005 its exemptions, limitations, implications and issues in a modern world.

link.heading: Information Profession
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Andhra University, Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh.
link.abstract: Gives a brief review of the Library and Information Science (LIS) Profession, its past, present and future

link.heading: Copyright Issues in Digital Era
link.authorDes: Dyal Singh (Eve). College, University of Delhi, New Delhi 110 003.
link.abstract: The article discusses copyright issues of digital information while highlighting the difficulties raised by digital form, viz, ease to copy, manipulate, etc. Suggests strong copyright policy and ethical use of digital information as a means to protect the authors’ rights.

link.heading: Institutional Repositories: Challenge and Opportunity for LIS Professionals in Digital Age
link.authors: Hirwade MANGALA1, Librarian, Hirwade ANIL W2
link.authorDes: 1Shivaji Science College, Congress Nagar, Nagpur. E-mail: hirwade2004@indiatimes.com2Patent Information System Seminary Hills, Nagpur 440 006.
link.abstract: In the present age of information revolution and ever increasing demand for exact and consolidated information, the functions and old methods followed by traditional libraries are being replaced by new techniques and technologies. Providing access to information free of charge in electronic formats is a concept that is gaining momentum. Open Access is one step ahead of Free Access. Open Access holds promise to remove both price and permission barriers to the scientific communication by using Internet. Creating Institutional Repositories is a step towards open access. The paper provides information about major Institutional Repositories in India.

link.heading: Standards for Assessment of Information Literacy Skills of Undergraduate students
link.authorDes: 1Sri Venkateswara College Library, (University of Delhi), Dhaula Kuan, New Delhi 110 021.2Dyal Singh College (Evening) Library, (University of Delhi)., Lodhi Road, New Delhi 110 003.
