link.abstract: Describes information literacy skills of undergraduate students. Highlights the need for information literacy assessment of undergraduate students. Discusses two well-known information literacy standards developed in United States and United Kingdom, which could be used to assess the information literacy competency of undergraduate students.

link.heading: New Choices for Bibliographic Services in a Wired Planet: Reflections on the National Library of India
link.authorDes: United Nations Information Centre, 55 Lodi Estate, New Delhi 110 003, Email: sharma@unicindia.org
link.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to present the state of public and national libraries and an overview of the bibliographic information services available with them. Mentions several of the challenges facing libraries in determining their present and future roles in their nation's information infrastructure and in a global information infrastructure. Web based bibliographic services provided in the British Library and Library of Congress have been discussed. Libraries are major providers of information. They have a crucial role to play particularly in the era of information technology and wired world. The undergoing shift caused by changing user needs not only affects the technical services of libraries but also streamline the library services that are being offered to the public. Need for availability of national bibliographic databases in machine-readable form on the Web would provide better bibliographic organization and control of material. Some suggestions for improving the computerized bibliographic services at national library and strategies for implementation have been put forth.

link.heading: Special Libraries in the Electronic Environment.
link.authorDes: Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar-143 005, satija_mp@yahoo.com

link.heading: UGC-Infonet E-journal Consortium for Universities and Colleges An Indian Experience
link.authorDes: An IUC of UGC, Near Gujarat University Campus, Ahmedabad 380 009, India.
link.abstract: Electronic journal packages, have become standard resources in academic libraries in the last few years The development in IT has facilitated the formation of different types of library consortia to share the cost of information resources. Library consortia are a concept of 1960s though the e-consortia are features of the present century. The increasing global collaboration of people and shared resources needs to be developed and concerted efforts by the LIS professional to solve the emerging problems. In this electronic Information age Library Consortia is gaining more importance. This paper will highlight about UGC-INFONET: The central theme of the paper will deal on the use of E-journals by the Academic and research community in India.
link.keywords: Agriculture Libraries, Agricultural Library Services.

link.heading: Measuring the Winds of Change: A State-of-the-Art Report of the PG Programmes and Placement in LIS (with special reference to DLIS, NU, Nagpur)
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Nagpur University, Nagpur.2Learning Resources Centre, Mahila Mahavidyalaya, 152 Nandanvan Layout, Nagpur. E-mail: crekha@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: The paper visualizes the impact of Globalisation on Higher Education in general, and LIS (faculty of social science) in particular. The paper, stresses on the current realities in the light of globalization by presenting a statistical review of the Universities, its students, and the changing ratios. Further, the paper stresses on the basic concepts of GATS, and its implications on the services included in the agreement. The present paper is an attempt to evaluate the PG programme and the placement scenario of DLIS through a survey based on the documentary sources, and Library and Information Science Alumni of the Nagpur University. The article, highlights the areas of concern and put forths certain recommendations and measures revitalizing LIS education and professionals to face the new global scenario confidently.

link.heading: Gender Difference and Levels of Requirement for Information Resources and Services of the Career Seekers in Kerala
link.authors: Koovakkai DINESHAN1, Professional Assistant, Jalaja V2, Reader
link.authorDes: 1University Library, University of Calicut, Kerala 673 635, E-mail: dineshkoovakkai@yahoo.co.in2DLIS, University of Calicut, Kerala 673 635, E-mail: jalajadlis@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The problem of educated unemployment is a crucial social problem in Kerala. As the educational status of women is comparatively high in the state, it is worthwhile to study how far the requirement level of the female career seekers is different from that of the male career seekers. The data were collected using questionnaire from 1180 career seekers out of which 1039 respondent. The study reveals that no much difference exists between the male and the female career seekers in Kerala in the level of requirement for majority of the resource and services. However the requirement level of the female career seeker is higher in the cases where difference is observed.

link.heading: State-of-the-Art of Documentation and Information Services in SAU Libraries in India
link.authors: Gautam JN1, Professor & Dean, Srivastava MAHENDRA NARAYAN2, Librarian
link.authorDes: 1SOS in Library and Information Science, Jiwaji University, Gwalior.2Government PG College, Obedullaganj, Raisen.
link.abstract: The paper presents the state-of-the-art position of documentation and information services in agricultural universities in India. On the basis of survey report, highlights conventional documentation and information services, namely bibliographic service, current awareness service, abstracting and indexing service, reprographic and newspaper clipping services. It gives the present situation of library automation, computerisation, CD-ROM database services, Internet and On-line facilities, availability of software operating systems, library software packages, electronic services like CD-ROM, E-mail, Multimedia, etc. Finally highlights the reprographic services provided by these libraries as a part of information services.

link.heading: User Education in Agricultural Libraries in India: A Paradigm Need
link.authors: Gupta SUNITA1, Kanaujia LALETA2, MPhil Scholar
link.authorDes: 1IARI Library, Pusa, New Delhi 110 012.2Department of Lib & Info Sc, University of Delhi, Delhi 110 007.
link.abstract: The paper deals with the current situation of user education in the agricultural university libraries in India. states the objectives of user education. Presents a survey report of agricultural libraries where user education is a part of university teaching programme. Highlights the impact of user education on the use of library material; the self reliance achieved by the users through user education programmes and the overall impact on reference service. It also gives the common course contents as a part of the curricula of different universities. Finally, suggests the need for user education to be introduced in all agricultural university libraries in order to make users more self reliant in the use of library and for cost effectiveness and value addition of library material and services.

link.heading: India's Research on Information Seeking Behaviour of Agricultural Scientists: A Literature Survey
link.authors: Satija MP1, Professor and Head, Singh KP2, PhD scholar
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar (Punjab).2Department of Library and Information Science, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar (Punjab) and Lecturer, DLIS, University of Delhi, Delhi.
link.abstract: Information seeking behaviour is an essential component in designing and developing of need based information centers for meeting the information requirements of users. The study undertaken is an output of doctorate research in the field of agricultural sciences scanned in Indian context. The study covers various facets of information seeking behaviour of agricultural scientists and their conceptual meanings. It includes about forty researches undertaken by Indian researchers in the field of agriculture and its allied areas. The findings of the studies are grouped into information needs; users characteristics; information seeking; and information seeking behaviour.

link.heading: The Image and Role of the Librarian: A Review
link.authorDes: Department of Library & Information Science, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra 136 119, E-mail: manojkj01@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Reviews the study investigating image and role of librarians in diverse settings and different historical periods spanning more than a centuary. Spread over four aspects– professional role, cultural images, popular perceptions and future trends, the paper attempts to bring together historical analysis and survey of present situation of the social perception of librarians.

link.heading: Records Management Programme in Nigeria: A Survey of Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Ago-Iwoye, Nigeria
link.authorDes: Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Ago-Iwoye, Nigeria.
link.abstract: This paper examines the creation, maintenance and use as well as preservation, protection and disposition of records in the Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Ago-Iwoye. Questionnaire and observation methods were employed to accumulate data for the study. The study reveals that various categories of records are created and kept in the Library. The findings show that the records programme in the Library is okay but not yet complete. The paper therefore recommends that the Library should establish a central records centre, archives and provide necessary facilities like biological agent control and others for improvement of records management in the Library.

link.heading: Information Seeking Behaviour of Medical Professionals Working with Public Sector Institute/Hospital (PGIMER, Chandigarh) and Private Sector Institute/Hospital (EHIRC), New Delhi: A comparative study with reference to their library use
link.authors: Sengar K P SINGH1, Gautam J N1
link.authorDes: 1SOS, Library and Information Science, Jiwaji University, Gwalior (MP) E-mail: ksengarl@yahoo.com and jngautam@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The study reveals the results of the survey undertaken on information seeking behaviour of medical professionals who are working with Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education & Research (PGIMER), Chandigarh and Escort Heart Institute and Research Centre (EHIRC), New Delhi to assess their information services/facilities provided to them. The survey results also highlight those areas in which some improvements are needed to cater to the need of their users in both the libraries.

link.heading: LICs as More Responsive Organisations in the Changing Environment: Applications of Principles and Techniques of Total Quality Management
link.authors: Sasikala C1, Dr, Raju N Govinda2, Research Scholar
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Andhra University, Visakhapatnam, (AP).2Department of Library and Information Science, Andhra University, Visakhapatnam (AP).
link.abstract: Change is inevitable in every sphere of human activity in the society. LICs as social institutions are no exception to this phenomenon. Being open systems they need to react change in their environment and responsive to the needs of the society they are serving. But managing the Change is not an easy task especially when the organization is working in a turbulent and dynamic environment. This paper discusses about the reasons for change, their impact on human resources and functioning of libraries and the relevance and application of TQM principles in managing the change in LICs.

link.heading: Knowledge Management and Challenges to LIS Professionals in Electronic Age
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi E-mail; singhkp1972@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: Information Revolution and Global Knowledge Society (IR&GKS) are two important buzzwords of 21st century. Web and web-based technologies in the last couple of years have attacked on the boundaries of Library and Information Work. Consequently the traditional image of LIS professionals is rapidly changing and widening into a knowledge centre and a knowledge manager. The modern library system, keeping in mind that “the right information needs to be in the hands of the right people at the right place” and knowledge is the new expandable source of the economic wealth and a critical asset to an organization, has transformed their external and internal functioning and management. Knowledge Management (KM) is not about technology management but rather than about deciding what information and knowledge is critical to the success of the organization. The emerging issues of Knowledge Management need to be taken seriously in changing perspectives as challenges by the LIS professionals. It has widely and undoubtedly been accepted and proved from various studies that future shall be knowledge based. Therefore, knowledge management, content management, content engineering through LIS professionals shall play a significant role in the 21st century. The paper discusses in detail the various facets of knowledge management such as Evolution and Concept of Knowledge Management, Knowledge Management Technologies and Tools, LIS professionals as Knowledge Manager, and challenges for the LIS professional in the electronic age.

link.heading: Indological Libraries in Madhya Pradesh
link.authors: Sharma DR ARVIND K1, Assistant Professor
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, M L B Government College of Excellence, Gwalior 474 009.
link.abstract: The present study is based on 20 Indological Libraries of Madhya Pradesh established between 1854 to 2002. It includes scope, objective, importance, sources of data, and historical development of Indological libraries. Major findings are: during the period 1980–1989 a total of 7 (35%) institutions/libraries were established and this decade can be recognized as a golden period for establishing Indological institutions/libraries. In Madhya Pradesh. Only (65%) libraries have librarian, 9 (45%) Indological libraries have special manuscripts, 12 libraries have classified their collection out of them 6 (50%) libraries use Dewey Decimal Classification and 3 (25%) use Colon Classification, 7 (35%) libraries have computer, 3 (l5%) libraries are connected with networks and financial scarcity is a major hurdle in the development of indological libraries.

link.heading: Meta Data – Dublin Core
link.authorDes: Vellore Institute of Technology, Vellore 632 014, E-mail: yvramana58@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: This paper deals with Meta data, its benefits, usage, elements of Meta data, Meta tags and Meta standards. Emphasis is placed while describing the Dublin Core Meta data and presents the recommended elements of Meta data, their usefulness and benefits.

link.abstract: This paper deals with the author's viewpoints and observations on the Report of UGC Model Curriculum of Library and Information Science (2001) as a critique to the overall growth of LIS education in India.

link.heading: Ever First University Librarian of the Imperial City of Delhi, Professor S Das Gupta: His Life and His Times
link.authors: Saini DR M L1, University Librarian (Retd)

link.heading: Are we on Right Line in LIS Curriculum Development?
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Info Sc, Nagpur University, Nagpur.
link.abstract: Gives a brief overview of the developments in LIS education in India. Discusses the efforts of UGC in curriculum development and presents some shortcomings of UGC Model Curriculum (2001) to make the curriculum needbased.

link.heading: Learning Objectives in BLIS Study Materials of IGNOU
link.authors: Mishra DR SANJAYA1, Reader in Distance Education
link.authorDes: 1Staff Training and Research Institute of Distance Education, Indira Gandhi National Open University, Maidan Garhi, New Delhi 110 068, E-mail: s-mishra@ignou.ac.in
link.abstract: The paper critically analyses one of the instructional elements (i.e. Objective) of self-learning materials supplied by the Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU) to the Bachelor of Library and Information Science (BLIS) learners. Using the original Bloom's taxonomy of learning objectives, the study reveals that about 30 per cent of objective statements are written without any thought to the guidelines. Indepth analysis further shows that only 16.31 per cent are higher order objectives. The paper also makes a case for revision of the learning materials in light of the revised Bloom's Taxonomy.

link.heading: Professional Competence Building Through Distance Mode Library and Information Science Programmes with Special Reference to MLIS Programme of Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU): A Case Study
link.authors: Rath DR PRAVAKAR1, Professor and Head
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Mizoram University (A Central University), Aizawl 796 001, E-mail: prath@fulbrightweb.org
link.abstract: The article describes about MLIS programme and its components being offered through distance mode by Indira Gandhi National Open University, New Delhi (India) with a special emphasis on professional competency building by the learners who have successfully completed this programme. The objectives of joining this programme and the competency achieved through course material, seminar, computer practical, teleconferencing, library facilities, audio/video materials, counselling, assignments have been discussed in detail based on a feedback study/survey undertaken by the author. The article further explains the benefits gained, problems confronted and advances suggestions for improvements in future by the learners.

link.heading: Education and Training of Library Semi-Professionals in Iran: A Survey
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, Kharazmi, (T T U) University, Iran.
link.abstract: The paper deals with education and training of library semi-professionals in Iran. Gives results of survey conducted using a structured questionnaire administered amongst the admitted students belonging to 1999, 2000 and 2001 batches.

link.heading: Qualitative versus Quantitative: A Methodological Perspective
link.authors: Guha Tamal Komar1, DR, Assistant Libarian, Saraf Veena2, DR, Reader
link.authorDes: 1Indian Institute of Technology Guwahati, North Guwahati-781 039. Assam, fam@iitg.ernet.in2Department of Library & Information Science, North Eastern Hill University, Shiliong 793 014, Meghalaya, veenasaraf@yahoo.co.uk
link.abstract: Over the last five decades, libraries have faced a great challenge to reach out to their users. Studies have been conducted through out the entire array of library services to understand the needs and assess the requirements of the users communities. However, an introspection of the methodologies used for conducting such studies and the paradigm shift from quantitative has been felt a necessity in the ever changing scenario of information services in an electronic era.

link.heading: Role of Public Libraries in Electronic Environment
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi 110 007, E-mail: singh_34@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Mentions the initiatives of RRRLF and UNESCO for promoting public libraries, Gives a brief overview about public library legislation in India. Emphasises the changing role of public libraries and new strategies in changing environment.

link.heading: Refresher Course: A Ritual or Tool
link.authors: Kaushik DR SANJAY K1, Senior Assistant Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Maharshi Dayanand University, Rohtak 124001 (Haryana). E-mail: kaush_s@rediffmail.com; kaush2k3_sk@yahoomail.com
link.abstract: The aim of this present paper is to analyze the refresher course of Library and Information Science conducted by University Library of Maharshi Dayanand University Rohtak (Haryana) whether such kind of refresher courses are mere rituals to get the Senior scale/Selection grade or these are the tools for the continuing education/professional development. The paper also presents the results of the study conducted through a structured questionnaire. The results indicate that these courses are not mere rituals rather these serve as the best tool for continuing education and professional development.

link.heading: Role of Internet in Social Science Research
link.authorDes: 1Nabakrushna Choudhury Centre for Development Studies (ICSSR Institute), Bhubaneswar-751 013. e-mail: ncdsvc@sancharnet.in
link.abstract: With the emerging phenomenon of information and communication technologies, the areas of education and research have witnessed significant changes. The by-product of these technologies is the Internet, which is variously used for different purposes. Internet is being widely used for education and research. The method of web-based research has started to gain momentum. Researchers have found the usefulness of Internet as a very effective medium for conducting research work. The paper discusses the use of Internet in social science research and how different steps in methodologies of social science research can be conducted over Internet to complete research work.

link.heading: India-Middle East Collaboration in S&T: An Analysis Through Co-authored Publications, 1996–2000
link.authors: Gupta B M1, Dhawan S M†, Osareh Farideh‡
link.authorDes: 1National Institute of Science, Technology and Development Studies, Dr KS Krishnan Marg, New Delhi 110 012, India.† National Physical Laboratory, Dr KS Krishnan Marg, New Delhi 110 012, India.‡Department of Library & Information Science, Shahid Chamran University, Ahwaz, Iran
link.abstract: The paper studies the India's collaboration with Middle East countries in S&T during the period 1996–2000, using the co-authored publications output as the base. The collaboration is under two broad streams, bilateral and multilateral. The study analyses the co-authored papers by main fields and sub-fields and the impact of such collaboration in different fields of S&T. The paper identifies the major institutions involved in collaborative research in the two countries. The study reveals the extent of commonality of subject interests between India and Middle East countries.

link.heading: Marketing of Information Products and Services in Bangladesh: Theories and Practices
link.authors: Munshi M NASIR UDDIN1, Associate Professor
link.authorDes: 1Department of Information Science & Library Management, University of Dhaka, Dhaka, 1000, Bangladesh.
link.abstract: Discusses the marketing concepts, marketing strategy and techniques those have been used for making libraries and Information centres as profit making organizations. Determines the present status of library's information products and services in Bangladesh perspective. Measures the marketing functions and activities that are performing in the special libraries and information centres of the country. Identifies some benefits of using marketing techniques in library and information services.

link.heading: Users’ Education Programme for Marketing Strategy in Context of Information Society
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra (Haryana), E-mail: promilapawar@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Educating the users forms the integral part of marketing strategy in all the sectors of the economy, be it Banking, Agriculture, Health or Railways etc. The significance of the marketing aspect can be realized from the fact that today even political parties spend handsome amount of funds on educating the people about their ways and means, the direct result of which can be felt at the ballot boxes. But as far as Information Sector is concerned there is a paradoxical situation amongst its major constituent agencies i.e., Information Architects and the Information Managers, whereby the former has responded with tremendous changes with total transformation of marketing strategy from that of traditional to a modern one. But the Information Managers are slow to respond in this regard and thus there is growing challenge for them to be taken over by their counterparts.

link.heading: Introduction to the Eighteenth Edition (2004) of the Sears List of Subject Headings
link.authorDes: 1Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar 143 005, E-mail: satija_mp@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Mentions briefly the history of Sears List of Subject Headings 18th edition (2004). Highlights some major changes and new features of latest edition. Also discusses the methodology of application, structure and limitations of Sears List for making the SHs in general.

link.heading: Guidelines for Computer Maintenance to Optimise Utilisation of PCs
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, 136119.
link.abstract: The article deals with the basic maintenance techniques, measures and steps to keep the functioning smooth, as well as, improve the efficiency of computers. The suggested measures, if followed properly, regularly and religiously, will ensure greater life span of hardware/software and trouble free service to the users.

link.heading: Library Legislation in Bangladesh: A Current Status
link.authors: Deshpande N J1, (MRS), Reader, Ullah Ahsan2, MOHD, PhD Research Student
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, University of Pune, Pune 411 007, India. E-mail: njdeshpande@unipune.ernet.in2Department of Library Science, University of Pune, Pune, India. and Librarian, Deptartment of Public Libraries, Ministry of Cultural Affairs, Bangladesh. E-mail: ahsan_hasan@yahoo.com
link.abstract: Libraries are the hardcore for dissemination of knowledge and information in a technocratic modern society. Library legislation is of paramount importance to empower the appropriate authorities, overall control and co-operation for proper developments and to ensure adequate financial support and efficient administration by leaps and bounds within such society. In other words, legislation can play a pivotal role for organization, smooth flow of finance and development of a library system on proper line.

link.heading: Towards the Promotion of a Credible Reading Culture: A Case Study of some South Western States in Nigeria
link.authors: Iyiade A K1, Acquisition Librarian, Adekunmisi S R1, Gift and Exchange Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Ago-Owoye, Ogun State, Nigeria.
link.abstract: This paper examines reading as a habit and the need to encourage the habit among our teeming population in Nigeria and also discusses the problems associated with reading. A total of 710 copies of a questionnaire were administered to civil servants in Ogun, Oyo and Osun State while 635 copies were returned constituting 89.43% response rate. Analysis of the returned questionnaires shows that economic hardship, illiteracy, low level of government involvement in the implementation of a credible reading habit and inadequate functional libraries among others militate against life-long reading habit. The paper offers suggestions and recommendations on how to promote and sustain reading habit in the Nigeri an populace.

link.heading: The Thesaurofacet: An experiment with Soil Science
link.authors: Sharma A K1, Gautam J N2, Singh S P3
link.authorDes: 1Indian Institute of Soil Science, Nabi Bagh, Berasia Road, Bhopal-462 0382SOS in Library & Information Science, Jiwaji University, Gwalior3Department of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007.
link.abstract: The Thesaurofacet is a combination of a faceted classification scheme and a thesaurus. The novel feature of the system is that it is integrating the classification schedule with the thesaurus, thus giving advantages of both the systems. The terms or descriptors are appearing in the thesaurus portion and the schedule part. In the schedule the term is displayed in the most appropriate facet and hierarchy and the thesaurus supplements this information by indicating the alternative hierarchies. The thesaurus controls the word form and gives an standardized vocabulary to an indexer. This paper is a part of thesis and an effort to give the noble feature of thesaurofacet in the Soil Science. The methodology of application of the Thesaurofacet in pre coordinate and post coordinate system is discussed. For compilation of the Thesaurofacet, the THES module of the CDS/ISIS has been used with slight modifications for the compilation of the Thesaurofacet.

link.heading: Importance and Availability Patterns of Sanskrit Polyglot Dictionaries: A Bibliometric Study
link.authors: Sharma ARVIND K1, Assistant Professor, Mall B
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, MLB Government College of Excellence, Gwalior.2Central Library, Jiwaji University, Gwalior.
link.abstract: The study is based on 73 Sanskrit polyglot dictionaries published from India and abroad covering the period of 1798 to 1999. It defines the term polyglot and gives meaning, importance, objective, scope, hypotheses, sources of data, methodology and author-wise, place-wise, subject-wise, publisher-wise, language-wise, year-wise analysis of polyglot dictionaries. Subject wise analysis of data indicates that 49 polyglot dictionaries deal with different Indian and foreign languages and literatures. Language group wise analysis shows maximum of this type of dictionaries compiled in Sanskrit-English-Hindi, which accounted for 14. Maximum 3 publications emerged from International Academy of Indian Culture. Place wise distribution of collected data indicates that as many as 13 polyglot dictionaries are published from Calcutta. Year wise distribution of data indicates that maximum publications 18 emerged in the period of 1901–1925.

link.heading: Evaluation of Circulation Services: A Case Study of University Libraries of Karnataka State
link.authors: Dr  Ramesha1, Assistant Librarian, Dr Kumbar B D2, Reader
link.authorDes: 1University Library, Karnatak University, Dharwad-580 003, Karnataka State, India.2Department of Library and Information Science, Karnatak University, Dharwad 580 003, Karnataka State, India.
link.abstract: The circulation services are discussed in this paper in detail with the help of the data collected through two different sets of questionnaires administered to librarians as well as users and also information collected from annual reports and through personal visits to all the university libraries of Karnataka State. It is important for the circulation services to know the views of both the receivers and the providers of services – namely the users and the librarians. Based on the findings, the paper puts forward some implied suggestions to improve the overall quality of library and information services in general and circulation services in particular. The study helps the librarians to understand the users’ opinion towards performance of the circulation services. In addition they also present to them the better side of the library.

link.heading: Marketing and Pricing of Knowledge Products and Services
link.authors: Dr Rajyalakshmi D1, Reader & HOD, Waghmare S B2, Mrs, Lecturer
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, Nagpur University, Nagpur.2Department of Library and Information Science, Nagpur University, Nagpur.
link.abstract: The paper discusses the concept of marketing, need for marketing of knowledge products and services in Libraries in the present context, the activities which can be undertaken for marketing; different products which become financial resource generators for Libraries. The ways and means of promotion; different methods of generation of finances in Libraries, and some examples of charges collected for knowledge products and services are given and methods of price estimations for different services and products are discussed.

link.heading: Collection Development of Electronic Information Resources in The R & D Libraries of Kolkata City: A Survey
link.authors: Maharana Bulu1, Lecturer, P G, Choudhury B K2, Reader & Head, P G, Dutta Syamashree3, M.Phil Scholar, P G
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, Sambalpur University, Jyoti Vihar-768019, Orissa.2Department of Library & Information Science, Sambalpur University, Jyoti Vihar-768019, Orissa.3Department of Library & Information Science, Sambalpur University, Jyoti Vihar-768019, Orissa.
link.abstract: The paper discusses about the policies and practices of development and management of e-resources in the select R & D libraries of Kolkata City. Depicts the current state of e-collection, policy statements, and management practices under vogue. It also examines various criteria for selection and evaluation of eresources. Feasible recommendations have been put forth for the development of a balanced collection of electronic resources and its effective management.

link.heading: Nigerian Academic Libraries and Collection Development: A Case Study of Olabisi Onabanjo University Library Nigeria
link.authors: Omagbemi C O1, Readers’ Services Librarian, Ogunbote K O2, Acquisitions Librarian, Adekunmisi S R3, Serials Librarian
link.authorDes: 1Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, PMB 2002, Ago Iwoye, Ogun State, Nigeria.2Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, PMB 2002, Ago Iwoye, Ogun State, Nigeria.3Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, PMB 2002, Ago Iwoye, Ogun State, Nigeria.
link.abstract: The paper assesses the collections of Olabisi Onabanjo University Library using the projections by the University Planning Committee, the take off stock and the present collections. The present state of the library collection has not been able to meet up with the initial projections, as well as the CULNU guidelines. It identifies inadequate funding and geometrical increase in students intake as major problems. It stresses the fact that the Olabisi Onabanjo University's issue is not an isolated one as various reports and studies have revealed similar situation in other Nigerian Universities using the Nigerian, African and United Kingdom average on collection as yardstick.

link.heading: Textile Information and Communication Network in India (TEXICONET)
link.authors: Jena Kamal Lochan1, Mahapatra R K2
link.authorDes: 1Institute of Textile Technology, Chowdar, Cuttack.2NKC Centre for Development Studies (ICSSR Institute), Bhubaneswar-751013. E-mail: rkm_02@yahoo.com
link.abstract: The paper discusses the textile sector in India and the need for development of an information and communication network for sharing of resources. It has clearly discussed the users group, information needs of users group, the objectives of such network and the institutions and organizations imparting training and conducting research in textile and allied subjects forming the part of such network. The role of two (major nodal bodies such as NCUTE and NICTAS has also been discussed. A national level network for textile information such as TEXICONET is proposed in this paper.

link.heading: Developing Digital Libraries: Technologies and Challenges
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, Tribhuvan University, Kathmandu, Nepal. Email: mpradhan@healthnet.org.np
link.abstract: Discusses the basics of developing a digital library and explains the new concepts underlying the digital library development procedures regarding technologies and managerial skills. Measures are needed to overcome the problems of computer viruses and also unauthorized use. Initial investment in digital libraries is high, as is maintenance; it is therefore essential to explore the new sources of fund.

link.heading: Sociologists’ Perception of Librarians
link.authors: Satija M P1, PROF, Joshi Manoj K†, Lecturer, Singh Sukhdev‡, DR
link.authorDes: 1Department of Lib & Inf Sc, Guru Nanak Dev University, Amritsar 143 005, (India), satija_mp@yahoo.com†Dept of Lib & Inf Sc, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra 136 119 (India), manojkj01@yahoo.com‡Guru Nanak Dev University Library, Amritsar 143 005 (India)
link.abstract: Describes a study investigating the perception of Indian sociologists of their institution's librarian. The survey was conducted during the 27th All India Sociology Conference at Amritsar (India). The librarian was found to be quite visible among user community, as 82.6% respondents personally knew their institution's librarian. 67.07% considered him a part of the faculty, while 15.85% viewed him as their professional colleague. 89% found him pleasant & enthusiastic and 83.7% sought his assistance for research and teaching activities. For more than 70% respondents, the librarian was effective in solving their problems. However, only 43.5% considered him partially or fully up-to-date in the use of IT. Although the perception of male and female sociologists does not differ significantly, but there is a significant difference in the perception of professors, reader/associate professors, lecturer/assistant professors, researchers, and those working in other type of institutions.

link.heading: Profiling the Experience of Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Nigeria, in the Automation of its Functions and Services
link.authors: Odusanya O K1, Amusa O I1
link.authorDes: 1Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, PMB 2002, Ago-Iwoye, Ogun State, Nigeria.
link.abstract: This study relates the experience of Olabisi Onabanjo University Library, Nigeria, in the automation, and the successful application of X-LIB, a library application programme developed in Nigeria. It examined the steps taken by the library in the course of automation and the choice of X-LIB; highlights the problems and constraints being confronted by the Library on automation; and offers suggestions on how to improve in project.

link.abstract: Mentions different aspects of computer application in humanities research. States the characteristics of humanities research. Highlights the interdisciplinary approach in this field and the tendency of humanist researchers regarding information. Discusses also the mass storage devices of computer.

link.heading: India's University Libraries: Financial Issues and Funds Raising Strategies
link.authors: Bhatt R K1, Senior Lecturer, Singh K P1, Lecturer
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi.
link.abstract: At present, the university libraries in India are passing through a very crucial phase. They are in the process of change and transformation. Over the last two decades they have witnessed a number of significant changes affecting their structure and services to a great extent. Presently, academic libraries in India are facing number of problems like space manpower standardization, professional development of the staff, challenge of information and communication technology, and above all, the most serious one being the huge financial crisis. Present paper discusses the possible ways to generate financial resources by the academic libraries and possible solutions to over come the problem of finance.

link.heading: State-of-the-Art of Documentation and Information Services in SAU Libraries in India
link.authors: Srivastava Mahendra Narayan1, Librarian, Kanaujia Laleta2, MPhil Scholar
link.authorDes: 1Government P G College, Obedullaganj, Raisen.2Department of Library & Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi 110 007.
link.abstract: The paper presents the state-of-the-art position of documentation and information services in agricultural universities in India. The authors on the basis of their survey report highlight the conventional documentation and information services, namely bibliographic service, current awareness service, abstracting and indexing service, reprographic and news clipping services. It gives the present situation of library automation, computerization, CD-ROM data base services, Internet and On-line facilities. It gives the availability of software operating systems, library work packages, electronic services like CD-ROM, On-line, E-mail, Multimedia, etc. Finally highlights the reprographic services provided by these libraries as the part of information services.

link.heading: Data Mining (Bibliomining) for Management Decisions in Libraries
link.authors: Mukhopadhyay Bikash1, Information Scientist, Central Library
link.authorDes: 1The University of Burdwan, Burdwan (West Bengal), E-mail: buclib@satyam.net.in
link.abstract: Library and information services in corporations, schools, universities and communities capture information about their users, circulation history, resources in the collection and search patterns. Unfortunately, few libraries have taken advantage of these data as a way to improve customer service, manage acquisition budgets or influence strategic decision making about uses of information in their organizations. In this paper, a global view of the data generated in libraries, and the variety of decisions that those data can inform is presented. The paper describes ways in which library and information managers can use data mining in their libraries, i.e., bibliomining to understand patterns of behaviour among library users and staff members and patterns of information resource use throughout the institution.
link.keywords: Data mining, Data warehouse, Bibliomining, Digital Library, OLAP.

link.heading: Modelling the Growth of Literature in the Area of Chemical Sciences
link.authorDes: 1National Institute of Science, Technology and Development Studies, Dr K S Krishnan Marg, New Delhi-110012.
link.abstract: The article reviews the different approaches for studying the growth of scientific knowledge, as reflected by publications. It studies and explores the applicability of selected growth models in the growth of the world research output in the form of papers, patents and books in the field of chemical sciences during 1907–1999. Also studies the criteria on which growth models are to be selected for their possible applications in the field of chemical science literature.

link.heading: Contribution of Cities, States and Regions in Indian LIS Journals From 1991 to 2000
link.authorDes: 1Development Alternatives, B-32, Tara Crescent, Qutab Institutional Area, New Delhi 110 016.
link.abstract: This study is based on 1637 research papers in Library and Information Science (LIS) published in 10 Indian LIS journals during the period 1991 to 2000, LIS research and study is concentrated in ten cities mainly viz., Delhi, Bangalore, Hyderabad, Kolkata, Mumbai, Lucknow, Amritsar, Bhubaneswar, Madras, Dharwad, Thiruvananthapuram, though the analysis of published literature on LIS indicates that Indian research activities in the field of LIS are distributed over several geographical regions. The northern, southern regions have strong base, while the western, eastern, north eastern & central region have made very marginal contributions, The six major states contributing LIS articles are: Delhi, Karnataka, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, West Bengal, and Maharastra.

link.heading: e-Journal Portals: A Web Retrieval Tool for Scholarly Communication in Digital Era
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi, Delhi-110007. e-mail: singhkp_1972@yahoo.co.in
link.abstract: Information Communication Technology (ICT) and its offshoots technologies such as Internet, Intranet, www, Web directories, Web portals, and E-portals, etc. have palyed a significant role in the libraries and information centres. The new emerging technology like E-journals portals have played a marvelous role in acquisition and dissemination of full-text information to libraries at a minimal cost. The present paper discusses the various facets and issues of E-portal journals in detail.

link.heading: Knowledge Management: A Growing Discipline
link.authors: Thakur D S1, DR, Documentation Officer, Thakur K S2, Librarian
link.authorDes: 1National Institute of Educational Planning and Administration (NIEPA), 17-B, Sri Aurobindo Marg, New Delhi-110016. E-mail: dsthakur@hotmail.com2Punj Lloyd Limited, 17–18, Nehru Place, New Delhi-110019. E-mail: ksthakur@punjlloyd.com
link.abstract: This paper presents the role of knowledge management in business, learning and research organizations. It is a need of the hour to big, medium, small and all kinds of organizations to cope with the challenges of knowledge management in the new century. Tacit knowledge is a pivotal point of organizational learning and focuses on the role of tacit knowledge in the business, industry, research and learning organizations. Conversion of tacit knowledge into explicit knowledge and vice versa is the requirement of present and future industries and research organizations. Knowledge management is a strategy and shows a path how to face the global challenges in most accelerated information technology world. It gives a message - “If they don't they won't survive”.

link.heading: Management of e-Journals in Digital Environment
link.authors: Raza M Masoom1, DR, Lecturer, Eqbal Monawwer1, Research Scholar
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh (UP), India.
link.abstract: Over the years there been a rapid rise in the number of e-journals. In most of the cases these journals are available free to print subscribers. The management of e-journals raises a new set of issues needing urgent attention. The issues surrounding can be resolved through collective efforts and cooperation of librarians, publishers and the vendors of e-journals.

link.heading: Journal of Rock Mechanics and Tunnelling Technology: A Bibliometric Analysis
link.authors: Senapati S K1, Library Officer, Central Officer
link.authorDes: 1Central Building Research Institute, Roorkeer 247 667.
link.abstract: The paper deals with a bibliometric study on ‘Journal of Rock Mechanics and Tunnelling Technology’ during the period of 1998–2002. It examines year wise distribution of papers, authorship pattern, affiliation and country wise distribution. It also shows subject wise break-up of articles, citation pattern and illustration.

link.heading: MLIS Dissertation Practices in Selected Indian Universities: A Survey
link.authorDes: 72-B, Tapovan Complex, Jaiprakash Nagar, Nagpur-440 025.
link.abstract: The study is based on the survey conducted of the MLIS Dissertation practices in 15 Indian universities. A five part questionnaire was developed and sent to 29 universities, out of which 17 universities responded to the questionnaires. The analysis of data reveals great variations in the practices being followed in selection and allotment of topics, methodology for preparation and presentation, system of evaluation and assessment of dissertations and Viva-voce examination (where associated with the evaluation of dissertations). There is a consensus among universities to treat Dissertation, as an integral part of MLIS syllabus in all universities and it must be made compulsory in Universities where it is elective at present. Recommends avoidance of duplication in selection of topics and suggests creation of database of Dissertations submitted in LIS schools in a city at local level and bibliographical control of MLIS Dissertations at National level; evolving of suitable policy for allowing students to prepare and submit dissertations in regional languages, where MLIS education is being imparted in such languages. It is also recommended that some standardization may be achieved in the matter of evaluation system for Dissertations. Some guidelines by bodies like UGC, are considered necessary in this regard.

link.heading: A Survey of the College and University www Sites of Shillong, Meghalaya
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library and Information Science, North Eastern Hill University, Shillong, Meghalaya 793 014. E-mail: bikilaloo@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: This paper examines the websites of five academic institutions (one university and four colleges) emerging from Shillong in Meghalaya to determine whether they are able to make their digital presence felt on the World Wide Web. The websites were analyzed and their content, design, multimedia features and currency evaluated. It was found that the websites coming from this so called remote part of the country are quite up to the mark and can easily give those of bigger cities a run for their money.

link.heading: Changing Role of the Libraries in Contemporary Society
link.authorDes: 1Department of Library & Information Science, Bundelkhand University, Jhansi-284 128 (U.P).
link.abstract: Points out about changes taking place in the twenty first century. Discuss changed concept of the library. Describes the concept of Information Society. Brings out the implication of information for development. Describes the changing role of the libraries and national development. Concludes that libraries have special significance in the changing environment.

link.heading: Some Impressions of Libraries in Kuwait, USA and Canada
link.authors: Kumar Krishan, Former Head and Professor
link.authorDes: Department of Library and Information Science, University of Delhi (Address for Correspondence: K-14, Rajouri Garden, New Delhi-110 027, E-mail: krishan14@hotmail.com)
link.abstract: Mentions the emergence of digital age and globalization, and its impact on libraries. Briefly, describes libraries in USA, Canada and Kuwait. Discusses innovations employed in teaching-learning process. Describes the role of friends of the library and volunteers. Mentions about resources of some of the leading libraries. Discusses digitation going on as a major activity. Describes free access to Internet and accessibility of resources. Discusses extension activities, special services, services to people with disabilities, user education, staffing, and security system. Describes issues concerning budget cuts, digital amnesia, censorship, dress code and filtering software. Raises the question ‘do we need libraries’? Describes the efforts being made to improve the image. Concludes the libraries in Western Countries have a rich and long tradition of support from philanthropists and friends of the library.

link.heading: Minimum Standards for School Libraries
link.authorDes: 1Library and Informatics Centre, Nigerian Education Research and Development Council, PMB, 91, Abuja, Nigeria.
link.abstract: Describes minimum standards regarding objectives, space (accommodation), personnel, training, furniture/equipment, stock, funding, services (programme of activities), sustainability, publicity and evaluation.

link.heading: JALNET (Jalgaon Library Network): An Online Library Information System
link.authors: Sharma A K1, Shirude S B2, Patil A S2, Pawar B V3
link.authorDes: 1Shyamlal College, University of Delhi, Shahdara, Delhi-110032, E-mail: ajaykumarsharma19955@yahoo.com.2Department of Computer Science, North Maharashtra University, Jalgaon (M S).3 E-Mail:bvpawar@hotmail.com
link.abstract: Information plays an important role everywhere in different fields. ‘Library’ is one of the places where such lots of information reside. But there are several problems that may arise while accessing available resources of library using traditional way or approach. In the age of Information Technology, by applying IT in libraries the way by which resources can be accessed gets simplified. In short, there is formation of Virtual Library. And this phenomenon has resulted into sharing of resources by many users from any where in the world, also reduction in cost due to easy access of resources and increase in the convenience of users. The database maintained by virtual library can be accessed globally by everybody irrespective of geographical boundaries. In what follows, there is explanation of one of such design for network called as JALINET, Jalgaon Library Network and reveals how the libraries are worth to use the new concept of information technology to cater the needs of information seekers and how it is one of the channels to receive useful information.

link.heading: Automation of Agricultural Libraries in Andhra Pradesh: An Overview
link.authorDes: 1College of Fishery Science, ANGR Agricultural University, Muthukur 524 344, Nellore District (AP), E-Mail: veeru_123@rediffmail.com
link.abstract: Describes the need for automation. Enumerates the different aspects of library operations. Mentions about Agricultural Research Information System, lists agricultural libraries in Andhra Pradesh. Provides information about utilization of computers. Enumerates problems faced in automation by agricultural libraries.

link.heading: A Fresh Look at Agriculture Library Services: A Need for Change
link.authorDes: 1G B Pant University of Agriculture & Technology, Hill Campus, Tehri Garhwal 249 199, Uttranchal E-mai: nshill @rediffmail.com
link.abstract: Discusses the state of agriculture libraries in India. Evaluates agricultural libraries on the basis of parameters such as need for Agriculture Library Association, automation and networking, Agriculture Documentation Centre, professional development of library staff, professional status etc. Suggests measures for improvement of library services.
link.keywords: Agriculture Libraries; Agricultural Library Services.

link.heading: Some Aspects of the Imperial Library of Mughals during the Rule of Babar: 1526–1530
link.authorDes: 1Islampur College, Islampur (West Bengal) 733 292.
link.abstract: Highlights the position and condition of the Imperial Library of Mughals during the rule of Babar. During his rule the emperor with the help of some scholars, calligraphists, painter or binder of books on manuscripts augmented the library considerably. Mentions that during those days, the Imperial Library gained a vast fame throughout the oriental world as the library was well-managed by its Kitab-dar (Librarian) Khoaja Mahammad with the help of Yogi Khan, who was also ex-librarian of Ibrahim Lodi.
